movie_review_blurb: Despite the presence of four credited screenwriters, the plot is a rehash of cliches and tired jokes.
Clearly meant to be adorable, the kids crack jokes like screenwriters rather than children, and the plot is just as contrived as the self-conscious dialogue.
If conspiracy theories are your cup of tea -- or if you just like a good yarn -- JFK may satisfy.
While Shipp looks the part, that's about all that this neutered movie has going for it.

Even a film like Detroit-centered on a moment from hell and the real story of the harrowing death of several young Black people-can make you feel more powerful because the film privileges the Black perspective and is unflinching about our reality.
The movie would fall apart if her lyrics weren't dope-why would we care what she's fighting for?-but the fact is: Killa P can really rhyme.

Shinkai's films speak directly to the times in which they were created, and with this latest work, he has more than earned the right to step from out of the shadow of comparisons to Miyazaki and forge his own name.
One Piece Film: Gold is a pretty solid entry point for those looking to enjoy the series without having to devote hours to wading through reams of filler episodes and expository fluff.
Genocidal Organ's alternate reality cuts the closest to our own: a world in which the shadow of the past and its assorted traumas holds the future hostage.
The movie feels much like one of its many "solograms"-an expensive, artificial spectacle of vibrancy and depth, revealed to be little more than a trick of the light.
Just as the title implies, there are several secrets guarded by different characters, and the movie is about more than just tracking down the killer.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: For all its X-rated gags, Girls Trip never strays far from its main messages: The importance of female solidarity and living your truth.

This movie probably isn't going to win anybody any awards. Still, it seems a logical conclusion that most people willing to part with their hard-earned cash would be expecting something great from a film called Hansel & Gretel: Witch Hunters.
In terms of bringing the book to life, Twilight is a complete success, so much so that most of the film's flaws work within the context of the story.
Coraline is equal parts fanciful, menacing, beautiful, and subversive.
War, hormones, and dark magic equal a better-than-average year for the students of Hogwarts, and the best Potter movie since Prisoner of Azkaban.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The film's success is owed to the fact that the living, breathing actors understand the show belongs to the Muppets. In their capable paws, claws, and flippers, the fun, kindness, and total, unadulterated wackiness of The Muppet Show is finally back.

For the most part, the final movie delivers the combination of emotional intensity and rousing battle sequences befitting the end of a phenomenon that evolved from an unexpectedly popular children's book series to an era unto itself.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The supporting cast is excellent (most notably Stanley Tucci as flamboyant television host Caesar Flickerman, and Woody Harrelson as Haymitch Abernathy, Katniss and Peeta's troubled mentor).
It's not a masterpiece, but it isn't supposed to be. It is, however, a perfectly pleasant film for young children.
Condon, the cast, and the crew of The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 2 have made something they can be proud of.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Thankfully, what the film lacks in suspense it delivers in plain old fun. Whether it's a favorite dish, a ragged stuffed animal, or an animated movie, sometimes the comfort that comes along with fun is sustenance enough.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones is a beautifully shot movie featuring talented actors and a story with a lot of potential. At the end of the day, however, it just doesn't have much soul.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: While entertaining, it's a shame that The Giver, after so many years in production and with a story about the importance of individuality, would fall in line with the conventions of young-adult drama rather than allow its soul to speak for itself.
Slapstick is king in Muppets Most Wanted, and each gag is a welcome reminder that this franchise is at its best when the men are foils for the Muppets, rather than the other way around.
This is such a well-written, well-acted, and well-paced film with a great payoff at the end that it proves that "adorable" and "zombie movie" are capable of coexisting together.
This is arguably the best installment in the franchise because the love triangle is put on the back burner in favor of deeper themes.
As J.K. Rowling wove a conclusion as ominous as it was elegant in the final installment of the Potter series, so too has director David Yates in Part 1 of Deathly Hallows.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its drawbacks, Ender's Game is a visually spectacular, tightly paced film that is certainly a win in terms of adapting a seriously complicated novel.
Catching Fire is tightly paced with very little filler. No line or character is wasted.
The Island is a curious hybrid of intriguing sci-fi premise and over-the-top action sequences. Nevertheless, it manages to provide adrenaline-charged entertainment for two hours.
Harmless sequel.
Bad News Bears isn't bad, really, but it isn't good, either.
This is a honeymoon trip worth taking.
This is a film that pre-teen and young teen girls -- and for that matter, any woman who remembers being 16 -- will love. Others are likely to be teeth-gritting their way through it.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The martial-arts mastery we expect is all there, in spectacular fashion, yet the story also allows Li to show off boyish vulnerability, and it's a winning combination.
If this sequel is any indication, the next XXX will be subtitled 'Bigger, Louder, Dumber.'
Be prepared to be charmed, fall in love (several times) and laugh yourself silly. It's the perfect date movie, just in time for Valentine's Day.
Should you spend Christmas With the Kranks? Well, perhaps if you're an adolescent boy, or you have nothing better to do, then go for it. Otherwise, make other holiday plans.
It's an assault on the senses with plot holes an armored tank could drive through.
Samuel L. Jackson, who has pretty much been swaggering through recent roles, straightens up and brings a steely, dignified strength to the title role.
A gorgeous treat.
From the very first action scene in the frozen Arctic, to a chase up the Liberty Bell tower, to the climax in a tunnel deep below New York City, National Treasure takes you on an exhilarating ride.

As a whole, Shall We Dance? is enjoyable.
Bettany proves that he has the chops to carry a film.
Hey, its not like we came to this movie for its plot or anything.
An inspiring story of triumph over adversity.
Both refreshingly realistic and charmingly implausible at the same time. A real miracle, indeed.
Like many a real sunset, it'll dazzle and entertain, yet soon be forgotten.
A well-crafted film.

Though it's needlessly opaque and doesn't completely hold together, Haven seldom fails to fascinate.
While nothing ground-breaking, Flyboys is two-plus hours of passable entertainment.

This film gets more right than wrong in the playbook.
Though not flashy or 'big,' GITMO is a stark, blunt, powerful indictment.
Grant's personal experiences and his sense of British quirkiness lend the story a great deal of authenticity.
Brilliantly acted, especially by star Presley Chweneyagae, who makes Tsotsi's journey toward redemption a truly mesmerizing -- and, at times, nerve-racking -- experience.
Besides the rousing ending, which combines ballroom and hip-hop moves in an exciting way, the film offers nothing we haven't seen before.
Martin deserves another case as Inspector Clouseau -- and we deserve a better movie.
Almost makes you want to cash in your IRA and live it up.
Those scenes of everyday chaos that were so charming in the original are few here, alas.
Time and again, it goes for cheap laughs at the expense of character development. And, could the message be any shallower?
It's not nearly as good as Jumanji.
A fairly entertaining family film.

Worth the time.

n the end, The Imitation Game ably details a little-known corner of the WWII story, one that has incredible relevance today.

movie_title: All The Light In The Sky (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The west has never been less gritty, less pulpy than it is here, with the locale fading into the background when it should be a character in its own right.

My first thought after the credits rolled on Martin Scorsese's 3-hour symphony of greed and depravity was, "How in the hell did this not get an NC-17 rating"???

movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Sommers, who adapted the screenplay himself, clearly has a passion for the material and Koontz's bizarre short order cook.
A brilliant, rapid-fire examination of parenthood, ego, and maniacal genius told in a refreshingly innovative way that Jobs himself would have loved.
The first train wreck of 2014 is a labor of incompetence not even Hercules' strength can overcome.

Nymphomaniac isn't just a chance for von Trier to hit all of the politically incorrect G-spots, it's a real film with a fully-realized female protagonist who has lived a life most people will never understand
12 Years A Slave is more than just one of the best movies of the year, it stands alongside Roots as a significant cinematic contribution to this country's never ending discussion about slavery.

It makes for a daunting proposition for forward-thinking director Kimberly Peirce to update such a classic, but not only is her version one of the few truly successful horror remakes in recent years, it's simply better than the original.
An entertaining but wholly unspectacular flick that can't seem to figure out if it wants to be The Untouchables or Dick Tracy.

This is a highly confused film that doesn't seem to know exactly what it wants to be.
Packs mucho star power, boasts a gorgeous Costa Rican locale, and yet lacks the one thing that every thriller needs to succeed: actual thrills.

An unforgettable crime thriller that is guaranteed to be the most talked about and fiercely debated movie of the season.

An economical and solidly entertaining film that recaptures everything that made Pitch Black such a cult favorite.

An incredible and prescient real life story of how a savvy ad campaign brought about real political change.

An inoffensive way to spend 90 minutes, unless of course you're on the husky end of the spectrum, in which case they're all going to laugh at you.
Longtime action cinematographer Pierre Morrel proves adept at using the quick, claustrophobic cuts of the Bourne franchise and the Transporter flicks.
This new Friday the 13th is infinitely better than Jason X or Freddy vs. Jason, but it's still schlock.
It's enjoyable, though, even if it's extremely slight.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Just ugh.
The performances are outstanding across the board, which is extraordinary considering that every single shot is a first take.
While the resolution might seem a little neat for the film's naturalistic style, this is still independent filmmaking of the highest order.
If you're looking to feed the melancholy existential restlessness of the soul, there are few films that have ever done it better.
At times the structure labours, but ultimately Fanboys rises above routine Hollywood fare because it never makes fun of the people it represents.
The Lovers shows more wisdom while still embracing the explorative humanity of relationships.
The Lure is a Polish electo-punk, mermaid sex horror-musical, with heart.
Like a poem, Window Horses evolves into a story of love. Love for art, love of family, and ultimately (hopefully) love of self.
Wonderfully shot and crisply edited, the film has elements of innovation, necessity, and hope.
From writer to writer, Guillermo Calderón did Neruda proud with his sleight of plot whimsy and powerful dialogue.
As long as fully formed products like Catching Fire keep coming, the odds will be in The Hunger Games' favor to continue being celebrated as the definitive popular moral tale of the early 2000s.
The grown-ups are pretty much overshadowed by the youthful cast of the nativity play itself, who are so natural on camera that you can't help but smile.
This utterly beguiling biopic about a cleaning lady with the artistic gifts of a Van Gogh is just a bit special.
The movie gestures towards deep emotions, but an abiding soft-grained superficiality effectively insulates us from the piercing realities of grief.
Balancing emotive drama, pop history and evocative period piece, the film is undeniably engrossing and an illuminating addition to the Beatles mythology.
Ultimately, this bracingly austere film falls a little short of the greatness of the book, but it's still a terrifyingly effective warning that we squander the planet's resources at our peril.
It's fun when it's at its bitchiest, and Kutcher's astute performance will surprise a few people.
This ultra-mild frolic follows the 'fish-out-of-water' comedy formula so closely its lack of surprise is almost, well, surprising.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Rigorously controlled, perhaps at the expense of a little emotional light and shade, this is one of the Coens' subtlest films. Expect smiles, grimaces, a slightly furrowed brow, and, finally, a feeling of satisfaction.
The clunking storyline is a real drag, and the movie is essentially hobbled because the nominal lead is a rock performer not a martial artist.
The film is never flat-out terrible - just thoroughly bland.

Bana exudes downhome blokeyness throughout, but an hour of this will be enough for most, after which egomania fatigue sets in. Add another star if you're a petrolhead, two if you really like Eric Bana and cars, three if you're his mum.
Woolcock deserves praise for ambition, but this tumbles awkwardly into some netherworld between streetwise musical and social-conscience crime chronicle.
A well-intentioned misfire.
A slightly bland Portman and an overwrought Maguire rather highlight the contrived turns in the plotting of what is a thoroughly respectable effort, but one that is not all it could have been.
It's mean and upsetting, but though the cruelty may undermine the message of vengeance breeding vengeance, it's never presented as slickly enjoyable or a facile solution.
Diffuse, but worthwhile.
There's an effective thriller element to this vividly assembled doc.
Expectations of farce are stymied by long stretches of mid-life navel gazing.

The film's real problem is building momentum from its action set-pieces. Belle's agility and Raffaelli's fleet footwork are fine, but the parade of rent-a-thugs toppling like ninepins isn't very exciting.
But there's also a puppy-dog doesn't-know-any-better enthusiasm to this pacy fluff which means you can't get that worked up at it.
That a great comic idea does not necessarily make for a great screen comedy is the lesson for first-time writer-director-star Ricky Gervais as he comes unstuck.
This debut British feature weaves sundry biographical details into an awkward cross-hatch of oblique celluloid portrait and backwoods horror thriller.
The credible production design impresses, the camerawork offers an exquisite chill and Giamatti is in his pomp.
Since the fights are all digitally conjured up anyway, genuine thrills are at a minimum and the copious sprays of pixelated blood quickly pall.
Overall, the story's just a bit too neat to carry the portentous weight that the film-maker seems to be willing into the material.
Cinema that speaks to the soul.
This is undeniably an amusing movie, but it falls well short of time-twisting comedy classics like Back to the Future and Groundhog Day.

True, [its] hustle and bustle sometimes feels like too much to take in at once, yet its heavy payload of literary quotations, philosophical argument and classical music is also perhaps an act of faith in an intelligent audience.
The jury is still out on Cyrus's ability to sustain her screen career over the longer term, but this is respectable enough as a first step in that direction.
Neither sexed-up nor dumbed-down, Storm is both absorbing and satisfying.
This is one of the dullest gang flicks ever to see the light of day...

Quite how Sandra Bullock deserved an Oscar for her one-note turn as bleached supermum Leigh-Anne is a mystery, since it transforms a potentially worthwhile character study into a grandstanding star vehicle.
Director Susanna White, surely one to watch, manages some disarming emotional grace notes under the circumstances.
It's not just Greenaway's best film in years, but one of his best films, period.
Tongue-in-cheek entertainment...
Loved the chutzpah, but the heart and the funny bone are left relatively untroubled.
Unfortunately the elaborately unspooled plot delivering these ideas in dramatic form is so scraggy and effortful it defeats the cast and rather compromises our involvement.

The subsequent tragic events are moving rather than just manipulative, while the bond between man and canine is treated with a tender gravitas that might surprise those expecting merely some doggie-themed weepie.
Moderately illuminating in parts, but the clichÃ (C)s of cinematic suffering tend to overwhelm it.
An intriguing, keenly observed journey, but one that demands too much patience from the audience.

Saddled with a mostly thankless role as the straight man, Rhys Meyers is decidedly wooden, while the energetic Travolta fails to make us forget he's played this sort of freestyle psycho one too many times already.
Moore comes up with enough of these startling moments to keep us watching, though he's certainly stronger on huff and puff than concrete solutions.
Windsor's taciturn and stoic central performance is both haunting and affecting, framed by Morton's deliberate, even stately direction.
Engaging performers all, but the movie's superficial flummery is slightly exasperating when the true-life events would have provided an even richer palette of ideas.
There's an undertow of dread here reminiscent of the work of Hitchcock and Michelangelo Antonioni.
movie_title: La Mujer sin Cabeza (The Headless Woman) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's evidently Potter-ish, but unashamedly aimed at younger viewers - which makes the emphasis on the junior hero's fighting skills and a clearly misguided Las Vegas casino sequence all the more dismaying.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This micro-budget British shocker blends horror and character study to create an absolutely convincing portrait of psychosis.
The ideas probably have a bit more juice than the movie, but it's still an alert piece of entertainment.
For all the effort expended, Jordan never really entices us into believing the magic. It looks classy, but it just doesn't come off.
The pint-sized heroine's defiant adherence to humanitarian values renders her more a stand-in for arthouse viewers' right-on worldview than a real child in a specific dramatic situation.
You can't fault the film's exuberance, but it's draggy in spots, with the grown-up cast outshone by Jolie Vanier's little terror - nattily monikered Helvetica Black.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: If it just misses being this generation's 'Annie Hall', it's still deliciously refreshing, sweet and fizzy. A sherbet dip of a movie.
True, there's only the merest suggestion of an education system for these juveniles, but credibility's secondary when you've got lots of dogs doing cute stuff.
Nicely put together, but just a little dull.

It all feels very samey, the comic potential of the mock battles never approached with genuine enthusiasm but treated as a mere gag, and one which soon outstays its welcome. Amiable yet underwhelming.
It's not what you'd call any good, but Claude Lelouch fans, say, might relish its grandiose romantic gestures in the face of all known logic.
What could have been the acme of talky dramas about the inner lives of French intellectuals turns out to be a feast of a movie.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Che: Part One is the first half of a long movie rather than a satisfying screen experience in its own right, and should clearly be approached as such.

Some will find it all too polite, but compared to rival blockbuster exercises in explosive CGI mayhem, its character-based index of longing and protectiveness at least provides a viable alternative moodscape.
The result is approachable for newcomers, but with Dornhelm's camera keeping a close watch on group dynamics, it'll remind old hands to look beyond the creamy melodies.
It's a satisfying story, played out in decorous period surroundings of the classic warrior tale but Yamada's 79th film lacks any hint of surprise or excitement.
Inspired by a real-life incident, this captivating Israeli film is both a compelling story of self-determination and an astute evaluation of the current state of a divided territory.

A gripping, astringent portrayal of what happens when you try to force a revolution on territory which isn't fertile ground, in and of itself, Soderbergh's second instalment exerts a certain analytical intrigue.

Brilliantly shot, utterly convincing footage of young men inching up a vertical rock face proves nerve-racking and a worthy tribute to the true-life bravery of 1930s climbers. It's gripping and fascinating in equal measure.
The yawning chasm between the film's aspirations to social significance and its cheese-o-licious straight-to-video construction make it a chucklesome guilty pleasure.

Although it draws on a real-life memoir, this Gallic crime drama never really gets going. There's potential in the tension between a wavering ex-con and his cop sibling, but the actors seem to have been cast the wrong way round.
Dismaying, indeed, that a movie purportedly selling itself on refreshing nay-saying scepticism should so cravenly succumb to the same old schmaltz.

Perhaps Scott's ever-restless shooting style doesn't quite differentiate between the peaks and troughs of the narrative, yet it's still an engrossing account of the intersection between process and ethics.
A striking portrait of the price of fame and the transience of the music business spotlight.
movie_title: 'Tis Autumn: The Search for Jackie Paris (2007)

movie_review_blurb: There's enough charm and enterprise here to win over viewers who have the patience to stick by the tongue-tied Jorge. An intriguing change of direction for pop-video pioneer Barron, though next time he might like to cut loose that bit more.

Overall, the film's never less than lively - with Kris Marshall a nifty scene-stealer as the wise butler - yet you do get the sense that greater discipline all round would have made even more of it. As it is, it's fizzy, but variable.
Notwithstanding a willing central performance from Dujardin, the film simply lacks the comedic savoir-faire to leave us shaken, stirred or even reasonably amused.
movie_title: OSS 117: Le Caire Nid d'Espions (OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The issue of separation acquired a particular poignancy in wartime, it goes without saying, but Ryu's stoic underplaying offers a heartbreaking performance for the ages.
At this stage the emotive and thematic weight of Bergman's ambitions prove a bit too much for his decidedly functional plotting and characterisation.
movie_title: Skepp till India land (A Ship Bound for India) (1947)

movie_review_blurb: For all its transient black-and-white beauties, denies its subject the sort of solid context that would reveal the scale of her achievements. A patchy, frustrating, though loving tribute.
The ideas are fun, there are some striking design ideas (the villain's commonplace-yet-freaky mask), yet the clogged storytelling just doesn't make enough of them. Shame.
movie_title: 20-seiki shônen: Honkaku kagaku bôken eiga (20th Century Boys 1: Beginning of the End) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The guy's a hero in any musical language, and he deserves this heartfelt, emotive, supremely entertaining tribute. Anvil! We salute you!
In story terms, its cavalcade of melodrama and conflict isn't always persuasive, but writer-director Darnell Martin's respect for the music shines through.
Unsanitised, worryingly convincing in its sadomasochistic detail, this is seriously provocative cinema, a telling reminder of what it really means to be dangerous.
movie_title: In the Realm of the Senses (1976)

movie_review_blurb: The film's urgent point about the need for understanding is made with dignity and an appreciable tinge of sorrow.
It's a tribute to the visceral impact of the staging that the film retains its grip despite becoming somewhat predictable, while thematically it's the usual cycle-of-violence hand wringing.
Murphy at least tries to stay in character rather than overdoing the silly voices and physical knockabout, but maybe the material was so blah that he felt it wasn't worth the effort.
A ragbag of lackadaisical plotting, drugs references, puerile lechery and shiny effects work, an assemblage far from child-friendly yet not quite grungey enough to wow older teens.
While the film's compassion is never in doubt, it's sometimes a bit too cute for its own good.
On a scene-by-scene basis, though, it's classily effective, mainly because of Wright Penn's skill in nailing the precise tenor of every moment.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Slightly stretched at 82 minutes, the film nevertheless makes a strong case for this high, wide and lonesome sound expressing the soul of the alpine landscape, beautifully captured by the aerial camerawork.
Slightly woolly overall, though you might find yourself buying the CDs. I did.
movie_title: Am I Black Enough for You? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's a fascinating moment in history, and Mann captures the cars, the guns and the buildings with painstaking, immersive authenticity.
Even if 'Telstar' can't quite get the measure of its fascinating material, its pluck and ambition prove infectious enough to outweigh its flaws.
There's much to enjoy in this admittedly generic thriller - a snappy set-up, strong central performance and a story which escalates from cosy domesticity to bullet-riddled mayhem.
The tell-it-as-it-is title hardly indicates anything out of the ordinary, but this bare-knuckle boxing flick is put together with more love than you'd expect.

The re-creation of St Peter's and the Sistine Chapel on the Hollywood backlot is a production achievement, yet the movie's about as exciting as looking over someone's shoulder while they finish a crossword.
In the end, it doesn't satisfy as fact-based bio or love story, but we appreciate the effort.
With Kyomi's manga-drawing skills a key part of the scenario, the visual approach is sometimes too fluffily decorative to let the emotions deliver in full. Eminently likeable nonetheless.
movie_title: Funuke Domo, Kanashimi no ai Wo Misero (Funuke Show Some Love, You Losers!) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Seemingly off-hand, cumulatively imposing, utterly masterful.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's pacy all right, but glib and uninvolving for grown-ups, though perhaps furnished with enough in the way of spaceships, lasers and digital explosions to pacify undemanding little 'uns of an afternoon.
Although the action footage is impressive, it becomes repetitive, exposing the rest of the movie as something of a ragbag. Surfing fans may be more enthused.
Gray's direction lovingly toys with images of containment and release, effectively playing out the drama in visual terms - but we never really feel it.
Ambition and accomplishment are aeons apart in this would-be meaningful drama.
Evidently contrived and something of an ungainly hybrid, the film shares its canine protagonist's facility for wearing down your resistance.
Eventually, you just let the tangled double-crossing take care of itself and enjoy the way the film defiantly bucks the contemporary thriller trend for shaky-cam coverage and lightning cuts.
This impressive sports doc finds enough drama in the situation to involve a wider audience, since the archive footage of these chaps gliding through waves the size of a house is quite something.

For the most part Ridley keeps the bizarre events under a tight rein, with Sturgess turning in a compelling central performance as the vulnerable protagonist caught up in increasingly horrifying events.
Slipshod storytelling allows the excitement to peak too early, leaving us considerably less engaged by the time the underwhelming and predictable final stand-off is upon us.
It's about as substantial as a layer of lipstick, but while you shake your head at its arrant silliness, the film's brazen cheek still raises a smile.
Ultimately, the drama's more satisfying than exciting, but it's a solid entertainment nonetheless.
Channels the world-weary '70s paranoia of 'Taxi Driver' and 'The Conversation' through the imposingly clinical formal approach of process-fixated auteurs like Robert Bresson or Michael Haneke.
More man-child high-jinks in a comedy which seems to be looking down its nose at smalltown America's terminally unhip, but proves good-hearted and delivers enough laughter to seal the deal.
An intriguing misfire.
A film that's never quite as witty or thrilling as you'd hope, yet marches defiantly to its own beat.
movie_title: Les aventures extraordinaires d'Adèle Blanc-Sec (The Extraordinary Adventures of Adèle Blanc-Sec) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A blander, more responsible 'Arthur' with far fewer laughs and, be warned, a painful update on the classic Burt Bacharach title tune over the end credits.

Yes, there's enough connection with the source's underlying issues of repression and desire to give this reason to exist, but, boy, does Hardwicke labour in getting from fairy tale to would-be psycho-thriller.
It's slightly glib, very glossy and over-extended at 154 minutes. But there's an overriding sense that Canet knows this territory, and gets the best out of an excellent cast.
Billy Zane's toe-curlingly awful turn as a preening design professor turns out to be the main entertainment value on display.
Presented with all the visual intensity of a Stanley Kubrick film, this is not just a vivid dispatch from Afghanistan, it's a classic snapshot of men at war.

The director's style is certainly deliberate, but the gradual build-up of events is undeniably thought-provoking, played out in images of stark beauty as Adam's personal odyssey reaches a powerful and moving conclusion.
There's a vein of thoughtfulness running beneath the brazenly explosive action highlights and fist-pumping soundtrack, though the suspense does fall prey to some debilitating credibility issues.
Ultimately, there's something cheering and very human about a hero's journey towards the recognition of his myriad flaws.
There's plenty of grit and craft on display here, yet somehow the result is never quite as rousing as you'd hope.
The artist formerly known as "The Rock" deserves so much better.
Punchy and witty entertainment with an adept balance of adrenaline rush and clear-eyed sobriety.
It turns out that middle-ranking executives and even some corporate board members have feelings. Who knew?
Damon and Blunt have such obvious chemistry we do start believing the ripple effects from a single kiss could indeed change our collective future.
Broadway director George C Wolfe's inexperience with visual storytelling makes everything go with a clunk. Shame.
Certainly good enough to leave us once more astonished by Shakespeare's invention, yet it ultimately lacks the interpretative authority that might have made it something special.
The movie rather crumbles when it eventually has to deliver its secrets.
By trying to do something different with the characters, the film omits much of the good-hearted yet slightly edgy laughter we enjoyed so much the first time round.
Slightly anachronistic, yet altogether endearing.
Yes, it's a feature doc about a hairdresser. And you can wipe that supercilious smirk off your face right now.

Statham gives a good account of himself as the no-nonsense Detective Brant, handy with his fists and ready with a wry one-liner, but an unoriginal plot and a general lack of excitement don't do justice to either him or the high-calibre supporting cast.
Explaining it makes it sound aridly abstract, but watching it is pure delight...
Compendious and compassionate in equal measure, it's ultimately an affecting portrait.
movie_title: George Harrison: Living In The Material World (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A succession of would-be rousing clichés.
Provocative yet utterly sympathetic, this is an engrossing study of what it's like when you don't quite fit into any of the available gender roles.
You'd have to call the whole undertaking workmanlike rather than inspired.
At times, the narrative seems to be taking a somewhat roundabout route, but patience is rewarded, since this is elegant, perverse and provocative.
Two minutes 48 seconds of cuts by the BBFC have taken the edge off some unnecessary sadism, but the brush-written credits remain the highlight.
True, the resolutions on offer seem conventionally pat, yet the tough questions stay with you in an absorbing drama which pushes the viewer's buttons with effective intelligence.
A thumping modern policier with a social-conscience edge.
The script grinds its way through sundry reversals, initial jollity giving way to plodding rigmarole.
Cooper's outstanding performance(s) deserved better.
For those who grew up on the Spielberg classics, a truly nostalgic treat awaits.
Testosterone at its most tragic.
Unusual and endearing.
The storytelling really draws us into the emotional world of these vulnerable tiny folk in a way that will captivate curious younger viewers.
The didacticism takes the shine off Weitz's accomplishment, even if the film builds up enough empathy to generate slow-burning emotional impact.

[Conveys] the frustrations of dissent when the only hope of change seemingly involves stepping over the bounds of legality, before closing with some surprisingly hopeful news by way of encouraging those contemplating this path.
movie_title: Just Do It: A Tale of Modern-day Outlaws (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Offers genuine empathy with the put-upon protagonist's longing for justice, yet plays the bloody ramifications for cartoonish fun.
This campaigning documentary offers a sobering warning that the possibility of nuclear destruction is still very much with us.
Life in a Day has the integrity never to cop out on the extremes of wealth and poverty that divide us - as well as the showmanship to remain thoroughly entertaining throughout.
This worthwhile drama reports from the home front as the war on terror continues.
Excruciatingly misguided.
An acquired taste.
All in all, this is a low-key affair, but its strength is in the keen observation of how relationships develop.
Portman does seem a bit too brittle and neurotic for this sort of easygoing fluff, but Kutcher, who makes relaxed light comedy seem much easier than it actually is, proves right at home.

The sight of Dyer operating under the delusion he's channelling Al Pacino is grim enough, but the real blame must be laid at the door of director/star/co-writer Cavanah, who seriously underperforms in all three roles.
This is a superficially chic offering, which skips along pacily enough but leaves very little impression.
Iñárritu's film won't work for everyone. Yet, it offers consolation that, in a world of numbing, overwhelming anguish, human feeling is still possible.
There's the occasional twinkle from distinguished performers obviously not taking it too seriously, but this is by and large a waste of their talents.
It's riveting stuff...
Not terrible, but undemanding.
The thuddingly sincere dialogue, one-dimensional characterisation and occasionally wobbly performances turn ... sincere intentions into the stuff of cheesy melodrama.
Although there aren't enough entertaining highlights to see us through the many dull spots, the film's sheer curiosity value keeps it queasily fascinating.
A shame, really, that the title character is perhaps the least interesting, but the spot-on performances still leave us with lots to enjoy.
There's much to enjoy, if not quite enough to disguise the film's essential awkwardness in trying to cover too many bases.
It's all so dreary you'll wonder why they bothered.
A captivating film not just for pianomaniacs.
Although Angelina's star power is never in doubt, this is pacey and empty in just about equal measures.
Africa United is never less than jaunty, the locations are suitably vivid, and the intention to make a film about the "real" Africa that's not all doom and gloom can't be faulted.
At least Stone is getting a provocative alternative viewpoint across -- and in an engaging and entertaining way, too.
It's a shame Tornatore's movie, impressive statement though it is, never musters the emotional potency that would make it really special.
It's not side-splittingly funny, or exactly emotionally trenchant, but Zeta-Jones and Bartha are both decidedly charming, even if there's a notable lack of sexual chemistry between them.
In which we learn, once more, that you can take utter tosh, douse it in classical music and -- voilà! -- you've got classy tosh masquerading as something meaningful.
Since the mannered storytelling never really draws us in, we're too often left to contemplate the film's oddity instead of its emotional conflicts.
Derick Martini's first feature may inhabit similar territory to The Ice Storm and American Beauty, but it's not overshadowed by them.
It's not a terrible movie, but eliminating the romance with planter's wife Presle and sprucing up the script might have made rather more of it.

Writer-director Ralph Ziman strings it all together with slick competence, but given that leading man Rapulana Seiphemo does a persuasive line in moral ambiguity, it's disappointing that the proceedings too often default to glib shoot-'em-up.
This is vividly challenging, utterly inclusive and heartfelt cinema. It's not only gripping to watch, but it'll open your eyes to the intractable human conundrums behind the blood-stained headlines.

Although it still only just gets away with sundry homophobic and size-ist gags, there's a tad more zing than the original, though if you caught that already, be warned: this is a scene-for-scene retread.
The shambling plot strings together a series of explosive set pieces rendered ineffective by mediocre digital effects.
Jalali's film takes everything slowly, giving us plenty of time to take in the barren landscape as we wait in vain for anything of significance to happen.
Stumbles every time it attempts to rise above the perfunctory, with its tiresome comic-relief geese and bog-standard internecine rivalry in the wolf pack.
True, the plot almost overreaches itself, but it's still enormously funny and has surprising cross-generational appeal.

True, it's just a bit overlong for junior attention spans, but given that the boys get lots of movies with wizards and special effects, little girls will surely welcome a film that seems tailored just for them.
There's enough Richler-derived scope and sophistication to provide grown-up appeal, and Dustin Hoffman kicks in some memorable scene-stealing as Giamatti's embarrassingly no-nonsense old dad.
The observations on male double standards all seem rather obvious and the arbitrary resolution comes across as the purest contrivance.
Unlike François Girard's dizzyingly cinematic '32 Short Films About...', this just looks like standard arts telly.
movie_title: Genius Within: The Inner Life of Glenn Gould (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Thanks to strong performances from Michelle Williams and Ryan Gosling, there's a genuine emotional credibility to Derek Cianfrance's film, though it's by no means comfortable viewing.
As simple exploitation fare, this barely works since the intermittent carnage never gathers much momentum - and a big, bare-knuckle set piece is dismayingly tame.
While the hushed tones of Fox's would-be naïf commentary slightly grate after a while, his film's images, contrasting natural beauty with industrial horror show, are bracingly effective indeed.
For all the film's occasional peaks, we're left with the sense of a story so incredible even this cinematic visionary is struggling to contain it on celluloid.
The film's freewheeling strangeness leaves the viewer unable to decide if it is truthful or exploitative, genuine or faked.
Yes, it's dreck, but we've all seen duff movies. What makes this so painfully exasperating is that 'The Tourist' is so bloody pleased with itself.
Some viewers might find the pacing over-deliberate, but it's clearly part of the film's plan to immerse us in these lives of devotion, and it works beautifully.
Quote not available.
Yen, with his fleet footwork and rippling torso, may have the moves, but he certainly doesn't have the material.
movie_title: Legend of the Fist: The Return of Chen Zhen (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The film's keen observation of individuals in crisis, not to mention its adept balance of life-affirming wit and chastening introspection, give it plenty of heart.
movie_title: The Be All and End All (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Very big train hits stuff. Bish bash bosh. Job done. Great fun.

Imposing, yet slightly academic.
The American is always coolly watchable, but the suspicion remains that there's rather less here than meets the eye.
Overall, this is captivating as a riot of rhythm and colour, but somewhat disappointing in the story department.

It's a convoluted set-up that fails to deliver on its promise, combining vindictive yet scarcely believable characters with regular doses of queasy sentiment.
There are some surprisingly poignant moments amid the high jinks.
Sombre and piercing, The Hunter courageously defends the right to voice resistance.

Still, the quicksilver editing and thumping score mean it's zippily put together, and an undeniable willingness to engage with a youthful audience is admirably inclusive.

Apart from the brushed metal production design and pin-sharp camerawork, this offers only moderate excitement.
Nobody made this heart-warming fluff better than MGM.

Zinnemann's customary care for detail pays occasional dividends, but the film goes on rather too long.
A mild holiday caper, for the wettest of afternoons.
Not unbearably terrible, just thoroughly mediocre.

Insomnia director Erik Skoldbjaerg knows his '70s conspiracy thrillers backwards. As a result, Pioneer delivers insidious, shadowy tension.
This well-acted adaptation of Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie's award-winning novel starts like a college soap opera, before turning into a Nigerian Gone with the Wind.
Believable, emotionally complex performances help sustain momentum, yet the direction takes a misstep by withholding information to create a greater sense of mystery.
Captivating, educational stuff: ideal viewing for families looking to broaden their cinematic horizons.
movie_title: A Story Of Children And Film (2014)

movie_review_blurb: With only 74 slowly unfolding shots, it's closer to gallery installation than conventional cinema, but for audiences open to the experience, it's inexplicably compelling.
Writer-producer-star Jonny Owen's amiable central turn just about gets the movie through myriad sticky patches.
Hits the heights in its first forty minutes ... Later developments prove disappointingly predictable.
Much sound and fury ensues, but without a compelling story behind it, it signifies very little.
Proves that technical knowhow and a reliable old yarn will only get you so far when imagination is lacking.
For Francophiles of a literary bent, just hearing these two actors silkily unfurling their lines will be frisson enough
Very nearly classic Peter Greenaway.
Chic yet exasperating, it's somehow quintessentially French - just not in a good way.
Those who like to discover a film for themselves will find this a rewarding, reflective experience.

This thorough, engrossing film shows how idealistic Aussie hacker Julian Assange took on the might of the US, exposing their military and diplomatic misconduct, then allowed his own murky personal life to tarnish his credibility.
movie_title: We Steal Secrets: The Story Of Wikileaks (2013)

movie_review_blurb: This ambitious low-budget Welsh drama never quite finds a way to make its emotional drama matter much to the audience.
An urgent portrait of compassion under fire.
Not dissimilar in merrily ghoulish spirit to 'The Nightmare Before Christmas', it's hugely entertaining.

For all its flaws '71 offers a lapel-grabbing, immersive viewing experience likely to shake up audiences who couldn't otherwise care less about the boredom-factor whys and wherefores of Northern Ireland's bitterest years.
[An] easy-going charmer in which deftly tailored banter and evident chemistry prevail over predictable plotting to deliver a comedy with clear appeal for an older audience.
The film generates potent, often claustrophobic drama while never losing our sympathy for the fragile, resilient Effie.
A deeply satisfying combination of fascinating subject, ace performers and refined directorial sensibility.
Just when you thought Italian arthouse cinema was on a roll, it comes under the malign influence of Paul Haggis's 'Crash'.
A landmark in political cinema
Amiable observational humour and likeable performances.
movie_title: What We Did on Our Holiday (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Accompanied by a valuable ruminative voiceover from Cave himself, pondering the interconnectedness of his many narrative songs, the whole artefact offers a fascinating portrait of an artist and performer with a relentless drive to create.
Given the deadly stakes, this should be gripping, but the film gets sucked into academic plot details, trudging through each rendezvous and stakeout.
Yes, it takes far too long to get to the punchline, but there's genuine emotion in the story's life-affirming take on the mental shackles we create for ourselves.
The usual Nordic Noir garnishings of furrowed seriousness, chilly visuals and grim subject matter add a dash of flavour to this plodding crime procedural but still fail to enliven it.
movie_title: The Keeper of Lost Causes (Kvinden i buret) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: For a drama pretty much aimed at 12-year-old girls, this is less superficial than you'd expect.
This remains a textbook example of fantasy cinema's ability to tackle thorny moral issues while splattering the screen with gloopy creature effects.
Philip Gröning builds his would-be magnum opus of domestic unease in fragments. A three-hour running-time, however, means an awful lot of fragments.
movie_title: Die Frau des Polizisten (The Policeman's Wife) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's as if Ferrara's just chucked all the bits in the air and left us to deal with it ourselves - which is a surprisingly effective approach to the sort of material that could easily have made for a superficial and preachy movie.
Pretty much everything in this South Korean co-production is slightly undercooked, lacking the same degree of sprightly wit or dramatic punch regularly found in A-list studio product.

This doc attempts to put a human face on the statistics, not only following the grisly day-to-day of American officials dealing with the bodies, but also exploring the dead man's rural Honduran background.
You can imagine ET phoning his legal team, but although this kids' sci-fi adventure is derivative, its characters are drawn with more care and insight than you'd expect.
Pettyfer and Wilde (both Brits) look the part in a soft-drinks-commercial way, but their characters might as well be called Ken and Barbie for all the depth they bring.
Not exactly arthouse, but as subtitled fluff goes, we're talking première classe.
A vivid and valuable historical document.
movie_title: The Battles Of Coronel And Falkland Islands (1928)

movie_review_blurb: Fiennes's confident direction captures every nuance in a subtle, accomplished and intelligent piece of film-making.

It's pacy, engrossing, and Jake Macapagal's turn as the plucky schmuck protagonist is stellar

It's gripping stuff - even if the original title 'Snabba Cash' is way cooler than the English one.
A sweet-natured character study that's altogether charming, if not exactly hard-edged.
That old arthouse chestnut, about the restorative power of naked young women, gets another outing in this pretty but superficial musing on the creative process.
movie_title: El artista y la modelo (The Artist and the Model) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Its encouragement to let ourselves be captivated by everyday humanity as well as the old masters is both richly illuminating and quirkily endearing.

The most visually imaginative American film since David Lynch's Eraserhead.

A film that's well aware of its own hipness, but never too cool to laugh and cry.

movie_title: En Lektion i Kärlek (A Lesson in Love) (1954)

movie_review_blurb: It's no less schematic than it sounds, but solid performances and straightforward handling make Bergman's fourth feature the most fully achieved, though hardly most characteristic, of his fledgling film career to that point.

A film as uplifting, dramatic and mysterious as the startling events on which it is based.

This isn't just another arthouse film, but a powerful testament to incredible human resilience
