movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The film, shot in black and white, doesn't follow a linear storyline. But the message of his jet-setting lifestyle and, more crucial, the naturalness of his gift is clear.

Visually, the director's flair is impressive. But Longley's clear intention of using children's faces to better tug at our heartstrings would be more admirable if it didn't feel as shamelessly staged.

With a nearly two-hour running time that includes its share of blowhards, repetition, and cheesy attempts to heighten drama, Cocaine Cowboys brings to mind an unfortunate comparison: Miami Vice. The movie.
Driving Lessons is as dull as its title.

The most impressive ingredient is Cohen, whose inflection and timing are dead-on as he negotiates a vague accent, a native language composed of gibberish and a sprinkling of Polish, and a way of making tired American jokes funny again.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Like most sports movies, Stick It has a message: Unless they're equipped with loads of sass-back and a pile of band T-shirts that announce their hardcoreness, female gymnasts are really, really stupid.
It's not a bad film -- grading on a curve, it's actually rather enjoyable. But Burton-Depp devotees salivating for a bleak holiday blockbuster need to dial down their expectations.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Who knew that Judd Apatow, the master of sex comedies, also spoke jive?
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The result, for all its swirly colors and surrealism, is alternately dull and irritating, an experience akin to learning that you're going on a field trip only to discover that it's to the box factory.
Letts' story is ultimately an extreme cautionary tale about how a little bit of passion can make you do magnificently fucked-up things.
Severance is a story of terrible things that couldn't have happened to funnier people.
It doesn't matter if you love music or inspirational stories or Robin Williams (anyone?) -- this is enough to make your teeth ache.

The explosion of AIDS is the film's sobering heart, but the manner in which it affects those who witness it makes the story universal and, through each person's small, life-affirming reactions, hopeful.
You'll likely experience a strong reaction to Funny Games, but therein lies the conundrum: Is the film simply reprehensible, or is it art?
The target's a slow-moving one, and the digs get old fast.
It may be time for Van Sant to remove his head from -- well, let's call it the underground -- and re-find his inner Forrester.
Does anyone actually remember The Matrix Reloaded or Revolutions? They kinda sucked. The realization will hit you like a thud of Neo-ian philosophy before Speed Racer even hits the halfway mark.

Milner and Poulter are incredibly natural in roles that ask them to be alternately goofy, angry, and melancholy -- never poor-widdle-me sad -- skills that are further emphasized in the film's third gem: the boys' movie itself.
By the end of its serpentine even-a-sports-flick-can-house-a-con plot, you may be too busy rolling your eyes to buy into the rabid-fan axiom that even minor Mamet is a treat.

The dialogue can be summarized thusly: Hannah's female friends go, "Awww!" 'Eeeeee!' and 'Oooooh!' And Tom's friends say things such as, 'Any time is the right time to say I love you!' You'll be ready to retch even before Act 2.
After a parade of romantic comedies that shoot one-liners with machine guns or twist circumstances to contrivance, it's a relief to enjoy a story that just feels natural.
Instead of a B movie, Jay Lee barely delivers a double-D.
[Perelman] makes like a poet on Provigil and starts dumping symbolism by the bucket, until you can't help but sit there, Beavis & Butt-Head-like, thinking, 'This means something.'

This modern-day, partly animated fairy tale is a cheery love story, yes, but it's also a little Scream and a lot of Hairspray, cleverly sending up its shamelessly feel-good genre yet sending you off with a fizzy high nonetheless.
Pacino's bluster isn't quite as big as his hair in this one, at least. But he still often comes across as one of those people who've crossed the line from "eccentric" to "deluded."
In this unbearably smug dramedy, the humor is nearly nonexistent and the drama will irritate you just enough to stave off a snooze.
Without Cheryl Hines or Chris Parnell, The Grand would be a fast fold.
The scene in which Elmaleh's Jean is caught waiting tables is alone enough to make the script's eventual romantic-comedy pitfalls forgivable.
Body of War doesn't bombard you with statistics or parade talking heads to beat the dead-horse argument that the invasion is a tragedy fueled by bullshit. Its pull is more human.
The story aims to be a quaint, classy crime drama. But its quaintness comes off as laughably old-fashioned, and instead of classy, it's just plain dull.
A disappointment for moviegoers who prefer their escapist entertainment to be less, well, utterly inert.
Although you can see the finish line from the starting shot, Pegg elevates the movie from eye-rolling to forgivably genial with his ace delivery and genuinely entertaining pratfalls.
The film's biggest failure isn't Accio's constant contentiousness, nor the story's dense political center. Rather, it's the script's tendency to wander.
movie_title: Mio Fratello è Figlio Unico (My Brother Is an Only Child) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The things Martian Child gets right are strong enough to save this apparent glucose-spiker.
It's certainly melancholic, occasionally funny, and ultimately life-affirming. But overall, it feels as if writer-director Goran Dukic dropped a rather promising ball.
47 doesn't even want the girl. What kind of action movie is this? A skippable one, ultimately.
Diary wields its "criticism" of bloggers and MySpace addicts as if it were the bludgeon and you the brain-feeder.
You may not remember how exactly this trio passed the time during most of the film's too-spare 98 minutes, but Plutarco is a character you likely won't forget.
Nanking bombards you with words and images of acts too barbaric to fully absorb.
In Bruges may, at its core, be just another Tarantino-esque shoot-'em-up with jokes, but it's been a long time since someone's gotten one right.

The film is very reminiscent of No End in Sight in its ability to induce teeth-gnashing, using one cab driver's wrongful death story to launch into a breakdown of how the American military's interrogation system has, well, broken down.

Along with the comics' constant riffage and the doc's terrific, vintage-country soundtrack, the film's full of joyful moments that pretty much guarantee you'll feel better walking out than you did going in.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's a testament to the brilliance of Mungiu's writing and the actors' performances that the conversations feel more natural than anything captured on a reality show.
Like Charlie's classmates, you'll likely be skeptical when the film introduces itself -- and then surprised when you're won over by its small charms.
Bayona successfully bathes his film in a very similar, Pan's Labyrinth ambience and generally proves himself a skilled acrobat in negotiating the material's triteness.
An art-house cartoon about war and revolution as seen through the eyes of a potential Blossom is more than just unique -- it's rich, eye-catching, educational, and, yes, crowd-pleasing.
Viewers prone to motion sickness should bring Dramamine or take through-the-fingers viewing breaks. Otherwise, Cloverfield is a blast.

This is the Coens' masterful return to Blood Simple territory. The biggest thing you'll notice is the quiet: Whether it's the lack of a soundtrack or a lack of dialogue, the silence often makes the tension unbearable.
Despite all its melancholy, The Band's Visit is often quite humorous and warm, and its underlying message of common humanity is elegantly rendered.
Violence is the overwhelming and viscerally unsettling theme...but the story's subtext is the paternal absence that leads kids to such aggression, not unlike less-developed Hollywood fare.
'Wrestling the bear' isn't quite as colorful as 'jumping the shark.' But Ferrell's fight with a not-so-gentle Ben suggests the glory days of his dumb-guy shtick are over.
If you think all there is to Hugh Hefner is a smoking jacket and a posse of blondes, this film will likewise strip that assumption.
movie_title: Hugh Hefner: Playboy, Activist and Rebel (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The film's trailers suggest the triteness you're in for, and Morgan Freeman's opening narration -- his usual wise-old-black-man spiel -- seconds it.
The film occasionally gets weighed down by its ponderousness, but despite a few lags, it's always involving.
You, too, may be feeling violently angry by the time the movie ends. Did the writers-directors sprinkle their reels with the script's airwave-riding rage-ohol? Nope: The Signal just sucks.

Honeydripper is an electrifying period piece about how music can bring folks together and generally save one's soul -- or at least its final 15 minutes is. The rest of the time, it's just a lot of sassy talk and scenery.

This is a story about all wide-eyed dreamers as much as it is about him: When Reilly reads off the roster of his classmates in a New York acting class for the dirt-poor, it's a simple act that's hugely inspiring.
Please, enough with Napoleon Dynamite Syndrome already.
Audiences who've laughed their asses off at Rogen's other work will be pleased to know that Superbad is not just another teen movie.
Bobby and Peter Farrelly don't bring any fresh insight or relevance to their remake of The Heartbreak Kid. Mainly, they've taken a decent comedy and turned it into a...decent comedy.
Ronan has a remarkably self-possessed, haunted quality that would be impressive for a newcomer of any age.

All this bellowing and testosterone gets old fast -- especially since there's not much of a plot outside of the combat scenes, and the not-much-of-a-plot scenes are laden with dialogue worthy of Anakin and Padmé.
To put it plainly, most of Off the Black is simply terrible.
By the time No End in Sight gets to a late chapter titled "Things Fall Apart," you'll believe that call could have been made a long time ago.
Regardless of your feelings about the fantasy genre, there's one thing everyone can agree on: Elves should not be 5-foot-6.
If a horror movie is of true holy-bejesus caliber, you should be exhaling with relief at the end instead of thinking, 'Gee, that went fast!'
A portrait of a marriage, Capturing the Friedmans-style.

It often feels like a dream -- specifically, someone else's, a nonlinear, illogical synapse explosion that's always fascinating to the person in whose head it detonated but not so much to those experiencing it secondhand.
27 Dresses is a closet full of tired, bursting with characters, dynamics, and perspectives that went out of fashion many films ago.
Keaton and Latifah lend enough intelligence, wit, and charm to their characters that Mad Money often feels like an ovarian Ocean's Eleven.

Ultimately, Book of Secretsis an embarrassingly by-the-numbers rehash of the first National Treasure, lighter on the swirly, emotion-cuing music but still well-trafficked in ridiculous feats and worse dialogue.
How She Move is as lazy about its good intentions as most of the other recent dance dramas that may vaguely come to mind.
Considering that parts are frightening, parts are nauseatingly sweet, and it's all confusing, it's not clear which demographic Mimzy is aiming for.
An alleged story of determination and empowerment, about the lengths -- and girths -- a formerly timid dowager will go to in order to save someone's life.
After previous Bond-skewerers from Get Smart to The Naked Gun to Austin Powers, this feels like just another stretched-thin case of been there, spoofed that.
movie_title: OSS 117: Le Caire Nid d'Espions (OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Turns out the old man can still take hits to both body and ego and remain as cheer-worthy as the first time he rocked a bullwhip and dusty lid.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The Pool is as quietly pleasant as its namesake.
The emptiness felt by Yiyun Li's characters doesn't seem as much the result of an emotional void than a too-thin plot.
movie_title: A Thousand Years of Good Prayers (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The tone swiftly becomes more serious in the film's last reel, coming to a brilliant (or infuriating, depending on your beliefs) head with a Maher monologue that's stunningly biting and incisive.
A valentine to first loves, New York City, and the ability of a good iTunes collection to become your therapist and best friend.

This being a Palahniuk story, Victor is not his peccadillos. That's the (loose) moral that serves as redemption in a film with situations so seedy and humor so dark you'll feel a little ashamed after laughing.
Georgiana seems to get dumber as the years go on instead of learning how to play the game. Blame the hats and rent Atonement.
The Roberts family, constantly helping others, maintains both a realistic and positive perspective on their situation, with Kimberly in particular showing remarkable resilience.
The final installment of Mackenzie's 'sex trilogy' is so strenuously edgy it's tiresome.
Chabrol's fluid camera and less-is-more storytelling is thrillingly Hitchcockian, and his lack of judgment regarding the sexuality of his characters is refreshingly French.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An unremarkable and often dull writing and directorial debut.
Barnev gives a deftly Chaplinesque performance...but Díte never really finds any meaning or lessons in the choices he made, and neither will the audience.
movie_title: I Served the King of England (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Ignore the boorish main character, and The Grocer's Son is salvageable as a celebration of rustic pleasures.
movie_title: Le fils de l'épicier (The Grocer's Son) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: With each familiar story, you wish Sharma dug a little deeper into the issue. Still, his message conveys.
Even viewers burned out on talk about politics and war will be queasily engrossed by conversations inside Samir's cell.
With a different cast -- and fewer saccharine-cutting jokes -- the film might be completely dismissible. But all the actors have a charm.
movie_title: In Search of a Midnight Kiss (2008)

movie_review_blurb: You shouldn't want to cheer when a criminal uses dirty money to save the family flat-screen from repo.
Apparently, characters are supposed to be so racist, controlling, and narrow-minded, it's funny.
High School Musical with needles and dye jobs.
Demme's shaky-cam I'm-not-trying approach actually screams the opposite, but scriptwriter Jenny Lumet and a terrific cast credibly transport you into the middle of a family maelstrom anyway.
Hilarity does occasionally ensue, though it's almost exclusively courtesy of Sex Drive's big guns, James Marsden and Seth Green.
A be-true-to-yourself message prevails, one that can be safely stretched to it's-OK-to-be-gay. But the film never definitely takes the stand that homosexuals can't be 'converted.'
An undignified mess that should embarrass Rickman and everyone else involved.

There's a sense throughout that this movie, stuffed script and all, means something. It's art! Only toward Australia's heavy-handed end do you realize that no, it's not art. It's a bloated cheesefest that will likely bomb at the box office.
Twilight is not Bram Stoker's Dracula...because, ew, who'd want a hottie who weakens or combusts in sunlight when he could just, well, sparkle instead?
Disney's holiday tentpole is an engaging, solid effort. Its primary fault? Being released the same year as WALL%u2022E.
A generally odd project: The balance of pathos and humor never seems quite right, and the end is as puzzling as any of the rest. But it's a remarkable Van Damme performance.
The film's last-chapter flood of confession and emotion is cathartic for the audience as well as the characters.
Elsa and Michele's story is such a deft study of what can make a relationship go to pieces that it's a satisfying watch in spite of all the bitterness.
Campbell may do a great job of playing himself, but both the character and the actor deserve a better project.

There's a commendable amount of originality in Lindqvist's story and even in Alfredson's elegant vision of it...[but] you get the feeling the book supplied a lot of details that didn't make it into the screenplay.
Kaufman's other works at least weaved a thread of hope within all their bends; here, the lack of it is glaring and sinks the viewer's spirit along with the film itself.
A juvenile test of one's stomach and patience.
movie_title: Another Gay Sequel: Gays Gone Wild! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Highlights, besides Smith's wittily offensive dialogue, are the porn scenes themselves.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Rarely goosebump-inducing and often rather dull...but you'll become entranced by the animation.
movie_title: Peur(s) du Noir (Fear(s) of the Dark) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Tornatore's instincts for crafting a stylish, nonlinear thriller are indisputable. But he's not yet a master, and at times you'll feel cheated even as you anticipate the next disquieting scene.
Pride and Glory remains gripping despite offering little more than what you can catch on the latest CSI. But if you prefer your escapism bleak, here's pay dirt.
Craig and Dench alone are enough to keep it entertaining, superior to the goofy Pierce Brosnan flicks if not nearly as impressive as Casino Royale.
Can the movie version bring any surprises? Not really, but in Howard-like fashion, it's a satisfying two hours.
When the humor doesn't involve sweaty armpits or vomit, it's alternately dry, silly, and profane -- a mixed bag that will serve as a nice antidote to viewers maxed out on Apatow blue.
Compared to films such as Tropic Thunder and The Blair Witch Project, Baghead's poke at the film industry and attempt at verite horror are a little like making vroom-vroom noises next to a Porsche.
Overacted, underwritten, and with flashback cues so lazy the characters may as well just say, "I remember when...," the film feels like The Notebook II.
The film is most absorbing when Herzog stays out of the way.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A dense but enthralling biography that manages to keep its focus on the Rolling Stone journalist while exploring Gibney's political obsession at the same time.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Alexandra washes over you like a gentle slice-of-life movie rather than polemic, with Vishnevskaya demanding your attention every moment she's onscreen.
This antihero merely spreads his suckage filmwide.
Another Pixar triumph in storytelling...you'll recognize in the wee machine a version of yourself.
The interplay between Broderick and Snow ultimately make Finding Amanda more enjoyable than it should be.
The Wackness is a nostalgia piece, but ultimately explores the more universal question of how to deal.
An Iraq satire being released past the point when discussing the occupation has become wearying and parodying it a slow-target yawn.
Even if what the very idea of such a stunt gives you is a knot in your stomach rather than a lump in your throat, Man on Wire is pure delight.
Marvel's second production leaves you with an unmistakable impression: The geeks have finally inherited their universe, and they're going to have as much fun with it as superhumanly possible.
It's easier to appreciate the craftsmanship of Savage Grace than enjoy it as entertainment.
Feels quite different than Suspiria and Inferno, like a more stylish and sorcerous take on torture porn that you might expect from Eli Roth after an extended European vacation.
movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Not reporting a man stuck in your windshield because you realize you were wasted: logical. Not believing it was your fault: priceless.
Bell presents an entertaining but ultimately sneaky piece. By the end of the doc, you realize the debate -- while informative and occasionally eye-opening -- is largely one-sided.
The story is essentially Doc's, but the more compelling aspect of Surfwise is the obvious question: Are the kids dysfunctional or what?
Eventually, you stop snickering at the Sardinas' trailer-trashiness and empathize with the humanity beneath their glitter.
Hamlet 2's laughs and inventiveness are as spotty as the ability of its drama teacher to recognize brilliance. But the music is a knockout, and Coogan is consistently the best part of the film.
Damned if it doesn't suck you in like a late-night rerun of Rock of Love.
movie_title: Une Vieille Maîtresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Walking out to your own city's streets afterward, you'll likely have a "Hey, this isn't Gotham!" moment. It's a level of transportation that no cackling, Kool Aid-colored villain could achieve, but it's what every comic book fan truly wants.
You can feel the filmmakers' manipulation at every turn, yet there's a melancholy and life-is-a-gift spirit that still conveys.
Downey's racial transformation is a mere launching point for a performance so brilliant, it's fair to regard Lazaurs as August's Joker.
What would you do if your only chance of survival involved aiding the Nazi regime?
Breaking up is hard to do when you're wearing nothing but a pout and were just regaling your soon-to-be-ex with a celebratory wang-flapping to welcome her home.
Rudnick maintains a deft balance between personal journal and objective examination of the issue.

Creadon's managed to turn dry material into engaging cinema before with the nerderiffic Wordplay, and though I.O.U.S.A. lacks that film's narrative tension -- this time, we know who loses -- it still sugars its medicine.
You might want to cancel that camping trip after watching Andy Abrahams Wilson's candid and frightening look at Lyme disease.
You could listen to a greatest-hits CD with nearly the same result.
The film Gus Van Sant wanted Paranoid Park to be.
The rapport between Rogen and Franco is immediately charming...more important, it's pretty funny when they're high together.
It'd all be tres dull if it weren't for the magnificent faces of Pauline Acquart and Adele Haenel. Actually, it still gets dull, even if at times the film skirts kiddie-porn territory.
You feel the students' relief when they graduate -- and breathe easier remembering that that chapter of your life is over as well.
Does anyone really want to sit through the campaigning, scheming, and dissecting of fictional candidates when we're drowning in the minutiae of real ones? Especially with Costner?
Step Brothers immediately dirties its sitcom-ready path with humor that's largely filthy and occasionally flat-out weird.
Regardless of whether you recognize the names of Christopher Isherwood or Don Bachardy, this masterful documentary draws you into the men's lives like a star-studded bedtime tale.

Even if the opening riff of "Teach Your Children" makes you want to stab an incense stick in your eardrum, there are enough detours to make the doc surprisingly compelling to anyone with an interest in the state of the union.
The Zombie Strippers of biker movies.
Solondz seems to grasp for significance while hating his creations.
Even if you're so spatially challenged that you can't make one Lego brick out of two Lego bricks, you'll find this documentary moderately charming, if self-aggrandizing.
Amiable enough if underwhelming.
Rémi Chayé's economical 81-minute film, penned by three scripters, may not have the emotional and visual depth of a Pixar gem, but it's delightful nonetheless.
movie_title: Long Way North (Tout en haut du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Cuarón's second feature suggests that he's talented enough to follow in his father's footsteps. But though Desierto may entertain, it hardly slays.

Campos doesn't sugarcoat it. None of Christine, in fact, is wrapped in sweetness -- it's all medicine. But its ability to grip you with its sadness and mourning offers something better: one woman's truth.
Ice Guardians is a thrilling highlight reel with some bonus game strategies thrown in.
What makes Peter and the Farm particularly engrossing is Dunning's talk of his depression and art.
Arrival may offer a few too many metaphors to keep some viewers engaged. But it's guaranteed to stick in your mind a fair amount longer than, say, Men in Black 3.
You can't help but like the guy, who's at once full of braggadocio and self-deprecation.
An effective thriller.

Perhaps only Christopher Guest can pull off an entirely improvised movie. And perhaps Malick should return to scripts, full-volume voiceovers, and more linear storytelling if he doesn't want to Woody Allen himself and push away fans for good.
Dalio, despite good intentions, does not offer the sort of lyrical artistry referred to here.
If Larraín's intention was to both slam the church and give his audience a hint of how repulsed, traumatized, and likely complicit its victims felt, he hit it out of the park.
The issues presented in Where to Invade Next are disillusioning enough to provoke reflection on our society instead of irritation at Moore's antics.
Whenever Alton interacts with anyone besides his parents, Lieberher's attempt to appear as if from another, more developed plane is more often flat and borderline silly than foreboding.
Rowling may be back, but her magic has largely been lost.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Yes, the actress nails Jackie's soft, breathy, almost brittle voice. Yes, she moves about with the perfect posture and grace that Kennedy was known for. Yet her Jackie rarely feels lived-in.
These good intentions never translate into a good movie.
Besides the lush backdrops (and yes, the fiery eruptions are also spectacular, just overused) Tanna's most impressive aspect is its performances.
The story's strangeness makes it interesting enough, but it's somewhat lacking in terms of what the couple's day-to-day lives and mindsets were like while imprisoned.
The result is a treat.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Maggie's Plan still manages to be enjoyable despite its flaws. It offers bits of intellectual musing as well as mild humor throughout.
Louder Than Bombs may be a bit theatrical in its telling, but its ever-present, if largely low-lying, gut punch rarely feels unrealistic.
Redundancy is key to absorbing many Hindu teachings, mind you, but we don't need to repeatedly watch people chow down or get dressed or avoid cows in the road.
Yes, there's hugging at the end, but there's also no sugarcoating the truth about drugs.

You may very well find L'attesa's premise absurd. But the actresses' finessed portrayal of two women peeling away niceties to reach a truth elevates the script till you forget your irritation over its whys and stay transfixed by its hows.
The most impressive part of Papa is that it's the first American movie to be shot in Cuba since 1959. As far as the film itself, however, it might as well have been titled The Old Drunk and the Sea.
Although Fireworks Wednesday holds its own among Farhadi's impressive catalog, it's not his best.

Its third act may leave you sickened instead of surprised. Elle is not for the closed-minded. Michèle's home and lifestyle may project a sense of chicness, but it never completely obscures the ugliness underneath.

There's enough humor to elevate the script above total idiocy. And as with Schulman and Joost's fake documentary, you'll always be wondering what's going to happen next, even if you're a little embarrassed for doing so.
In Little Men, director Ira Sachs demonstrates how a pebble dropped in a puddle can create a tsunami.
While watching Miss Sharon Jones!, you might come to think that the film's title is missing a couple of exclamation points.
Streamlining a film to cut out the fluff can be a great thing; editing it till its bones show, however, is obviously less than ideal.
Even though the audience knows how this story ends up, the film does little to shed light on how it truthfully started.
Want to punch the narrator in the face? Good, we're on the same page.
Neither the humor nor the drama are strong enough not to feel derivative.
Saylor is alternately stiff and extraordinary here, not so great at playing the sober innocent but an ace at the blurry motions of someone who's extremely wasted.
Gleason, needless to say, is not an easy sit.
La La Land's transportive reverie is its strength.
Every plot turn plays as either a little too convenient, too uncharacteristic, or too undercooked.
Its dizzying volume of numbers, names, facts, and "facts" are just as headache-inducing and bewildering as any Transformers flick.
movie_title: The Best Democracy Money Can Buy (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Exhilarating from start to finish.

Writer-director Josh Mond's feature debut is a devastating portrait of the stress of being a caregiver, particularly one so young, that's remarkably free of sentimentality or a typical tearjerker's cues.
Feels less like a hagiography and more like your grandpa telling stories about the good ol' days.
(The end) slams the brakes on any goodwill you had for the characters.
With boys -- and men -- on the side, the females of the film anchor it with ease, once again proving that a good drama is dependent on everything except the actors' genders.
This may be the Jobs biopic you've been waiting for, even if you sometimes forget that it's about Jobs.
Sarsgaard's sleepy, soothing voice and demeanor are bewitching.
You root for these characters all the way.
Being able to bear witness firsthand to this three-month struggle is an incredible privilege, albeit a heartbreaking one.
movie_title: Winter on Fire: Ukraine's Fight for Freedom (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Winds up being that rare beast: the buddy comedy where you're not tired of the buddies well before the credits roll.
We get to see what sets off wild applause and nauseatingly insincere-seeming smooching: a wardrobe inspired by... McDonald's.
Turns out people can get really irritable after seeing heaven.
Decides to go for - nay, strain for - antics. You can hear the brainstorming: What can we have happen to them?
The documentary feels like a puzzle whose pieces were forced together by a toddler.

movie_review_blurb: Regardless of its similarities to Before Sunrise, it mostly works.
Many aspects of A Sinner in Mecca are fraught...so why does it seldom feel like a matter of life or death?
The laughs are mild, but at least some exist.
From Villalba's apathetic attitude toward his patient to detestable insurance company policies... the film's gradual revelations make Sonia's actions justifiable -- almost.
movie_title: A Monster With A Thousand Heads (Un Monstruo de Mil Cabezas) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Embrace of the Serpent is ultimately too mysterious to win many fans.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Hope is overall too knee-jerk mean to like very much. But Rauch's timing is impeccable, wringing a smile even after minor jokes.
Despite its missteps, this is a sweet and inviting road trip, taking place in the colorful fall and accompanied by an indie soundtrack that lulls.
Even coming nearly four years after the shooting, Newtown remains devastatingly timely.
This documentary may indeed stir outrage and encourage victims to report such crimes. But it's still a song we've heard before.

London Road does slow to a crawl at times, and occasionally it's hard to get past its inherent weirdness. But when the characters' movements are dancelike and their songs rhythmic, you may just be mesmerized.
Within the tempest, though, Maïwenn captures some lovely scenes.

It gets beneath the skin by examining the state of isolation at the bottom of the world.
I'm wondering if it is possible to do something analogous to a citizen's arrest and file a credit dispute on behalf of the viewing public. Nobody produced this film.
It was my pleasure, as an intermediate-level Stones buff, to see that director Brett Morgen has put together something reeking of astringent danger.
That neither Krauss nor anyone has anything remotely unflattering to say about the subject points to the fundamental dishonesty of the work, which extends from its excessive reverence.
From start to finish, Captain America: Civil War reminds us that there is a capable soldier and a remarkable human behind the mask and shield.
Audiences with memories of the 1980s will surely find themselves humming right along with all the right sentiments.
The Man Who Knew Infinity is persuasive and quite surprising.
The Meddler never tips over into broadly thoughtless hijinks.
In The Lobster, the bottom-line examination of love gets dressed up and framed in curious ways.
In the end, Alice Through the Looking Glass never descends into the black pit of the truly horrific; instead, it simply fades from memory.
There is a delicious thrill in watching a completely dialed-in performer tackle a truly larger-than-life character...Ralph Fiennes is a spellbinding treat.
The Conjuring 2 is a deliciously slow-building affair that comes on strong at the end because Wan makes sure we are as invested as humanly possible in his characters.
Wampler's Ascent dares to show us a life well-lived in the hope that it might take us higher. Climb aboard.
How can you pack in so many curiously questionable pop culture figures into a franchise based on nothing more than beloved (?) 1980's nostalgia?
What we get, in the end, is more of the same.
[Finding Dory] injects heartfelt emotion and a thoughtful examination of the necessary links between family and identity into a film geared toward a younger audience.
Woody Allen staves off the looming naysayers with a film that will likely appeal to a literate niche, all but forgotten in this day that is sadly a long way removed from the Jazz Age.
Where the film succeeds is with its talented cast.
Equals strictly adheres to a mood of oppressive sterility that threatens to squeeze the life out of the film.
Dheepan is a stirring and unflinching rendition of a legend near and dear to our American hearts.
Director Todd Solondz continues to force audiences to stare into stark and unflinching scenes of never-ending personal humiliations. That's his auteurist signature.
Indignation resolutely remains a solitary character study, and it challenges viewers to look inward for a glimpse of their own quiet redemption.
Don't Think Twice has comedy as its subject, but it is a far more dramatic and perplexing affair than a comic one.

Southside With You doesn't need to preach, shout or wave its racial bona fides like a battle-worn banner. Instead, it embraces us, conspiratorially acknowledging a shared understanding that change requires fighting for hope and love in every moment.
O brother Cianfrance, where art thou? Maybe next time.
With the right mix of action-thriller skewering and social/cultural digs, Key and Peele just might rescue the genre spoof from itself.
The Fits is a unique spin.
This doesn't come across like the kind of movie anyone would want to take their mothers to as a sign of appreciation for giving birth to them. Enough already, Mr. Marshall.

Everybody Wants Some offers a return to the Dazed and Confused mode of storytelling, lighter and meandering fare that finds real intimacy in the unfettered high times of life before adulthood sets in.
Menashe is the most human and humane of dramas.
[The Witch] convincingly makes us believe that such supernatural elements could be real, and that we are watching an account that feels terrifyingly of-the-moment.
There's a truly loveable sense of relating to Eddie Edwards.
Hollywood seems to be holding its breath to see if Butler might prove to be a worthy successor to Liam Neeson or if he'll fall to the wayside and become a Texas Ranger down the road.
Zootopia appears posed to rule the roost with all members of the family as we sprint free of the Oscars.
[Hello, My Name is Doris] helps us to appreciate the kind of beauty that doesn't fade away.
Rauch's Greggory is a brash, foul-mouthed creation who bends the will of the proceedings away from outright satire of celebrity to something surprisingly more engaging.
My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2 could have been so much more than a reunion. It could have offered us the chance to celebrate the progression of family and culture in the face of a brave new world.
By journey's conclusion, we bear the mark, too.
It is an intimate high-wire act, completely open to interpretation, but with Weisz and Shannon as our guides, Complete Unknown doesn't leave us stranded alone.
The film works best as an anxiety-inducing intellectual and ethical thriller that draws viewers into real-world debates being waged.
Krisha certainly is a difficult film to like or recommend in the traditional sense, but what writer-director Trey Edward Shults has birthed here is something that demands to be seen.
Demolition is the perfect vehicle for Gyllenhaal. You get the sense that not a single choice he has ever made as an actor has been rooted in concerns for vanity or financial gain.
Leading a pack that includes Kristen Bell, Peter Dinklage, Dave Bautista and Kathy Bates, McCarthy seems ready to prove she's The Boss of bosses.
Bravo to Cheadle for breathing life into this fantastic imitation of the Miles Davis of his dreams.
Screenwriter and director Pamela Romanowsky adapts Elliott's memoir, allowing the loose strands of narrative to unravel even further, approximating the downward spiral of Elliott's blocked psyche.
There is a lot to enjoy in Criminal; enough, in fact, for it to remind us that such guilty pleasures shouldn't be thought of as crimes against humanity.
From a cinematic standpoint, especially from an independent framework, what could be better than having Shannon and Spacey go toe-to-toe as these iconic figures?
Robert Budreau's Born to be Blue dares to blur the lines between fact and fiction.
Disney should celebrate the day they first teamed up with Jon Favreau as a national holiday.
I Saw the Light foregoes spending any real time with the music and the musicians, instead turning its gaze on the pedestrian details of the marital drama between the great man and his wife Audrey.
What happens in Green Room ain't right, but you'll find that you are in bloody good hands.
I wish this Nation had been borne rooted in the complex truth that even heroes experience dark nights of the soul.
A certain measure of humor informs A Man Called Ove, but it is not hokey or nostalgic. Instead, this film cherishes a knowing wisdom that leaves us with a wistful smile.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It might look and feel like a "TV movie," but Fanning wills 3 Generations toward something richer and more nuanced - something that matters.
It is hard to believe, but Gere truly disappears inside the small shell of this man who is forever fighting to be seen.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Citizen Jane: Battle for the City is an unlikely redefinition of the story of David versus Goliath.
movie_title: Citizen Jane: Battle for the City (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Lovers dives headlong into tricky waters, showing us that passion can make strong and fearless swimmers of us all.
Davies and Nixon work in perfect tandem in A Quiet Passion, penning a letter from the past that refuses to draw parallels to our current situation.
The new Wonder Woman from director Patty Jenkins has an effective story, borrowing fictional archetypes while offering something original.
Paris Can Wait is a decidedly intimate piece of storytelling that contrasts quite nicely from the bolder and more dramatic features from the other members of the Coppola clan.
After the credits roll at the end and the lights come up, you will be overcome by the feverish need to head to the nearest dance floor with a kicking and swinging band.
More than any other actor I can think of, Sam Elliott is the epitome of a hero.
Baby Driver feels like Wright is elevating his own game, while tipping his hat to a host of his fellow big-league players.
Homecoming is a friendly reminder that even the most spectacular heroes have a lot of growing up to do.
The Big Sick signals the arrival of a new prince in the comic kingdom.

Dunkirk is a stunning cinematic achievement, skillfully and exactingly deploying music and sound to heighten drama, capitalizing on every inch of the large screen to document the looming horror and growing desperation.
In A Ghost Story, Lowery pulls off the neatest trick of all with this haunting image. He teases us with the idea that humanity survives into the afterlife.
Hawkins, once again, creates an impenetrable aura of resolute happiness.
With An Inconvenient Sequel, it's apparent Gore is tirelessly trying to build a sustainable movement. He's pushing beyond the initial steps of dialogue and engagement.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The girls of the step team don't shy away from tackling the issue in their performances. They create routines that defiantly address the Black Lives Matter movement. They embrace roles for themselves as advocates.
On the surface, Brigsby Bear will seem somewhat removed from the reality we might imagine from such serious subject matter. But that distance gives the narrative and its characters life.

Plaza's not merely bored and making a joke of the outbursts; she's angry and raw and raunchy. There's a darkness to her stare that's a challenge. She's got a bit of the old school femme fatale in her, but she's arrived at the wrong time.
It is not just a Good Time for Pattinson, but a perfect moment for genre and movie stars (and directors like the Safdies) to explore new possibilities.
Michael Moore unabashedly embraces a rather old warrior trope as the means of cobbling together elements from around the world that he believes would actually make our nation more than better.
What makes Vol. 2 truly awesome is Gunn's willingness to indulge in the whimsy and wonder of the dazzling color of comic book frames.
Queen of Katwe is a tough triumph of will that doesn't limit itself by focusing so narrowly on the game alone.

Terry George would have been wise to focus his attention on Bale's journalist, allowing his dogged account of the sad history of Armenia to raise our ire and serve as a rallying cry for exposing this long-hidden international injustice.

Gifted, under more traditional studio care, could have easily remained a sentimental tearjerker. But I would beg audiences to follow director Webb and screenwriter Flynn beneath the surface trappings.
In less than two hours, DuVernay makes an astonishing case for the 13th Amendment as a foundation for the currently fractured political landscape.
This film is harrowing, to be sure, but expertly drawn in the service of a great and remarkable true story.
In Moonlight, Barry Jenkins charts an intimate portrait of the plight of young African-American men and nods to the influence of spirituals in the African-American tradition of the Blues.
The Love Witch counters the darkness of its black magic with an abundance of nostalgic camp and a high level of naked titillation.
Nichols, in Loving, illustrates how family starts with a choice that's rooted in love - and we can't legislate love. But we must defend the right to love in the first place.
Waking up to the struggles of others, especially those closest to us, can prove to be challenging, and it is this process - and the movement forward - that drives the film.
The portrayal of someone struggling with post-traumatic stress disorder brings the personal toll of war into sharp focus.

For all the acting excellence on display in Nocturnal Animals, what mattered more was cracking the narrative Rubik's Cube invented by Wright and elevated by Ford's precise integration of style and substance.
Affleck lives in every frame, carrying Manchester By the Sea along with him, toward a transcendent state of being that reminds us of our own moments of love irretrievably lost.
La La Land engaged my senses in the moment, and will certainly do so any time I watch it, but it will not linger like a haunting refrain. Sadly, it didn't go to my head.
As her superb Things to Come opens at the Esquire Theatre on Friday, let the record show that Isabelle Huppert is ready for her moment in the spotlight.
[Sleepless] fashions a familiar action vehicle for an Academy Award-winning star (Jamie Foxx) looking to stroll through a paycheck role.
The great American modernist poet William Carlos Williams hovers over the new Jim Jarmusch film Paterson like a gentle guardian angel, somehow clearly visible.
Mike Mills' whip-smart film revolves around a single mother and her adolescent son amid a time brimming with cultural change and rebellion.
With a subtle and deft touch, Julieta illustrates how the senses can define character and memory.

I Am Not Your Negro curiously subverts our conception of history, perceptions of ourselves as a nation and attempts to address our unending dilemma. It tells its story best through Baldwin's own words rather than moving images.
The film draws from disparate sources, weaving and recontextualizing these inspirations into a groovy anthem for a powerful generation no longer waiting patiently to be heard.
The Salesman is outstanding.
Woody Harrelson surrenders fully to whatever traits have been defined on the page, never simply reading the scripted lines.

Prepare to marvel at the large scale of individual talent and total commitment to group execution, because the film seamlessly weaves micro and macro strands together to stitch a moving visual tapestry.
How do you live with yourself once you've crossed a point of no return? Raw displays a haunting hesitancy in its reply
I'm not even sure it makes complete sense while you're watching it unfold, but there is delirious and primal freedom in the act of killing.
Be prepared to see this flick more than once; there is next to no down time in the whole affair since the quips fly at lightning pace.
Ade, Simonischek and Hüller have crafted a loving ode to familial relationships that achieves universality in its own right. We don't need another Toni Erdmann in the thunderdome of a multiplex.

Director Wilson Yip, who helmed the first two installments in this series, employs an understated approach to the fight sequences that achieves a welcome degree of realism, which sadly is lacking in the dramatic moments.
But "Colossal" succeeds because [Anne] Hathaway provides a solid and engaging emotional anchor.
It is a simple tale of war and love, with teasing strands of feminism and sexual orientation woven into the mix, writ in small human terms.
"The Dinner" sets up a long and winding road that, at times, twists unnecessarily back on itself, seeking to create complexity while forcing us to question our own moral compasses.

Downsizing becomes yet another story about a white male protagonist who gets redeemed through his interactions with a person of color who guides him along the way, opening his eyes to the real world. Oh, please.
I love how del Toro trusts his audience, which means he's willing and daringly able to offer us a dizzying marriage of the sensual and also possible salvation.
Franco leaves flattery behind and finds the authenticity of this man, pointing the way to a real shot at critical redemption for Wiseau and The Room.
Stevens, in The Man Who Invented Christmas, is cementing another monumental stepping stone in his path, bridging the divide between characters and audiences. Talk about a gift that keeps on giving.
Being able to avert disasters along the way in the service of capturing the nuances of interpersonal relationships is their artistic calling.
It goes without saying that Washington, once again, proves to be the undisputed winner of this morality play.

Rather than spend undue attention on these elements, Pellington works his magic by tapping into the talents of his leads. Both MacLaine and Seyfried use their eyes and the act of watching to reveal who these women truly are.
The film presents justice as a moving target and dares us to actively pursue it en route to a greater good.
Lady Bird, in a year without a clear front-runner, could take flight and usher in the kind of impactful changes in the film industry we've been dreaming of and whispering about for the last decade.
Loving Vincent" is an emotional and spiritual mystery of sorts, an existential examination into a life and the art that sprang from a truly tragic figure.
"Thor: Ragnarok" reimagines Thor as a devilishly dim hero in love with the idea of his own power until a crisis forces him to confront the notion that he's not as strong as he always figured.
There is a gentleness that permeates the film, which keeps Wonderstruck from sliding into sentimentality; all of the young actors handle the responsibility of grounding the narrative admirably.
There is something real and pressing in this vision that requires us to remain attuned to the plights of people like Moonee and Halley.
What emerges, from a contemporary perspective, is a critical debate involving the use of children to sell books and products.
[Jigsaw] seems like a necessary reaction to the everyday madness of our newsfeeds.
Teller finds the strength of his characters by slowing things down and staring straight into the dangerous void.
George Clooney stirs up a hornet's nest of racial animus for no good reason.

What this film says about race cannot be confined to one character or perspective. It seems to adhere to a novelistic approach, speaking through a collection of voices gleaned from two families' viewpoints in a larger diagram.

Whenever choices become binary-black or white, kill or be killed-that's the sign of the apocalypse, and "The Belko Experiment" captures just one instance in what probably feels like a worldwide tournament of murderous madness.
Focusing on the seemingly unknowable perspectives of the cats, [Ceyda Torun] makes a case for the innate goodness of the human spirit.

There's much to ponder in the premise, but films rise and fall on the rapport we have with either the characters or the performers, and with "Before I Fall," try as I might, I never fell under the sway of Samantha or Deutch.

Nemes isn't able to place us directly in Saul's shoes, but we can more than imagine living in his skin, feeling the pain - literal and metaphoric - and seeing, up close and personal, the shape he's in.

Potter lets her talented cast cut loose in this chamber affair where wine and whining (in equal measure) spotlights every single microscopic fissure in the delicate façade these characters believe they have constructed.

The Artist makes a strong argument for film as an escape from the modern escapist fantasies. It doesn't mean anything - that's what some critics are crying now - but since when did we decide that movies always have to have meaning?
Affleck...takes on what amounts to a historic period thriller with humorous elements and a hero in Mendez, and he does so like he's the second coming of Robert Redford and George Clooney.
Annihilation titillates the eyes of adrenaline junkies while also appealing to the flawed hearts of lovers.

This version of Black Panther weaves a seemingly disparate set of strands together rather seamlessly, presenting more than enough comic book acrobatics and mayhem to satisfy the core fan base while also speaking a necessary degree of truth to power.
Just know your rules and their limits and stick to them. That's better than any half-hearted compromise or tepid sex play. Now that's what it means to be "Freed."

McQueen's 12 Years a Slave, a rich and distinctly faithful adaptation of Northup's experiences, begs us to continue this conversation by offering an artful and critical reflection on our past, present and future as a nation.
What truly results, in a meaningful way, is an understanding that neither side can claim to be morally absolute. There is no right or wrong, no sense of things being purely black or white.
I suppose Gudegast seeks to give credence to the notion that there's no honor among thieves, but if that's truly the case and point he wants to make, he could have done so with a bit more efficiency.
Despite it all, Streep and Hanks soldier on, as only they can, and they do convince us that this fight matters. But The Post feels like old news.

You purchase the ticket for the sensual slow-burn love story that develops between Elio and Oliver, captured against the gorgeous backdrop of Northern Italy, but you might find yourself moved to tears by the genuine appeal Stuhlbarg makes to his son.
Gillespie and Rogers have crafted a funhouse mirror of America - the film works as contemporary allegory.

The Last Key is not actively seeking to venture into political territory. The movie simply functions this way due to the accident of its release during this particular moment, but this reading affords the film a strong second life for curious audiences.
You've got Chastain, Elba, and Sorkin betting on themselves and each other. A big win is always a game changer.

As long as the focus is on Weisz, "My Cousin Rachel" is real and satisfying curiosity on today's film landscape, a performance-fueled work anchored by a strong female lead who knows and remains true to herself.
"Everything, Everything" doesn't even set up a bar for Maddy and Olly to overcome, instead insisting on the idea that we should just make believe like mindless children.
But "Gold" proves that you need more than a thinning hairline and a bulging waistline.
Nick Offerman and John Carroll Lynch as Dick and Mac McDonald never stood a chance, and it could be argued that, despite Keaton's cunning performance, neither did the movie.
"Jackie" shows us how Kennedy gave birth to the legend of the modern-day Camelot, but it also captures the ongoing evolution of a star, right before our eyes.
Rather than merely retreading the well-worn and bloody path of the first film, "Chapter 2" opens with a mythos, showcasing an international realm of intrigue.
Landesman doesn't give audiences enough detail to piece together how Felt could have brought down even a White House so crippled by its own ego-driven ineptitude.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The newcomers on hand, including the Rap-singing lover-boy Andre and Rome, the new sultry mistress of ceremonies with complicated romantic ties to Magic Mike, go a long way toward making us forget that we ever bought into Dallas' club.
This Best Picture nominee is a beautifully filmed coming-of-age and coming-out story.
Mistress America is definitely larger than life.

With Big Stone Gap, Trigiani sets out to crack the cycle of sentimental melodrama by reminding us that adults still dare to dream and sometimes even follow through on achieving those hard-to-articulate wishes.
Why focus on looking down, when this should be about the uplifting sense of crossing the heavens?

I would simply be remiss if I failed to point out the lowered stakes. The closest the film comes to acknowledging that anyone's life might truly be on the line is in the blankly understated face of Rylance's Abel.
[Beasts] is a mesmerizingly grim adaptation of Uzodinma Iweala's novel.
Truth belongs to Cate Blanchett.
The final presentation is quite clean and well composed, but lacking in passion to stimulate our narrative palates.
As much as I disliked Miss You Already, I have to admit that I was rather taken with Barrymore's performance as Jess.
We tell ourselves the world is a big place, but director Lenny Abrahamson, adapting Emma Donoghue's novel Room, shows us just how infinite the space can truly be.
In the case of Francis Lawrence's one-two punch with Mockingjay (the concluding text of The Hunger Games series), Part 2 seeks to perfectly execute the game plan.
This Night isn't very silent, thanks to a cache of drugs, a gaggle of celebrity cameos and infighting among the fellas, but the good-natured buzz is definitely mellow.
There is no "I" in team, but we need to start spotlighting the reality that, more often than not, it requires coordinated effort to achieve massive aims. Now that's the whole truth and nothing but.

Creed certainly looks like a reboot-spinoff, but without the crass cash-grab feeling we've come to expect from such fare. Don't call it a franchise comeback, because Creed is something else altogether.

Trumbo took full advantage of his wit and the power of language to not only garner fame and glory, but to also highlight the absurdity, injustice and utter un-American behavior of those behind the blacklisting.
Abrams seems far more intent on delivering on the promise of the originals as rousing space Westerns where good and evil stood opposite one another and dared the other side to blink.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: [Brooklyn] dares to dream an old dream, and we are reminded of the powerful allure of home.
Sisters looks like the kind of family affair that Judd Apatow and Seth Rogen have dominated the box office with, but these Sisters are doing it for themselves.
Youth, with an innocent and wandering eye, minimizes the glamor and privilege, spotlighting a common humanity that tends to succumb to invisibility.
Sumar's film issued a challenge to me, demanding me to get off my high horse, to recognize my own cowardice in the reflection of these two male characters.
The devil in the details is sadly missing from Mojave.
The film version of Z for Zachariah feels like a psychological reworking of Genesis, infused with vitality thanks to a pitch-perfect cast that makes the heart beat faster.
Director Andrew Haigh adapts this David Constantine short story with a fine sense of time, memory, affection and the dawning of regret that simmers without completely boiling over.
Pan never quite feels like this is what creator J.M. Barrie had in mind for his epic character.
What's in a name? As He Named Me Malala posits, maybe nothing, until the rose chooses to embody what it means to be a rose.

The rich perversity in the slow-building tension explodes, as these things do in Tarantino narratives, fracturing and fragmenting chronology and body parts with equal aplomb and delirious pitch-black humor.
The Martian never loses sight of the fact that it is about a supreme test of will and intelligence and human triumph.

Sudeikis and Brie also bring an astonishing amount of charm, sensuality and real emotion to the proceedings, elevating the film far beyond its rom-com premise. This might go down as the year of the dramatic sex comedy.
Vikander, last seen in Ex Machina, perfectly embodies all of these complex traits without allowing the performance to disintegrate into mere histrionics.
Every detail, both big (Michael Douglas) and small (Peña), works to alter our perceptions of we mean when we talk about this genre and those crazy expectations.
It is the fact that Infinitely Polar Bear provides an opportunity for audiences to engage in these considerations, effortlessly, that the film will win over hearts and minds.
Pixels is a simple story about video game nerds who get a chance to save the day.
Schumer shows a willingness to fearlessly venture beyond the comfort of easy laughs into real emotional territory.
Irrational Man, upon closer inspection, feels like a minor reinvention.

Kids will certainly love the hijinks, but parents, especially members of Generation X, might want to join in for a movie that subtly and shrewdly revisits the John Hughes classic Ferris Bueller's Day Off.
Too bad that U.N.C.L.E. can't even muster enough thrills for a final life-jolting pop. Instead, Ritchie and the movie strike a pose and leave us waiting and wanting.

No Escape plays into the worst fears of Americans abroad, where danger lurks around every corner for U.S. nationals, and compounds this jingoistic sense by fostering the notion that no other lives matter more than those of this one American family.
We've seen it all before and, to be honest, the Vacation package had already lost its ability to elicit even faint smiles and chuckles toward the end of its run.

By picking up the narrative baton that original Blade Runner director Scott carried for so long, Villeneuve immerses us in the hopeful reawakening to a future that beckons us to rush forward without fear.
Woodshock takes viewers on a dreamy trip.
The Mountain Between Us proves that fairy tales, no matter how silly can come true and make us believe in them.
While there is a loose story/plot line to the narrative, Boden and Fleck have crafted the perfect interlude to encapsulate a never-ending story with little hope or light.

Battle of the Sexes is not deep enough to speak truth to the enduring powerful impact this match had then and continues to have, now that sports again is a battleground in our never-ending cultural wars.

In all honesty, during my TIFF screening of Brad's Status, the new dramedy from actor, writer and director Mike White, I found myself barely able to contain the rage I felt for Brad Sloan, an insufferable mess of white male entitlement and privilege.
The true strength on display throughout the film stems from Gyllenhaal who has always had an edgy, almost twitchy kind of presence.
The horrors of Aronofsky's world have little to do with the traditional scares and found footage trends that have come to dominate the nightmares of the 21st century.
[Emily Blunt] is the perfect audience stand-in in Sicario, the latest journey into the heart of darkness masterminded by Canadian director Denis Villeneuve.
The Hitman's Bodyguard proves that summer fun comes best with two great tastes that taste great together.
The true revolutionary stroke of genius here is the decision by screenwriters Jacob and Michael Koskoff to set their story during something other than Brown v. Board of Education.

Like previous expository Marvel films much of Doctor Strange is devoted to Cumberbatch acquainting himself with his new powers. But the film's visual mindbending is what sets it apart from the studio's past releases.
Rogue One works best because its story is so narrowly focused.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Condon's Beauty and the Beast is visually as sumptuous as Branagh's Cinderella, paying close attention to ornate castle decorations and beautiful costumes.
Dunkirk's plot is fairly uncomplicated. The thrill is in the deeply exhilarating pace at which the action unfolds.
Not even Zac Efron's abs can distract us from the fact that we are treading in shallow, shallow waters.
This is the Spidey movie we've been waiting for. It's also the best Spider-Man movie of the bunch.
Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 amps up what you loved about the first film, but a frustratingly unfocused plot keeps it from surpassing its predecessor.
By the time Fergie is dismembered by zombies, you know you're in good hands. She tastes Fergalicious, I'm guessing.
Firehouse Dog isn't quite the equivalent of the 1999 talking-infant bomb Baby Geniuses, but at times it's close enough for discomfort.
... as muddy as Yasgur's farm back in the day.
It's inconsequential, potty-mouthed, extremely silly, and -- the worst sin of all -- dead boring.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's an angry story, but also a strangely hopeful one, in the sense of new life sprouting through a battlefield. Above all, it's personal and specific, and that is news we can use.
movie_title: The Prisoner Or: How I Planned to Kill Tony Blair (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Live Free is a comedy of vastly diminished criminal expectations. That's the fun of it, and the frustration, too.
True to the emotional reality of its young characters and young audience and flattering the latter into thinking way outside the box. There are worse things to teach than intellectual ambition.
A modestly effective thriller about a lost boy who falls in with a nasty pack of bank robbers, The Lookout promises minor pleasures and delivers them.
Makes a persuasive case that while companies put buildings up, it's the public that owns them.
The movie never convinces us there's anyone there to expose, though, and Malkovich flits from scene to scene without ever anchoring Conway in a lasting reality.
A stylish but essentially businesslike smash-and-crasher.
A laughably overheated thriller from the once promising James Foley.
Reign Over Me quietly says that we're our problem friends' keepers. At its worst, the movie is a problem friend.
The Namesake has a deep, alluvial poetry to it, like a mighty river reaching the sea. It's mysterious and ordinary, insightful and banal, rambling and precise, and it is altogether unexpected.
Almost as funny as it is hyperactive, the new computer-animated family comedy is luscious to look at and as fizzy as a can of soda popped open in your face.
All that keeps the movie from collapsing into soap opera is the exuberant drive of the filmmaking. And the central performance. Van Houten is pretty without being beautiful.
If, when this gang lights into Our Love Is Here to Stay, you feel you've entered a very special chamber in Hell, rest assured you're not alone.
movie_title: Sing Now or Forever Hold Your Peace (2006)

movie_review_blurb: There's no agenda in Vacancy other than to keep you in a state of nervous collapse for 85 minutes, but [director] Antal fulfills it honorably for the most part.
If you ride for pleasure or for sport -- or just to get from one place to another -- Scotsman is worth seeing.
Have I got a movie for you. Into Great Silence is a two-hour-and-40-minute documentary about monks, and it is one of the transporting film experiences of this or any other year.
Dig deep down into some bad movies and you occasionally find a good idea at the center. Civic Duty isn't one of those movies.
A fully felt, decently crafted teen B-movie melodrama, plenty preposterous in places but alive to the vibrant miseries of being young and misunderstood.
Sweet, but you've seen it many times before. Until then it's a tragicomedy of entropy, a film that wonders what happens to men when they can't do the only thing they know how to.
One problem: The movie's just not funny.
Filmmaker Lynn Hershman Leeson spins an essay on art, government, play-acting, and paranoia; it's easily her best film yet.
It's to the Lethal Weapon movies what left-hand driving on a country lane is to a freeway chase: pokey, more than a little daft, but with a bloody surprise around every hedge.
A delightful two-and-a-half-hour repast for mindful film junkies.
Written and directed by Reginald Harkema with a sharp eye toward the paradoxes of fighting The Man in the 21st century.
A straightforward but engrossing drama about what love is worth when memory is gone.
Very rough, very funny, with sensibilities derived equally from Chaplin, Jim Jarmusch, and the Gang of Four.

Structured very loosely along chronological lines, Punk's Not Dead takes core samples from musical forefathers, mid-period bands, and snotty young kids, building a jangly, contradictory mosaic as it goes.
Filmed with visual beauty and conceptual taste -- too much so, say the film's detractors -- it's an eerie glimpse into a secret world.
Life's a mess, it says, but you can't sweep up the dirt until you've taken a good, hard look at it.
A tart, smart, closely observed satire of the television industry.
Lake wants to break through decades of encrusted rhetoric to make us think again. With one slow reveal of Norma McCorvey, a.k.a. 'Jane Roe,' the movie upends all you assumed about this subject.
The smart, classy Hurricane on the Bayou preaches an invaluable environmental lesson for children and parents: Don't monkey with the ecosystem without expecting payback.
A documentary to make you proud of what America offers to the rest of the world and worried that it can't keep its promises.

The dialogue has wit, and the rug gets pulled out from under us and the characters in several short, sharp jolts. At a certain point, Behind the Mask loses the tatty digital-video and immerses us in cinema.
movie_title: Behind the Mask: The Rise of Leslie Vernon (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Halfway through we're introduced to nine industrialists and politicians -- they narrate their heinous biographies in Godardian voiceover -- who embark up the title mountain to become immortal. Dude.
This is gutbucket Luis Buñuel , surrealism on the cheap, and it hasn't dated well -- the blood is patently fake and the gunshots are dubbed.
The Italian offers a soul-blasted portrait of modern Russia ...
The film's a pleasant enough daydream before it turns all squoodgy at the end.

No one's going to argue that the 1986 psycho-thriller The Hitcher was a pillar of world cinema, but it had a scuzzy originality. The remake, by default, lacks even that. I don't think I've seen a movie with less reason to exist.
In the end, broader messages get beaten down by genre.

The Aura is richer and less showy than Nine Queens, and it lifts off from the gangster genre to contemplate deeper mysteries. Reminiscent of Antonioni's The Passenger in its obsession with fate and choice.

The last half hour of Jonestown is almost unwatchable. Video footage of the assault on the congressman's delegation gives way to audio of Jones exhorting people to 'die with a degree of dignity' as children shriek in the background.
Eloquent, bloody, and daringly simple, the movie examines notions of wartime glory as closely as Flags of Our Fathers dissected heroism.
If The Beatles were teen girls starring in a John Hughes picture made with a distinctly Japanese attention to the comedy of everyday life, the movie showcasing it all would go something like this.

Not surprisingly, the three Wong sisters and their father could exist in separate movies -- their (short) stories are interesting but not convincingly knit together. Think of Red Doors as a promise, and hope that [director] Georgia Lee keeps it.

The movie bing-bing-bings all over the place, repurposing fantasy novels, video games, Arthurian legends. Besson's grocery bill for all I know. Even the musical score has multiple-personality disorder.
movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The director stays true to the source novel even when it lifts into a magical realism that works only on the page, and his faithfulness betrays him. Perfume is a thriller that Hobbes might have envied.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Mostly, though, Miss Potter turns the solemn comedy of her books and illustrations into mere whimsy, animating Jemima Puddle-duck into cartoon life whenever Beatrix talks to her.

Tart and weightless, and it entertains without leaving a mark. Not that there's anything wrong with that, but at 85 minutes, The Valet at times feels like a blueprint for a farce rather than the farce itself.
The grown-ups fare worse: They speak . . . very . . . slowly . . . as if to pad the running time out. This may in fact be the most ridiculous performance John Corbett has ever given.
The film squeezes out its feel-good messages like toothpaste from a tube.
Factory Girl is not, strictly speaking, a bad movie. It's something worse: an irredeemably banal drama about some of the most protean, contradictory creative forces of the 1960s.
Part detective story, part coming of political age saga, and all teenage identity crisis.
The movie's enjoyable but almost wholly canned, coasting on the pleasure of its post-punk soundtrack and the novelty of the quiz-show scenes.
A fumbled attempt at modern romantic comedy.
The admirable feminist agenda occasionally trips up the narrative, but the film's performances keep it on track.
It's Godzilla with a severe case of Murphy's Law, and it is never less than bizarrely delightful.
Aside from pretty people behaving cutely, though, there's just not much here, and even devoted Francophiles may nod into their cafe crèmes.
The film's a bumptious weekend ride: The engine could use tuning and the plugs are shot, but it gets you most of the way there.
You may not like the terms Tarantino sets, but you have to admit he succeeds on them.
Has heat but little light; it speaks of pleasure while treating it as a dirty word. The cast huffs and puffs but the exercise, sadly, remains academic.
A love story of sorts, it's not a feel-good movie so much as feel-orgasmic-and-then-mildly-crestfallen movie. Like sex, like a good meal, like life.

A movie of slowly accumulating tension and power, Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck's drama -- a foreign language Oscar nominee, with a good shot at winning -- is also a romance between two men, but not the way you think.
Very Sad Things prompt Very Big Questions, and this movie is smart enough to avoid Very Easy Answers.
There's precious little espionage where we can see it, and that's what makes the movie such a compelling and eerily effective little drama.
Ghost Rider is the kind of movie that's great stupid fun as long as someone else is buying the tickets.
In the end, the movie's just the kind of enjoyably empty-headed fluff it celebrates and mocks.
What An Unreasonable Man does best is rehabilitate Nader's career prior to the election and remind us of an unparalleled public-interest legacy stretching over four decades.
If Woody Allen were a young, attractive gay woman, he might make something like this, or so Maggenti hopes. But it would probably be funnier, and it would definitely cut deeper.
It's a doughty movie, stuck halfway between Masterpiece Theatre and Classics Illustrated.
Dreaming Lhasa goes a long way on the strength of its exotic visuals and gently urgent narrative, but in the end it doesn't go quite far enough.
If you ever wanted a movie to put in the time capsule so future generations can puzzle over the bankruptcy of our current kiddie culture, Bratz is it.
Waitress isn't a great film, but it is great, deep-dish fun, with a generosity of spirit that extends first to the sisters on the screen and in the audience, then to the rest of humanity.
Skinwalkers is never able to escape its fundamental preposterousness. You've seen worse, but, trust me, you've seen better.
It observes the specific until the specific turns universal, and the universal until you find yourself moved beyond words.
There's a gutter pride taken in how aggressively Shaun confronts the world, but there's also a blunt, no-nonsense analysis of where the kid goes wrong.
If the movie is relentless low-brow swill, its splattery good cheer makes it hard to hate. Just go in expecting the expected, and maybe bring a tarp.
Where's the ambition? Where's the passion?
The film aims for sassy but lands in soggy, the victim of lazy scripting and pacing.

This is powerful stuff, so why does the movie feel less convincing the longer it goes on? There are two ways to tell this story -- coolly distanced or melodramatically hot -- but [director] Kim combines both approaches, and the mixture doesn't congeal.
The babies are adorable, the soundtrack choices ('We Are Family') obvious, the biological diversity awe-inspiring.
Deeply pleasing in a connect-the-literary-dots manner.
An intensely unpleasant killer-thriller mystery that has nevertheless been directed with low-budget craft by Chris Sivertson.
It's a dark little ride, but at the end the lights hesitantly flicker back on.
movie_title: 12:08 East of Bucharest (A fost sau n-a fost?) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: No Reservations, starring Catherine Zeta-Jones as a persnickety New York chef, makes a corned beef hash out of Mostly Martha, the much-loved 2001 German film from which it has been Hollywoodized.
Ultimately, pointless. One comes away from Interview exhausted.
An overstuffed turkey that's entertaining for all the wrong reasons. It may in fact be the comedy of the summer, a melodramatic folly whose ambitions consistently curdle into camp.

Against all expectations, Hairspray turns out to be an explosion of industrial-strength good cheer, delivered by very smart show-biz pros with wit, passion, and a soupçon of dementia. Resistance is futile.
In the way that certain baseball games become pitchers' duels, some movies are cutting-room battles.
It's a Saw rip-off with less smarts. (Take a moment, please, to allow that sentence to sink in.)
Death builds slowly and inexorably to a comic explosion that's just too good -- too insanely, impossibly mortifying -- to spoil here.
Honest and surprisingly lucid at its core.
Chalk might have been both funnier and more penetrating as a real documentary.
Contrary to what you may have heard, love isn't all you need.
In Eastern Promises, David Cronenberg's hellacious new Russian mob movie, Viggo Mortensen finally comes of age as an actor and a movie star.
Buy the CD and skip the movie.
Hannah is charmingly self-absorbed without the extenuating circumstance of self-knowledge. Above all, she's young. The movie forgives her for that and, with occasional misgivings, so do we.
It's a cocktail made up of three parts testosterone to one part brains.
Lean, almost absurdly satisfying.
The Kurds may not yet have a country, but as long as Bahman Ghobadi keeps making movies they have a national cinema.
Someday, far in the future, a team of archeologists will dig up the black, wizened, still beating heart of New York City, and it will look exactly like Steve Buscemi.
The film's violence erupts in rare, staccato bursts, all the more horrifying for coming out of nowhere.
The film's violence erupts in rare, staccato bursts, all the more horrifying for coming out of nowhere.
movie_title: Triad Election (Hak se wui yi wo wai kwai) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Maybe this is how the world ends in LA -- not with a bang but a 96-minute whimper.
A solid meat-and-potatoes B-movie with enough personality to spin it in unexpected directions.
It's waxy Classics Illustrated cinema.
Somewhere, Jacques Tati is smiling.
Too often the movies view the problems of Africa through Western eyes, but Devil turns that weakness to a literal strength, because Steidle could do nothing in his position except take photographs.
Sensual in escalating degrees of heat, but the film's eroticism, which is substantial, is laid on with a caress.

Those coming to Rescue Dawn cold will probably accept it as a straightforward, even predictable account of POW suffering, and they'll hang on Bale's muscular portrayal of a man who refuses to say die.
Smart, conflicted, and immensely entertaining.
You stagger out of this one both grateful and ready for a deep and dreamless nap.
Who knew the man had a workplace comedy in him, let alone one this sharp?
movie_title: The Boss of it All (Direktøren for det hele) (2007)
