movie_review_blurb: A fertile example of the Studio Film Gone Berserk, where too many characters and too many story lines geometrically progress until a level of blissful absurdity is reached.

Does Gracie work as a movie? Just close enough, and closer still for a young soccer player who may already know her sports movie clichés but also recognizes when they touch on something once and truly felt.
The MessengersI/i> is textbook, and the course it's teaching is HSL: Horror as a Second Language.
Few filmmakers portray emotional detachment so achingly well.
Hollywood Dreams is meant to be an insider's tale, but it feels like it comes from the cinema of hangers-on.
In its brief running time, writer-director John Carney does something both profound and unexpected: He reinvents the movie musical as a genre of swooning rock 'n' roll realism.

If the previous installment, Dead Man's Chest, was a classic No. 2, antic and insultingly unresolved, World's End tips the ship too far in the opposite direction. The first two hours of this 168-minute leviathan are bafflingly action-free.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Provoked rarely ducks below its glossy surface.
The resolution Jindabyne eventually offers feels small and safe. The movie goes out with a whimper.
Too many clichés and not enough energy have come along for the ride.

Fay Grim falls victim to its own worried hyperactivity; it shuts you out with chattery paranoia. Hartley wants us to see the big picture, but he forgets we need artists like him to bring it into focus.
It's dopey Army comedy in the tradition of Buck Privates and Stripes, just with the sights aimed lower and blissfully unaware of its own monumental tastelessness.
[Director Arnold] drops the voyeurism theme almost entirely, a bait-and-switch that doesn't cripple Red Road so much as snip off its richest and eeriest thread.
Overly forced, a shade too whimsical, but filling a void other words and other movies haven't the nerve or errant taste to confront.
I admired it and felt a little ground down at the same time.
Crazy Love scrapes away the cartoon exterior around this story and peers into the unknowable murk of the human heart.
Steel City may be the only movie released this year that's so observant you can hear what the characters aren't saying.

This series is growing up with moody blockbuster urgency. More emotionally wracked with each new entry, the Potter franchise has become a mainstream fantasy metaphor for adolescent crisis. It's Rebel Without a Curse.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Gypsy Caravan could have used some judicious trimming, but you forgive Dellal her excesses as she forgives her artists theirs. This is music to gorge on, raw ethnic survival in the form of sound.
movie_title: When the Road Bends: Tales of a Gypsy Caravan (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's breezy, blood-flecked entertainment, with no aim other than to give you a giggle and a shriek.
A charming disappointment that retains the elements that make the writer's novels so good without ever bending them into cinematic shape.
Broken English is a conventional New York-lonely hearts story made watchable by one element and one element only: Parker Posey.
It's a predictable but acridly pleasant 12-step bonbon: self-help noir.
No matter how much the director disguises the tale in flickery symbolism, the emotions feel painful and personal.
Georgia Rule is a bad idea dreadfully executed -- On Golden Pond with fellatio jokes and whimsical incest melodrama and Fonda playing her dad (who, more and more, she eerily resembles).
Sicko is Moore's best, most focused movie to date -- much more persuasive than the enraged and self-righteous Fahrenheit 9/11.
One comes away from 10 Questions emboldened, energized, and sadder -- aware that peace remains so radical a concept that most of us aren't yet worthy of it.
Floats by on a mood of concerned and puckish good will.
The problem with structuring A Mighty Heart as a suspense film is obvious: We already know the outcome.
Very much a bookend to Vera Drake in its mixture of post war British reserve and ugly reality. [Actor] Spall makes it work, creating a little man with big and terrible secrets.
Roberts is pleasant enough but, like her fellow TV-bred teen stars, there's not a lot of there yet, let alone enough to suggest a corn-fed Sherlock Holmes.
A stark, cohesive experience.
The film's slick and entertaining, an obvious must-see for musical hounds. It holds water for laypeople, though, because the insights into a communal creative process are so sharp.
Sorry, boys. After two decades, the first film still does more with one skyscraper than Live Free or Die Hard does with an entire country.
The kids' individual triumphs seem satisfyingly hard-won.
The film reveals its secrets slowly, and Chabrol tightens the screws not according to the rules of Hollywood suspense but with a cool, level gaze.
Silly, obvious, clumsy, and just gruesome enough to keep jaded genre fans from angrily throwing popcorn at the screen.

This mysteriously rich, mostly wonderful comedy-drama takes place in September 2002, when the lives of its unconnected New Yorkers have returned to something that looks like normal. 'Normal' being a thin layer of tissue paper over the abyss.
The most minor entry in the brainiac-doc genre to date, it's nevertheless a perfectly entertaining hour and a half for crossword adepts.
Click gets its laughs and then sucker-punches us with sentiment; if it doesn't quite represent the new, improved Adam Sandler, it shows him almost desperately trying to figure out who that might be.
The results bear witness to a time when sacrifice was bleached of everything but itself.
It's a wrenching, ennobling essay on teamwork and the hard struggle to change one's life.

As soon as Kate lets drop that her favorite author is Jane Austen and the Nick Drake songs kick in on the soundtrack, you know this movie won't be taking any prisoners. Don't fight it with logic, because you'll lose.
Very broad and very silly, it's a doodle of a comedy -- a one-joke idea (fat guy goes luchador) padded out to feature length by Black's willingness to do anything for a laugh.
Plays more like a rant, and a poorly focused one at that.
It's a globe-trotting drama with more than a touch of Wim Wenders whim to it.
The short answer is: Pixar does it again.
It's an altogether satisfying drama -- the sort of movie some people complain they don't make anymore.
Fateless looks man's inhumanity to man square in the eye and pronounces it standard operating procedure, and that may be the greater horror.
A heart-render and a hankie-drencher, it's a film of quiet, almost incalculable power.
The sly ultra-low-budget film The Puffy Chair fits right in with recent news reports about college graduates refusing to grow up already.
The Break-Up mostly just lies there -- alternately adoring and condemning its characters for their puppyish refusal to grow up.
A generally thrilling entertainment that's not quite the grand slam you want it to be.
Warm, witty, and sitcom-obvious -- a genuine audience pleaser that's built to wring laughs of pained recognition from anyone who has survived a bar mitzvah as either a participant or an observer.
It's a galling and provocative experience to viewers of any political persuasion, and a reminder to the left of how easily idealism can run amok.
This is a movie about losing one's grip and like any addict's story, it's boring, ugly, sad, and terribly human. And surprisingly funny.
A nervy but muddleheaded work ... with sharply unpleasant things to say about the First World's moral strip-mining of the Third but an overly tactful way of saying them.
Barnyard is nothing so much as The Lion King chewed in a cud and digitally regurgitated. It's manic and maudlin, borderline creepy, occasionally inspired.
Apes the cinematic and musical excesses of its era so eerily that it's worth a look.
There's much in the movie that won't translate to audiences this side of the Volga, but there's also a humor and a fierce filmmaking intelligence that demand attention.
It looks at the all-American obsession with winning and chortles darkly. You still come out of the movie wanting to give your family a hug.
Scenes from a Marriage was twice as devastating with none of the stylistic folderol.
It saddens me to report -- Scoop is distinctly minor Allen, with less weight to it than one of his old humor doodles in The New Yorker.
Klapisch has made something deliciously close to a nature documentary about the young, the foolish, and the alive.
Has Kevin Smith gone soft?
Even at 87 minutes, Monster House overstays its welcome. The finale is an overbearingly loud chaos of splintered boards and sentiment.
Lugubrious to the extreme of unintended comedy, the movie suggests a regional dinner theater production of a late- ' 80s Peter Greenaway film.
It has deep things to say and a hilariously ponderous way of saying them.
Whatever the approach, the songs are sturdy enough to support it while remaining resigned and elusive, their words practically glowing in the dark.
The main characters may be refreshingly cliché-free, but almost everyone they meet in Beverly Hills is a stilted cartoon.
Fierce, deftly entertaining work of muckraking journalism.

The dreaded curse of the sequels hits home with a vengeance in Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest, a noisy and lazy stopgap movie that goes absolutely nowhere and takes 2 1/2 hours to get there.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A near-masterpiece of mood and menace, and one that deserves to be seen on the largest screen possible.
See No Evil is proficient junk, which makes it something of an improvement over recent horrors like An American Haunting.
A Hitchcockian thriller with human conundrums to go with the suspense.
Feuerzeig's film is as good a portrait of the artist as a beloved basket case as you'll see, but it's kept from greatness by the questions it refuses to ask itself.
A fascinatingly conflicted artifact of Depression-era do-me feminism.
If Lucky Number Slevin was as good as it is clever, we'd be talking four stars here.
Brick is almost fiendish in its insistence on finding modern-day parallels to classic pulp-fiction figures.
This small, somber drama says things to battered women they probably already know. What it says to their abusers -- of any country or culture -- they can't afford to ignore.
movie_title: Te doy mis ojos (Take My Eyes) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Ice Age: The Meltdown is pure sequel product that should make children and undemanding grown-ups happy even as it lacks anything resembling storytelling inspiration.
Absurdly overheated and unforgivably dull, Basic Instinct 2 is the accidental comedy sensation of the year to date.
At last: the mutant alien redneck zombie movie the world has been waiting for.
If the movie's witless, it's also pretty harmless.
movie_title: Larry the Cable Guy: Health Inspector (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The Unknown White Male that Murray has made asks profound questions. They're just not necessarily the right ones.
Vile beyond redemption.
movie_title: The Heart Is Deceitful Above All Things (2004)

movie_review_blurb: [A] big-hearted failure of a film.
Like its protagonist, the movie is smart, soulless, glib, and utterly charming -- just the thing to warm up a movie season that's been late to bloom.
Duck Season hits every one of its modest marks and then some. It's the kind of movie to send you out looking at strangers on the street with newfound appreciation and something close to love.
Too suspenseful for the youngest children, but for anyone older than 8 or 9, it evokes nothing less than awe at the harsh beauty of the natural world.
This is a movie to make you cherish Pixar all the more; where every pixel and plot turn in Finding Nemo snaps organically into place, The Wild strains just to get to the end of a scene.
Does any of this work? Sure, but only through the graces of a cast that knows better than to play to our hearts.
Even The Doors looked like a model of clarity next to this.
American Dreamz is a political satire that's eerily emblematic of the moment we're living in: smart, spring-loaded with pop culture references, and far too good-natured to do any lasting damage.

As a film derived from a book, The Da Vinci Code isn't a fiasco on the order of The Bonfire of the Vanities nor is it a triumph a la The Lord of the Rings. Instead, it's an acceptable but uninspired simulacrum.
Shortland balances showing Heidi as a heartbreaking mess -- doing a jailbait dance here, impulsively swallowing a mouthful of chili peppers there -- and judging her for it.
Noteworthy for the poetry it aspires to and the jumbled prose it delivers.
It becomes the sort of thing Zwigoff usually holds in contempt, and how depressing is that?
Handsomely shot and with a likable lead in Kuno Becker, it also suffers from a script so outrageously generic you could buy it at Costco.
movie_title: Goal! The Dream Begins (Goal!: The Impossible Dream) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: There will be people who won't go to United 93 because they think it will be depressing yet will go to Poseidon expecting an exciting night at the movies, and I guess I don't understand how their brains work.
The problem is that a little of this minimalist kitchen-sink farce goes a very long way, and after a while Lonesome Jim starts to dry up.
Oliver Stone has made an honorable film, in other words, and almost the best thing I can say about it is that it doesn't feel like an Oliver Stone movie.
Extremely watchable, even if it never goes as deep as it should.
Hoot tells kids they can make a difference in this world, and that's worth a hundred Ice Age 2's.
It suggests that talented Chinese directors are being led astray by the seductions of CGI and wirework fantasies.
movie_title: The Promise (Master of Crimson Armor) (Wu ji) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Hard Candy is the rare movie that may be worthiest for the arguments you'll have after it's over.
RV has teeth -- more teeth than the last few Steve Martin films, anyway -- but it's terrified to bite down, knowing that the paying audience would feel it more than anyone.
... you come out feeling that the filmmakers have done the right thing by this day.
It's a handsome, often funny piece of work with a nearly fatal inability to settle on a tone.
It's that gulf between earnest idealism and beaten-down realism that's the unexpected drama of Beauty Academy.
There's a dark, abiding mystery at the center of An American Haunting, and it's how on earth major stars such as Donald Sutherland and Sissy Spacek were talked into appearing in this film.
You'll want to take a shower after Notes on a Scandal, but you'll be glad you got dirty.
The Groomsmen may be low-cal Cassavetes or Secrets and Lies for mooks, but Burns knows his turf. The marvel is that after seven films he's still finding fresh grass.
Trying to give us the true story behind the epic, the movie only reminds us of why humans write epics in the first place.
The Motel gives the lie to all those mainstream teen sex comedies starring happy, horny gwailos .
Happy Feet is one of the most visually ravishing CGI films yet rendered.
Let the purists squawk: In Daniel Craig, the Bond franchise has finally found a 007 whose cruel charisma rivals that of Sean Connery.
As B-level suspensers go, though, The Return isn't actively awful -- just slow and cursed with a lead who acts with her T-shirt.

James Longley's Iraq in Fragments is a visually stunning documentary that looks at that country through the eyes of its own people -- a novel enough approach at a time when everyone else has had their say.
A shamelessly enjoyable retread, an ode to la belle vie that has been well turned on a factory spindle.

Jack Frost gains control of Santa's workshop and turns it into a Las Vegas-style theme park -- supposedly a hideous inversion of Christmas values. So blandly commercialized is the movie's vision of the holiday that you can hardly tell the difference.
movie_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause (2006)

movie_review_blurb: For a movie that insists on the truth of humanity's mutual dependency, Babel feels disconnected from anything but its own artistic determinism.
Kids will probably be in stinky-sewage heaven with the new computer-animated critter comedy Flushed Away, but even they may realize they're up the proverbial creek in a boat with a faulty motor.
A comic put-on of awe-inspiring crudity and death-defying satire and by a long shot the funniest film of the year. It is Jackass with a brain and Mark Twain with full frontal male nudity.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It is harrowing, heartbreaking, cheering, and unforgettable.
The movie itself feels like an overstuffed burrito: Nicola Pecorini's cinematography has verve but no visual sense, and the film's self-important pace turns deadening over the long haul.
The whole film has the whiff of a low-cost documentary unspooling on a basic cable channel on Sunday afternoon when you should be out raking leaves.
The book has had its darkest, least-forgiving details sanded off for the multiplex.
It does absolutely nothing that previous movies dealing with this subject haven't done.
There's an interestingly ugly social comedy to be made about jail, but Let's Go to Prison isn't it.
The 85-minute documentary takes a torpid, fly-on-the-wall approach, providing little context, few insights, and not enough music.
movie_title: LoudQUIETloud: A Film About the Pixies (2006)

movie_review_blurb: How come the talk-radio blowhards never bring movies like this up when they're inveighing against the War on Christmas?
The film grows in power as it goes, finding ever more universal levels of feeling.
Off the Black is a small, dry, emotionally loaded short story that has been carried to film like baked fish to a platter.

The Good German is a movie wonk's triumph and no one else's. Soderbergh gets the visuals right but not the clean storytelling line of classic cinema, nor the iconic characters or moral certainty of the oldies.
Night at the Museum, in fact, is stuffed with smart performers doing graciously silly work, and all [director Shawn] Levy has to do is manage traffic.
Rocky Balboa isn't a response to Stallone's late-life crisis, it is his late-life crisis, right up there on the screen.
You wish some of the plot holes had been spackled better.
A deceptively small film, one whose observations may continue to detonate quietly in your mind after the lights have come up.
It's a fine film, with a portrait of fatherhood that feels scuffed and driven and real.

The way to watch it is to skip uneasily along its surface and steel yourself for those moments when Lynch pulls you into the vortex. More than any working filmmaker, he knows the dreamlike power of undertow.
Blood Diamond wears both its social conscience and its Hollywood calculation on its sleeve. The movie wants to rouse you to action while narcotizing you with Connelly's bottomless green eyes.
Mel Gibson may be a lunatic, but he's our lunatic, and while I wouldn't wish him behind the wheel of a car after happy hour or at a B'nai Brith function anytime, behind a camera is another matter.
As swoony and verbose and serious as an adolescent's journal entry.
The whole movie feels filmed through the wrong end of a stereopticon: stiff, fascinating, riddled with secrets it doesn't care to divulge.
It's a sweet, calculated two-hander starring someone you know very well and someone you've never heard of but probably should...
At the very least, it's refreshing to see a holiday film that doesn't involve Tim Allen wearing 80 pounds of rubber padding.
Ham-handed and TV-movie flat, it states the obvious, then states it again and again and again.

If there were more Darren Aronofskys, the multiplex would be a stranger and better place. Flaws and all, The Fountain believes in itself more fervently than any other movie you may see this year -- so fervently it doesn't need an audience's faith.
This is grand, half-crazy fun, and Jackman and Bale are committed to their parts: Genuine madness glints in their eyes.
It's a monumental subject, and this heartsick but diffuse movie only occasionally glimpses its entirety.
[Mitchell] reclaims sex -- filming it, watching it, talking about it, doing it -- as something both deeply funny and transcendently human: a revolving door that leads to the senses and to the heart.
At nearly two hours Lunacy becomes repetitive, at first ingeniously and then with a slowly dulling edge. The meat parade ceases to shock.
A gorgeous, meandering travelogue that only gradually bares its teeth.
movie_title: Journey into Buddhism: Vajra Sky Over Tibet (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The film is simple bordering on sentimental bordering on sloppy, yet it's kept in artistic check by the vast backdrops of China's remote Yunnan province and by Takakura's nearly wordless performance.
movie_title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Gritty and terrifically human, Half Nelson is not your big brother's Hollywood high school movie.
It's the comic, touching glimpses into a society run aground that make Something Like Happiness special and link it with the gentle fables of the Czech New Wave films of the 1960s.
Earnest and predictable, Crossover deserves more than the horselaughs that will probably greet it in theaters -- but not a lot more.
Demands to be seen for the juice it manages to wring out of its central gambit but mostly for the directorial career it hints is on the horizon.
Hamer has created a tidy film about a fabulously messy man.
Making a comedy that celebrates binge drinking and cretinous behavior isn't a crime against nature. Making one that's as brutally unfunny as Beerfest is.
If it grows more genial as it pokes along, it still feels like a lesser Nickelodeon special, with adults who are shrill cartoons and kids who are one-note character tics.
Enjoyable but undeniably creaky; what played as glorious period tomfoolery to European festival juries and discerning U S audiences in the early 1950s now just seems quaintly pleased with itself.
The pleasure of The Illusionist lies in its luxuriant belief in old-fashioned verities like character and storytelling; it's as thin as a sheet of marbled endpaper and as cleanly crafted.
Low of brow and pure of heart, the movie plays like Animal House extra-lite, and as such it's decent indecent fun.

Jackson is The Man, and he bestrides this film with the authority of someone who knows the value of honest bilge. He's as much the auteur of this baby as the director and screenwriters, and that fierce glimmer in his eye is partly joy.
Shabbily filmed and resolutely unfunny.
No offense to Pipkin and his real concerns, but a tougher questioner might have shed more light and heat.
Anyone with half a brain is not this movie's target audience.
The documentary any American with an opinion on our involvement in Iraq owes it to his or her conscience to see.
As with Garden State and Elizabethtown, The Last Kiss is an iPod playlist in search of a movie, and what it loses in honest drama it will surely make up for in sales of the CD.
The film's a pretty good scrapbook ... and it evinces a healthy cranky-old-man disgust with the mega-platinum punk acts of today.
Grander statements aren't needed when the specific indictments are so plentiful and so horrifying.
Man of the Year has to be one of the most frustrating dropped balls in recent multiplex memory.
Rarely do battling productions -- these two were shot mere months apart -- result in equally valid films, but that's the case here.
In turning over the question of what makes a person a Jew -- not to mention what makes a person belong to any society -- Live and Become is worthy of attention.
movie_title: Va, Vis et Deviens (Live and Become) (Go, See, and Become) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A subtle, often very funny, ultimately touching tragedy of royal manners and meaning.

49 Up marks the latest chapter in one of the most ambitious documentary projects in movie history. Make that the history of any medium, for how often do we get to witness a time-lapse study of human life?
Alive with infectious rhythm, likable characters, and slick dance moves, Step Up gives clichés a good name.

A relentlessly violent, breathtakingly assured piece of mean-streets filmmaking, the film shows the legendary director dropping the bids for industry respectability that have preoccupied him over the past decade and doing what he does best.
The documentary's a hagiography, no mistake about it, but a fascinating one all the same, and it makes the case that Lennon was as much a genius provocateur as he was a cracked saint.
It achieves something previously thought impossible: It renders Billy Bob Thornton unfunny.
A feeble college comedy aimed at middle schoolers.
Cute and exasperating and, in the end, not nearly lunatic enough; it's a Christopher Guest movie without the fangs.
The movie's straightforward and ingratiating, and as pretty-boy history lessons go, it's a lot less obnoxious than Pearl Harbor.
All the King's Men is a big, important awards-season special with one glaring problem: It doesn't have anything urgent or even interesting to say.
The charm of Conversations With Other Women, a gimmicky but oddly moving two-character drama that flies in from who knows where, is its intelligent knowingness.
A comic book -- mint condition, double-bagged -- that leaves you impressed only with its pristine hollowness.
A lighthearted riff on heavy themes, Dans Paris is a knowing throwback to the playful, profound works of the early French New Wave.
The Water Horse moves along at a dutiful clip, engaging us without transporting us.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: When something seems too bizarre to be true, that's generally how it plays onscreen.

A fairly good thriller with mixed-bag elements: preposterous plot, smartly elegant direction, one of the worst recent performances by a major actress, and a dynamite stick of an action scene that can stand close to the greats.
The movie plays like Love Actually with half the brains and none of the nerve.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Nearly four decades after its release, The Wild Child remains startling for its humane clarity, for Nestor Almendros's brilliant black-and-white photography, and for the sense that Truffaut is achieving filmmaking mastery on a very small scale.
If you have a 10-and-up who's drawn to alt-comics, smart books, dark clothing, and general pop culture subversion, the movie will be his or her Wonderland.
The movie's refusal to judge is its most interesting attribute, if one many audiences won't be able to get around.
You've seen New in Town before, and you've seen it done better.
The film, devastating and distressing in equal measure, widens in meaning as it narrows in scope.

What the Bielski brothers did in the forests of Belorussia deserves to be remembered and celebrated, but this glossy studio production robs them of life. It's not just new Holocaust stories that we need, but new ways of telling them.
There are moments to treasure, but they're small and delicately crafted -- actors' moments.
Friendly, formulaic, completely harmless.

Rather than creating a work of lament or complaint, the filmmakers embark on a series of feel-good profiles of working women artists -- in such places as Providence, Cambridge, and Taos, N.M. -- who also happen to be mothers.
movie_title: Who Does She Think She Is? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's a chick flick; nothing wrong with that. But it's also a chick flick that makes its chick characters -- and by extension its chick audience -- look like hateful, backward toddlers, and there is something wrong with that.
Winslet gives a fearless performance here. It's not her fault her husband has shrouded it in Taste.
Gran Torino is alive to the web of racial and ethnic discontent in this country, but the script by Nick Schenk and Dave Johannson has a tin ear.

The Wrestler is about the seductions of superficiality and the dull ache of living beyond one's moment. It stares with compassion at the man pinned on the mat and wonders how he'll ever get out of this one.
There's meat and sustenance there, but Cherry Blossoms too often traffics in shopworn Western notions of Japanese culture; it's a pilgrim's-eye-view of Zen.
With just the slightest tilt toward black comedy, Valkyrie could have been the Dilbert of Nazi movies.
Genial and potty-mouthed and dumb and sweet -- a rudely engaging road comedy with more inside Star Wars baseball than a convention hall full of Imperial Grand Moffs.
It's one of the few movies I've seen recently that improves on a second viewing, in part because Phoenix does such remarkably subtle work.
Alien Trespass could be the latest bulletin from Mystery Science Theatre 3000 except that we're the silhouetted heads and the filmmakers are sitting right there next to us.
It's good, nasty fun until it gets boxed in by its own contrivances toward the end.
movie_title: Kærlighed på Film (Just Another Love Story) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A visually ravishing tour of hell and a meditation on freedom that at best is wordlessly profound and at worst interestingly obscure.
The latest computer-animated production from DreamWorks is a perfectly acceptable family movie.
It's a Nicolas Cage movie, so, admit it, you're expecting crazy. You have no idea.
It's an honest little movie, well written by Megan Holley, well directed by Christine Jeffs, and very well played by Amy Adams and Emily Blunt as the sisters.
It's a bromance that's out and proud. In the liberation are the laughs, and they stick to your ribs longer than you'd think.
The movie's aiming for the drunken college crowd but most of the gags have the nervous, giggly idiocy of two middle-school kids flipping through dad's Playboy.
A movie so unendurably bad it deserves to be put down like a sick dog.
The film's a haul but it's imaginative and rarely dull, especially once you realize how far it has strayed in principle from its source.
Shuttle mostly exists, in the words of Alfred Hitchcock, to 'put the audience through it,' but it leaves you in a very different place than where it started and with remarkable economy of effort.

An almost indescribable pleasure from Brooklyn-based cartoonist and animator Nina Paley. The film, dazzling and poignant and five years in the making, retells the ancient Indian epic The Ramayana from a gentle but insistent feminist perspective.

Phoebe in Wonderland gradually loses its grip on tone and believability, climaxing with a show-must-go-on moment that's just plain silly. Thankfully, Barnz knows exactly where to end his film: on the face of a girl, and an actress, at the crossroads.
Overall, Snyder has given us a Watchmen that's visually faithful to the original to the point of panel-by-panel fetishism, and that may be enough for many members of the cult.
Applying criticism to Jonas Brothers: The 3D Concert Experience is like trying to lasso a bull with dental floss. It's not going to stop the bull and no one's really going to notice.
Gorgeous, minor, and pivotal.
Miller turns The Spirit into a hambone farce. Worse, by hiring well-known actors and indulging their worst impulses, he destroys the tart irony Eisner built into every frame.

It's made on the smallest of budgets and features awkward if sincere performances, yet Yen Tan's film still manages to strike a series of plangent emotional truths about speaking one's heart and moving on.
A structural mess that turns contrived just when it should be hitting home.
Madonna has made a career out of toying with image and ego, but this is a vanity project in the smallest sense possible.

Director Gavin O'Connor and co-screenwriter Joe Carnahan take a perfectly fine B-movie premise and slow it down to an A-movie pace; in the process, they remove the juice that keeps a story like this honest.
For all its unforgivable blandness, High School Musical opens young audiences to the charms of this most transporting of movie genres.
A performance documentary with a tiny budget and a big spirit that follows three comics as they travel the country looking for laughs and understanding.
movie_title: Allah Made Me Funny: Live in Concert (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Happy-Go-Lucky isn't one of Leigh's epic social canvases like Secrets & Lies or even Topsy-Turvy; rather, it's an edgy character study whose message only gradually emerges.
Eventually it just stalls.
A Thousand Years of Good Prayers feels like a fragile wafer of a movie, but it fills you like a three-course meal.
movie_title: A Thousand Years of Good Prayers (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's a working definition of "safe sex."
Leaving the theater, you may have the sudden sense that, really, it is too early for this movie to have been made, as sharp and as complicated as some of its pieces are.

The story's powered by the sense of discovery that moves classic quest tales -- the idea that there's something much, much bigger out there if only you can find it. It's a modest movie that understands the sky's the limit.
The movie is an urgent current-events thriller that falls somewhere between Syriana and the Bourne movies.

Ultimately, the problem with An American Carol is the problem with far too much political discourse in this country, left or right: It highlights the worst excesses of the opposition for the sole purpose of discrediting the vast middle.
Nothing in How to Lose Friends feels fresh or on target.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: ...The problem with Flash of Genius isn't that the subject is dull but that the movie is.
Sollett's working with stale material, clearly. He genuinely likes people, though, and his fondness revives Nick and Norah and sets it spinning with camaraderie and hope.
Other peoples' emotional intimacy can be downright embarrassing. Here, sadly, it's also boring.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Thomas packs infinite amounts of nuance and agony into such moments, and after a while she outraces the movie itself.
Seen on a big screen, this is a movie to get drunk on.

Role Models plays well within the Judd Apatow playpen, but its shaggy-dog dyspepsia renders it both less commercial and a little more dangerous, and Rudd is why. He's W.C. Fields trapped in the body of Cary Grant.

Despite a moving, canny incarnation of the man by Frank Langella, despite a slickly entertaining coffee-table production as only Ron Howard knows how, the movie feels cooked up. In the name of dramatizing history, Frost/Nixon sacrifices it.
The movie's not really interested in originality, though. Instead, it wants to wrap the old seasonal homilies in the warm specifics of time and place and ethnicity. At that, it succeeds.
The new Day the Earth Stood Still lacks the courage of its own eco-pessimism, and the final scenes play like a rushed, embarrassed concession to our need for happy endings, no matter how far-fetched.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There are times when it is safe to say that a labor of love is love's labor lost, and, reader, this is one of them.

If most of the budget has gone to ordnance and blood squibs, director Lexi Alexander films the sprays of gore with an artisan's eye, and the results make effective if morally indefensible movie red meat.
Fifty years on, we're still living with the aftershocks of what Muddy and Wolf invented and the Chess brothers midwived, but it's in the air and not yet on the screen.
Australia strains to do it all, and finally all you can see is the strain.

[Director] Troell lovingly re-creates a time when socialism and Charlie Chaplin movies represented the ways forward, and he anchors his social panorama in the meek, stubborn stare of an unnoticed woman possessed with looking at everything.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: When will filmmakers learn that if you start with Bad Santa and finish with It's a Wonderful Life, you just end up with curdled eggnog?
I'll keep this simple: Cancel whatever you're doing tonight and go see Slumdog Millionaire instead.
To tweak Tolstoy: All happy families may be alike, but all unhappy-family movies are entertaining in their own ways.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: JCVD is what you might get if a French deconstructionist decided to make a drive-in flick: It reverse engineers the mayhem until it locates the humor, the sadness, and the insecure void at the heart of the genre.

Because its gaze is so level and so unyielding, it stands as one of the better dramatic films made on this subject (although it's not nearly as fine as Louis Malle's Au Revoir les Enfants, in which the camps remain a distant abstraction).
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Can you call a movie 'feel-good' if it includes an aviation disaster, a deadly avalanche, and human cannibalism? That's the paradox of the grueling yet ultimately exhilarating Stranded.
movie_title: Stranded: I Have Come from a Plane That Crashed on the Mountains (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The first release from the gay-oriented Mythgarden production company, Save Me still bodes well for its evenhanded approach.
Preening and fleeing like a grunge-flick Bob Hope, Campbell's the whole show, but a little of his meta-referential shtick goes a long way.
A darn good hunk of pop moviemaking.
When filmmaker Irena Salina does marshal the facts, Flow is an eye-opening, troubling 90 minutes that makes us think twice about an element we take for granted.
Structurally and cinematically, The Black Balloon sticks to the coming-of-age basics, but [director] Down has a gift for conveying time and place.

In its unhurried fashion, Sugar can take its place with the best baseball movies. Where most focus on the grand slam, this one's about the life that surrounds the game and everything that comes after.
It appears designed for families who never leave the mall.
One of the most hopeful and heart-rending movies I've seen this year.

Séraphine may be one of the spookiest, most unsettling films ever made about the hazy line between art and madness. That's a theme the movies have done to death, yet it finds new life in the title performance by Yolande Moreau.
The problem is that Apatow is stuck between gears. (That, and there's probably no one around him to say no at this point.)

G-Force represents an inconceivably tragic waste of a brilliant idea. Frankly, if you can't squeeze a decent movie out of talking 3-D superagent guinea pigs, you may as well throw in the towel and consider a career in insurance.
Director Jaume Collet-Serra moves Orphan along efficiently, doling out a 'boo!' shot every few minutes with mechanical professionalism.
Humpday just wrings every uncomfortable laugh from its premise then shudders to a halt: cut, end credits.

[It's] that rare film utterly without heroes; instead, it amasses a group of boobs, users, and charlatans on both sides of the Atlantic and asks us to recognize our duly elected and appointed officials. You'll laugh until you bleed, or vice versa.
The movie charmed me enough to send me out smiling, and I can see younger filmgoers taking it very much to heart.

You could argue that the film would be stronger if it explained more fully and asked more questions, yet "Unmistaken Child'' stands as a window on a beautiful and mysterious world. The questions it leaves hanging are for us to untangle.
Panettiere, I'm sad to report, is a dud as the title character, a supposed wild thang who never rises above the level of runty, obnoxious mall chick, down to the roll-on tan.
Dillinger is one of those artful endurance tests that views conventional storytelling as a sell-out. Yet the movie's also playful, droll, and unexpectedly wise within its rigorous framework.
Public Enemies has everything going for it except a reason and a script.
Whatever Works would have only worked if its director had written his trademark self-caricature out of it.
If the movie were better -- less swoony, more relentless -- it might be unbearable to watch. As it is, Cheri touches on the insecure egotism of courtesans and movie stars with a knowing firmness.
A Perfect Getaway is proof that a dumb idea can be brought to life, however briefly, by smart people, and writer-director David Twohy is nothing if not clever.
This book hasn't been adapted, it's been taken outside and shot.
Still, the stylistic games reflect Yi and her generation's larger dilemma. Paper Heart is a movie that can't commit about people who don't know how to.
It's an outsider blockbuster, a juicy, bravura piece of moviemaking pulp, and its hellacious style almost -- but not quite -- disguises its shortcomings as a story.

It'd be a tragedy if it weren't so richly absurd, but it would also make for better comedy if the joke weren't on us. The Informant! laughs so long and hard that it forgets to check whether we're laughing along.
Not that the grieving process shouldn't be addressed in a movie, but this one feels increasingly cooked up.
A bleakly funny character study of a very particular species of urban fauna -- the sports radio call-in fanatic -- Big Fan is compulsively watchable.

Jennifer's Body falls into the dispiriting category of dumb movies made by smart people, in this case a glibly clever writer and a talented director who think a few wisecracks are enough to subvert the teen horror genre.
It's the best Tyler Perry movie to date -- the writer/director/actor/mogul's most confident and competent mixture of uplifting black middle-class melodrama and low-down comedy.
movie_title: I Can Do Bad All By Myself (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A ham-handed murder mystery.
Easily the worst movie of the week, month, year, and Bullock's entire career. It is to comedy what leprosy once was to the island of Molokai: a plague best contemplated from many miles away.
If it's not actually a good movie, on some level you have to admire the chutzpah of a film set in 1850s Ireland but shot on Staten Island.
Inglorious Basterds is an entertainment but an uneasy one; it represents 153 minutes of bravura stalling, after which its creator loses interest and walks away.

Thirst keeps coming up against the limitations of its various inspirations like a bumper car on a crowded court. On almost every other level, the film's audaciously entertaining, at times even quite moving. You just have to have the stomach for it.

Shorts channels the same gross-out overkill as the Captain Underpants books that parents endure and pre-teen boys so dearly love. The difference is that those books have an editor (and they're funnier).
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Silence Before Bach is a movie in which to take refuge, and it abjures the summer heat of pop culture for a cool and lasting immersion in the miracles that people are and can create.
movie_title: The Silence Before Bach (Die Stille vor Bach) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's a very good film nevertheless, and in Dobroshi it has a face that passes through every conceivable shade of sorrow.
Within the context of modern family comedies and the vast enabling wasteland of tweener TV, these people feel almost three-dimensional.
The Time Traveler's Wife is told with a tenderness that's unusual in a major motion picture but that leads mostly to dullness.
G.I. Joe is a loud but proficient slab of explode-o-rama summer blockbuster nonsense, perfectly entertaining if you like that sort of thing, extremely skippable if you don't.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: So what if he can't put a coherent series of shots together? Bay's going for pure sensation, and everyone knows dramatic continuity is for women and the weak.
This is the kind of tastefully poignant drama that asks its audience to confront taboos and then pats them on the back for doing so.

Even as the news-gathering apparatus in the US and elsewhere falters under the weight of new technology and outdated business models, Burma VJ is a fresh reminder that reporters can and must serve as a necessary Paine in the rear.
movie_title: Burma VJ: Reporter i et Lukket Land (Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: To answer the question put forth by the title of Is Anybody There?: Michael Caine is there, single-handedly lifting a soggy bit of coming-of-age whimsy into the category of the watchable.
Ghosts is better-than-average McConaughey swill, but not by much -- that's its pleasure and its curse.
The movie's worth seeing for Abbass.
Tyson is terrifically compelling and, more than that, unexpectedly moving.
Gigantic plays like a Sundance movie with half the nouns removed; fetchingly cryptic for a while, it's ultimately just obscure.
The piece had better have something fresh to say. The Informers doesn't, nor does it seem to want to.
In its slick cinematic urgency and its outrage, Z still has the power to shake you up.
The movie, for all its flaws, reminds us that everyone is worth catching, but it's the actors who best embody that message. They go the full human being.
It's an ode to the absurdity of attraction.
movie_title: Un Baiser s'il vous plaît (Shall We Kiss?) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Anvil! is one of the sweetest, funniest films I've seen this year. Also the loudest and most foulmouthed.
17 Again is product, loaded with high fructose corn syrup so the girls will like it, and as meaningful as an afternoon at the mall.
Fascinating stuff, but after a while the film runs out of things to say and falls back on clichés.
movie_title: Virtual JFK: Vietnam If Kennedy Had Lived (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If you've seen Paris, je t'aime or New York Stories, you know the rate of return on these urban omnibuses is variable, and so it is here. Go in expecting minor pleasures and you'll be fine.
It raises more questions about the church's place in a changing world -- and touches more emotions doing so -- than any big-budget studio folderol.

Self-consciously poetic and shot within a luscious inch of its life, the film's also an engrossing heartbreaker: a family saga that spans continents, political administrations, and decades of travail to arrive at a harder, wiser place.
Trading on affections sustained over 40 years of popular culture, Star Trek does what a franchise reboot rarely does. It reminds us why we loved these characters in the first place.
An overly muted and cautious piece of work. Watching it is like seeing a man ease out onto the limb of a tree, constantly testing its strength.
With The Limits of Control, [Jim Jarmusch] has come up with a dud.
Sergei Dvortsevoy's remarkable film is fiction, but the characters are played by people more or less playing themselves, and each actor brings a rough charisma to the film.
Treeless Mountain casts a sad, pellucid spell. It looks at life from three feet off the ground and meets the hardening gaze of its 6-year-old protagonist head on.
Any good will the movie generates is grated right back off by Black, whose obnoxiousness has lost whatever charm it once possessed.
O'Horten is a precise, deadpan drama of slapstick existentialism -- a Bent Hamer movie, in other words.
The new Pelham is a solid, suspenseful tale all over again, so long as it stays in the subway tunnels and airless offices of the transit department.
The latest in the wave of post-Judd Apatow Bad Lad comedies, The Hangover is rowdy, scurrilous, and, for about three-quarters of its running time, a lot more hilarious than it has any right to be.
Genially terrible, Lost is lazy, sloppy multiplex filler, good for a few solid giggles and not much more.
Those coming in cold may be forgiven for thinking they've wandered into Atonement remade as a farce.
This may be Knightley's first truly mature performance. Too bad it arrives wrapped in doggerel.
Because the movie's grounded, it's free to fly where it wants, and it does so with an exuberance and poignancy that at times feels majestic.
What's intended to be a daring look at repressed sexuality, three-ways and all, has the dramatic heft of a true-love comic book.
It's bigger, noisier, shinier, and dumber, and it has no earthly reason to exist.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A con game about con games, the second film from writer-director Rian Johnson is breezily enjoyable for about 10 minutes, until you realize the entire movie is going to be pitched at the same exuberantly manic pace.

The latest installment in the venerable sci-fi action franchise turns out to be a straight-up war film, grim and muscular and thundering and joyless. It's the color of cement, and it weighs as much, too.
Sometimes a cute-stalker movie can win the audience's heart. Management only makes you ponder the line between true love and a restraining order.

Watching Adoration is like juggling three tennis balls, a porcupine, and a graduate thesis, but eventually it finds a unifying theme, that of tolerance melting away racial and intergenerational hatreds.
Rudo y Cursi is a grave and calculated affront to the men of Mexico, and that's the source of its roistering charm.

What could seem an empty stylistic exercise (and was, in the director's 2002 Full Frontal) serves to bring a fresh urgency to the tale, ultimately granting the audience a wisdom and perspective the characters never possess.
I'm not sure why The Duchess doesn't wholly succeed, because the pieces are all there and they're very watchable.
The chief culprits are Townsend's TV-movie characterizations and a very muddled message.
Choke is disappointing not for what it is but what it could have been.

Cloverfield captures the chronic self-absorption of the Facebook generation with breathless, cleverly recycled media savvy, and then it stomps that self-absorption to death. These days, that's entertainment.
[Director] Bayona has fashioned an assured, even conservative piece of work, one that's lusciously filmed and more than a little terrifying but that in the end never widens out to greater art.
It's The 400 Blows viewed from behind a veil and drawn with a graceful, ironic black-and-white pen.

Daniel Anker's film faults Hollywood both for ignoring the Holocaust during the war years and for trivializing it later. It's a mixed message that coheres largely thanks to Anker's archival spadework and his luck in securing interviews.
movie_title: Imaginary Witness: Hollywood and the Holocaust (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The problems with the movie are twofold and easy to spot: the acting stinks and you can't understand what's going on.
The movie's a handsome piece of work, dramatically powerful even when it backs into silliness.
Smartly written and beautifully played.
A conceptual masterstroke. Sweeney always wanted to be a revenger's tragedy to make us recoil in fright. Now it is. Merry Christmas.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: As long as it's galloping along, the movie's perfectly good popcorn -- in itself a rarity these days -- but eventually you get down to the burnt kernels at the bottom of the bag.
Lynch may be the documentary David Lynch wants, but I'm not sure it's the one he or we deserve.

That smart, hip, human comedy you've been waiting for all year? The one with dialogue like a sugar rush and performances like grace notes? It's called Juno and it just arrived in theaters. Go forth and multiplex.
The Kite Runner will be loved by many moviegoers for its taste and humanity, but for all the places Forster takes us he doesn't show us anything we haven't seen.
The script leans heavily on the pranks and big-eyed cuteness of the li'l guys and leaves the live actors with unfunny dialogue and nothing to do.
Slick, impassioned, and guardedly upbeat.
The movie never goes as deep as the novel (no movie could), but it's a worthy approximation: a Merchant-Ivory movie that turns in on itself with a lucid and painful sigh.
Has John Sayles finally lost his mojo?
With all its hesitations and half-measures, The Golden Compass kindled something this critic hasn't felt in years: a burning thirst to see the sequel.
A grittier, slightly more real-world version of movies like Step Up, Stomp the Yard, and Save the Last Dance.

Depressive, slow, darkly funny, unyielding in its formal rigor, and unsettlingly beautiful.

movie_title: The Other Side of the Street (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Sounds like a grand old time -- a hip fusion of Nickelodeon attitude, the wittier children's books, and retro kitsch culture. In fact, it's a nearly unwatchable combination of the worst elements of all three.

Those who prefer a little meat on their documentary bones may come away hungry.

movie_title: CSA: The Confederate States of America (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Heart of Gold -- filmed in much the same manner [as Stop Making Sense], with pristine sound and a notable lack of audience shots -- is a deeper and infinitely more touching piece of work.
