movie_review_blurb: Rudderless is the greatest film to emerge from Sundance this year.
Though it is unlikely that Mud will live up to the expectations of those who were floored by Jeff Nichols' last film Take Shelter, it is still a powerful film in it's own right.

Whether Crystal Fairy will play well to those who aren't familiar with drugs or drug culture remains to be seen. I can say though that I absolutely loved this film and would highly recommend you give it a shot.
kink wonderfully achieves its goal of lightly educating and demystifying the world of BDSM, but for people that are already familiar with this world, you may find yourself left wanting.

Stoker proves that not only can Park Chan-Wook do what others like Polanski and Jeunet have sometimes failed to do, but he can do it with just the same amount of gusto and which panache that made all of his Korean films so damn good.

Blue Caprice premiered at Sundance as part of the NEXT category and rightfully so because it most assuredly marks the beginning in what we hope will be a bright career for both Alexander Moors, and Tequan Williams.
One of the reasons I hated this Joshua Michael Stern's need to find it necessary to spoon feed his audience to the point of being completely patronizing.
The Raid 2 is a film you absolutely can't miss!
For all its absurdity Dead Sushi is truly a film made by a bunch of like-minded Japanese Lost Boys who are all just trying to have fun and make each other laugh, and it shows!

The songs, most of which were composed by Indie legends Jonathan Rice and Jenny Lewis, are truly highlights of the film, but in reality, they aren't enough to add any significant amount of cohesion to the story.
Historical arguments aside, there is no mistaking that Lincoln is likely one of the best films of the year.
The Trip to Italy is a hilarious romp through the Italian countryside.

Tokyo Idols is a fascinating look behind the curtain of the idol phenomenon in Japan. For all its faults, it works as an intriguing character study, giving its viewers a unique opportunity to observe this craze that has been sweeping over Asia.
Drake Doremus returns to Sundance with a heart wrenching dissection of love in the internet age.
The intentions were good, the issue important, but the film's execution belies the changing impact it may have had.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Sundance really knows their music docs, and We Are X is possibly the greatest music doc to come out of the festival since Searching For Sugarman in 2014.
Boyhood truly is a film about the human experience, and this is something everybody can relate to.
An incendiary performance from Patrick Stewart fuels a stunning film, not for the faint of heart.
A focused, illuminating spotlight on a man who gave America's TV a clear, resonant voice.
movie_title: Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You (2016)

movie_review_blurb: One unnerving, stress-inducing joyride, and once you're buckled in, there's nothing left but to see it through to the end.
Observant, witty, and at no time too heavy-handed, it is one of the true gems of this years Sundance festival, and one of the best films of the year so far.
A wildly nostalgic, unashamed romp - Yoga Hosers is the most 'Kevin Smith' Kevin Smith has ever made.
Jones and Pearce do the best they can with the hackneyed material, but even they aren't immune to this painfully slight and remarkably forgettable film.
Existing as some sort of low-rent Eli Roth imitation that miraculously leaves us wishing we were watching one of Roth's films instead.
The sterile process that the film is fixated on is admirable, but Jimmy P. rarely gets at anything engrossing or interesting about its characters.
Intimacy, memory and questioned identity all bleed into one dejected protagonist who can't quite do the heavy lifting that the screenplay calls for.
Relatable and empathetic.
A stunning blend of life's grand and monotonous movements.
While Reeves exhibits natural talent behind the camera, his debut carries an austere coldness that shuts out any semblance of diverting pleasure.

With amazing visuals, a time capsule of clips and images from the actual Voyager mission, and human moments while trying to reach for the stars, this film is an experience that will make you think of what lies far beyond our skies.
Director Keen made a solid comedy with Fist Fight.
Sadly, this movie was heavily advertised as a comedy and was instead a bland and below average action movie with the few jokes from the trailer being the only humor in the whole movie.
If you're going into this expecting to be genuinely frightened, you may be disappointed.
Despite some infrequent highlights, the negatives are glaring.
Shyamalan created a film to remember with Split. In today's cinematic world of sub-par horror films and predictable thrillers, this film serves as a breath of fresh air
Super Dark Times is a film that I would recommend to anyone who is looking for a suspenseful and meaningful drama.

A nice-looking movie isn't a good movie. Jumanji focused on story, character development, and a strong sense of imagination while Welcome to the Jungle focused more on gags, clichéd moments, and visual effects.
Despite how many problems I had with the film's inconsistent narrative, the Coens still manage to make the overall experience quite entertaining.
...Barbershop: The Next Cut succeeds with its charming cast, endearing dialogue and timely sociopolitical subject matter.
...for all the problems Confirmation faces, its forceful leads are what make this a worthwhile one-time viewing.
...10 Cloverfield Lane will best be viewed for the amazingly acted, tense psychological thriller it is.
Sleepless is the epitome of Cop Movie 101 filmmaking, and it shamelessly cruises on autopilot from beginning to end.
After a slow two and a half hours of haphazard filmmaking, disappointment was the only feeling that lingered.
The Shallows is as simple as survival movies get, where it's nothing more than woman vs. shark.
This movie about a group of risk-takers should have taken more risks itself.
I think Titans will play better on the small screen, where its flaws aren't so exaggerated, and viewers can make all the cheap popcorn they want.

Downloading Nancy is ultimately more interested in presenting a situation rather than resolving it.
While all of the spectacle is relatively enjoyable, it's two key moments of magic relating to heroes and how we project ourselves onto them that really soar.
Both the script and direction conjure up the cold, clammy sweat of dread over and over again with a shocking amount of ease.
Carell and Fey may be funny "in" the movie, but the film doesn't actually support their comedy in any way, outside of providing a setting.
Egoyan's ideas are better than his payoffs.
Smith has succeeded at achieving his modest goals, [although] maybe those goals are too modest.
The problem is that Sigismondi's screenplay is ultimately trying to turn two stories into one, and it doesn't quite work.
Has its heart in the right place, but the chemistry just isn't there.

Awkwardly fashioned into a popcorn movie by studio folks with a pair of scissors and a few reels of reshoots.
There will be a lot of win/lose puns in reviews this week, but I don't think The Losers is either one. It's more like a participant.
There are plenty of laughs in the movie, although most of them are not as satisfying as you'd hope.

I wouldn't say that this budgeted-up rehash is a great movie, or that it has anything on Craven's 1984 original, but at least Bayer keeps his gaze focused on the parts of the material that interest him.

In case any Disney executives are listening: Johnny Depp's Captain Jack Sparrow is your paydirt, fellas. In Nicolas Cage, you hired the one actor that might be able to out-crazy him, so why isn't there more madness to this method?
It took quite a bit of patience on my part to make it through Peacock, and it's not because the movie is painfully inept, but because it has no focus or dramatic drive whatsoever.
There's no better way to describe Despicable Me than "cute". It's almost unbearably cute.
The movie's MacGuffin is itself.
Knight and Day is a real slog, bogged down by an anemic script that needs to pick up the pace and some of the worst CG I can remember seeing in a big-budget movie.
Quirk and whimsy, signifying nothing; Micmacs is the ultimate exercise in self-reflexiveness.
Cyrus isn't quite the rousing experience I was hoping for the theoretical crossover between arthouse and frathouse, but it's a small-scale success that's at least worth a look.
A villainous double-crossing traitor has robbed our hero of his soul, but the bigger plot afoot here is determining who sucked the life out of the film itself.
On one hand, it isn't quite perfect, but at the same time, it is, with the film's almost non-stop high points easily blotting out the rare smudge on the movie's veneer.

I was literally right on the verge of throwing up my hands and resigning to the fact that this was just a giant vanity project when Jackie Chan finally makes a serious entrance into the picture and saves it from itself.
While you can't walk away from it without the stench of commerce filling your nostrils, you'll have a grin on your face all the same.
Greek is basically the same formula [as Marshall], but the familiar structure is a little less bland, and the great one-liners are much, much funnier.
The principal players should be embarrassed to have this movie on their resumes, offering only shrugs and emotionless smirks whenever anyone asks them what the hell they might have been thinking.
A nutsoid piece of niche entertainment that savors every last drop of its hard-R rating and tries valiantly to go to places MacGruber never would have been able to go on late-night television.

I don't think that Robin Hood was forced onto the director's plate, but the movie shows Scott playing into (or too tired to fight off) the desires of focus groups and demographic surveys rather than actual audiences.
Cabin Fever 2 comes dangerously close to being a worthwhile sequel.
Iron Man 2 is a pretty good sequel to a very good original, and a lack of further development for its main characters is the movie's major weakness.
There are scenes in Please Give that are perfectly on-point and immensely satisfying, [but the movie feels] stretched to feature length with the application of major padding.
The Princess and the Frog is a well-meaning but perhaps overly calculated effort to please everyone.
Drag Me to Hell delivers...it's Raimi's version of the seat buzzer, and I imagine William Castle is cackling with delight.
In his newest outing, Jason Voorhees doesn't reinvent the wheel, and that's exactly what's wrong with it.
'They saved the best for last' becomes 'death saved the best for 3D'. Sadly, neither of these things is true: this is the worst entry in the series.
A strange, demented vision of Haddonfield that's unlike any of the other Halloween films. To many, this will be a bad thing...I thought it was great.
An incredibly compelling piece of filmmaking -- one of the best of the year -- but not a particularly engaging movie, offering a vision of a time and little else.
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Big Fan will make you second-guess the overly-devoted, without deciding for you whether Paul's love is tragic or bittersweet.
Nothing if not feel-good, but it feels more like it should be an episode in a miniseries about Disney's life rather than a feature-length film.

Sometimes I think Touchstone has a fill-in-the-blank interface for "blockbuster" movies: type in a mildly clever idea, add some actors, press "Start" and out pops a pre-packaged motion picture. Surrogates is one of those movies.
Inglorious Basterds requires patience, but anyone paying any of attention to the characters should find it almost unbearably tense.

There are numerous problems with Pandorum, including some really bad dialogue, corny sequences, poorly-written characters and a clunky twist. What works, though, and works well enough to eke out a recommendation as a B-thriller, is the sense of isolation.
I'm not a sixteen-year-old girl, but I can't understand why someone who is as smart as Jenny clearly is would consider listening to Sarsgaard's character David.
Zemeckis' version of the story has almost no forward momentum...something about the motion capture process robs the characters of motivation.
It's far from perfect, but Kelly has created my favorite kind of science fiction: thoughtful and creepy.

With the help of first-time performer Donal Gallery, this mix of gangster drama and quirky comedy boasts a modest charm that should appeal to young men around same age as the 16 year old lead character, despite a lack of focus and familiar twists.
The final product is so bad it's more likely to cause its intended audience to swear off comedy than to demand more.
Timer is an immensely enjoyable triumph that actually has a voice.

If The Goonies is kids' adventure, Flight of the Navigator is kids' sci-fi and Gremlins is kids' horror, then Where the Wild Things Are is the rarest of all, a genuine kids' drama, and it is a stunning one at that.

The Rise of Cobra will leap and bound like a solider in an accelerator suit to the hearts of anyone who's ever owned an action figure. Forget the overlong, extra-serious Transformers films; this is the finest brand of fun, big-budget schlock.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There are a few stories in Shrink that are interesting enough, but when all of them are in the same movie, surrounded by other, less interesting concepts, none of them have the screen time they need to come to fruition.

Larry David and Woody Allen should be a match made in neurotic Jewish comedy heaven, but it doesn't pay off: the movie just sits there, mostly inert, as some unexpected cosmic, comic element about David and Allen fails to mesh.
The Wrestler is a true tragedy. It aims to bruise the soul and succeeds, because it features a performance by star Mickey Rourke. He, and he alone defines the film, and it is the best movie of 2008.

Taken starts out a little slow, giving us time to know Bryan, but once it's off and running, it literally doesn't stop: there are no breathers, no fleshed-out side characters, no pit stops, no detours.
It's clear to me that Dakota Fanning is the real deal. Too bad Push is a bit of a lark; it's sound and fury, signifying a sequel.

There are lots of characters in Disney's new big-budget update Race to Witch Mountain, but they rattle around this hollow spectacle like bits of plastic inside a broken action figure, without a single bit of cinematic life among them.
Meandering, disgusting, amateurish and cheap-looking. It also made me laugh a couple of times, but not enough for me to recommend it.
The remake isn't terrible, isn't torture porn, and isn't much else either: to avoid depth, keep repeating, 'it's only a movie, it's only a movie'.
