movie_title: Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Does bad reception on the TV set send shivers down your spine? Me neither.
Viewing The Incredibles one night and SpongeBob the next is like spending a weekend in Paris before your visit to Fallujah.
Christmas with the Kranks finds a comfortable balance between hilarious and heartwarming. It's the best of both worlds and a pleasant surprise to find under the cineplex tree.
Rookie director David S. Goyer has driven a wooden stake into the heart of this bloodsucker franchise.
By the film's finale you'll pity any poor fool who actually is named Focker -- for following this picture they're certain to see a surge in mockery.
Tension, teamwork and a lust for life fuel this admirable remake of the popular 1965 Jimmy Stewart film.
A cinematic slam-dunk.
This pallid follow-up to 2002's most frightening film plays like an auction for abandoned horror-flick props and icons.
Oh bother!
It's doggie vs. baby vs. daddy vs. deity in a sequel so cartoonish it makes Who Framed Roger Rabbit (1988) look like a dry documentary.
Fans of the horror/fantasy genre will find plenty to applaud, and DC executives can finally breathe a sigh of relief -- even if that's not so easy for John Constantine.
Transgressions can be overlooked thanks to cast members so cool they make the title feel like a mantra.
In a movie season that has Vin Diesel changing diapers and The Rock singing show tunes, it's nice to have Willis back in action.
Barbershop has been given a cinematic sex-change operation.
Foxx so admirably immerses himself in the role that (with all due respect) Charles himself could not have done a better job.
Hawke and Fishburne are an excellent odd couple, with the former's honorable cop balancing the latter's confident bad boy.
Yuletide cheer gets a kick in the shins with this funny but forced cinematic Christmas present.
This family-friendly film is not unlike Garfield himself -- cute and charming at times, but more often lazy and self-serving.
Ladder 49 overkills on melodrama -- the slow-paced adventure flick has enough tear-jerking Hallmark moments to extinguish a three-alarm blaze.
Even Yankees fans can catch the year's best romantic comedy -- if they set aside their Sox disgust for two short hours.
Although Raising Helen boasts a charming cast with a cute factor that's off the cinematic Richter scale, typical Hollywood predictability rears its ugly head too often.
It would have been more apropos had the filmmakers titled this confusing sci-fi epic 'The Chronicles of Ridiculous.'
This is the most honest and entertaining comic book film ever made.
Although the lulled pacing of Two Brothers could put an insomniac in slumber land, the film's leading felines are more captivating than most high-paid Hollywood stars.
Dodgeball ducks most filmmaking no-nos and manages to serve up a light-hearted treat.
Anchorman is packed with genuine laughs and a plethora of pleasant cameos
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Raise Your Voice is like a Hallmark movie of the week produced by an MTV intern.
Only several charismatic actors and fleeting moments of genuine romance survive this modern thrashing of the age-old fairy tale.
Newcomer Corbet is forced to carry the film, a daunting prospect for even the most magnetic young performers.
Big-screen advertisement for Palm Pilots and romantic paranoia.
It's like The Goonies on acid.
Cellular is the year's first feel-good thriller.
Outfoxed is a must-see for any Fox News aficionado interested in understanding what occurs behind the curtain.
movie_title: Outfoxed: Rupert Murdoch's War on Journalism (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A lack of laughs places this ESPN-infused Bernie Mac vehicle in the already overstuffed bin of forgettable sports comedies.
By going over the top on horror and below the belt on humor, this clever British import hits an uproarious cinematic chord.
Seeing this samurai brave the challenges of childrearing and twilight duels is truly an honor.
The snore-inducing lack of real thrills and a storyline that seriously strains believability make Amityville harder to watch than it is to pronounce.
A political and symbolic thinking person's action movie.
This is bad horror at its best: hokey, predictable and completely unrealistic.
Destined to become a babysitter's top tot-tempering tool.
Newell snags Cuarón's cinematic baton and sprints, maintaining the dark tone of Azkaban while sprinkling in healthy doses of humor and humanity.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: With fine performers and decent dialogue creating a concrete foundation, it's a shame inane smacks and slaps ultimately make for a rickety flick.
If The Lord of the Rings is a shot of whiskey, then The Chronicles of Narnia is a glass of milk.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Director Peter Jackson carries King Kong to new heights.
The Bonnie and Clyde formula gets a healthy dose of laughing gas with this hilarious and apropos slice of social commentary.
Viewers eager to embrace 90 minutes of footage featuring women being brutalized, beaten, stalked and slaughtered may want to consider some serious introspection.
A visual masterpiece.
In a day and age that has violent slasher flicks gobbling up movie-goers' box-office bucks, it's refreshing to see a film that stresses cooperation, effort and racial equality over shock value.
Fans curious about George should explore the inquisitive simian's literary exploits rather than this big-screen banana.
Crooked cops, sketchy crooks and Bruce Willis as a washed-up detective -- this one has seen-it-before down to a science.
Unflinching gorefest packed with brutal visuals and buckets of bloodshed.
Expect big box-office numbers and a merchandising blitz from Van Helsing -- just don't expect a story or any semblance of logic.
Fans fired up by the first Ice Age won't be cooled down with this fun-loving follow-up.
Cruise reminds us what he does best, and it has nothing to do with TomKat or Scientology.
Chiwetel Ejiofor dishes out another magnetic performance despite a storyline that wavers from innovative to obvious.
The film comes across like a recruiting commercial with subliminal 'Join the Navy' messages layered throughout.
Supported by the thespian charms of Sir Michael Caine and the visionary direction of Gore Verbinski, Cage and crew deliver a soulful snippet of self-discovery.
Doom may not be a sure-fire hit, but it's certain to satisfy its target audience.
Quote not available.
Kicking & Screaming is a worthwhile family film in a season full of Sin. But this one scores on an error.
Quote not available.
The trailers for this emotionally charged skateboarding picture are more misleading than a politician's pre-election promises.
Despite a charismatic turn by Heather Locklear and comic relief from Carson Kressley, The Perfect Man is far from the perfect movie.
Despite being too bloody for its own good, Land is a different breed of walking-dead movie -- one with soul.
Any responsible person should be wary of a vehicle that accelerates on its own, winks with its headlights and sprays hot oil at hostile onlookers.
War is a blast.
(Chiklis and Evans) play the roles as though they had read the Fantastic Four their entire lives.
Viewers will be contemplating the commentary on life, death and humanity -- after they pop Advils for their pounding headaches.
The blueprints for Stealth called for long-forgotten spare parts, and the end result will likely cause a box-office crash.
Four Brothers begins with four-star potential, but director John Singleton's latest bullet ballet quickly degrades from taut family drama to sloppy action overdose.
Big salute to rookie director Judd Apatow and funnyman Steve Carell for reinvigorating the R-rated comedy.
One plot twist provides a creative respite from the rehash barrage, but this Cave is better explored on DVD.
Statham has truly stepped up to fill the shoes once worn by Jean-Claude Van Damme, Steven Seagal and, yes, even the legendary Bruce Lee.
There are only a few genuine laughs in The Man, separated by long moments of pondering the many ways you could have spent your 90 minutes and nine bucks.
This is a political, thinking person's film, not the action-comedy previews might suggest.
From start to finish, Curse is a blessing.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The pace is so slow that die-hard fans will be using their towels for pillows.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Saturday Night Live scribe Tina Fey can officially pat herself on the back.
Amanda Bynes lights up the screen with innocent charm and a sweet-girl smile.
More daring than Risky Business and sweeter than American Pie.
The filmmakers may have been a bit too empathetic with Daredevil's disability, as it feels they made the movie with one blind eye.
Anne Rice goes heavy metal in Hollywood's latest installment of bloodsucker cinema.
Fans of the Kevin Bacon action-comedy Tremors (1989) will feel right at home.
Fine performances from Diggs and Lathan give life to an otherwise rehashed love story, but musician Mos Def steals the show.
Small-town goofballs, bizarre musical numbers and plenty of toilet humor -- ah, the holidays are here again.
The quirky comedic timing of skater-turned-thespian Jason Lee helps resuscitate a screenplay choking on its own predictability and awkwardly odd scenarios.
Whoever let the dogs out should probably consider a career change.
The Santa Clause 2 is chock full of heartwarming holiday cheer.
In a film season dominated by male-oriented action flicks, 8 Women provides the feminine charm and sophistication to soothe the film-loving connoisseur in all of us.
Endearing moments battle with forced melodrama to produce a muddled family portrait both tiresome and tender.
Fans of The Rock should see this for his abundance of charisma, but fans of quality filmmaking should skip it for its lack of anything else.
Too little Griffin and too much toilet humor equals too bad for The New Guy.
Chan's ballet-like martial arts moves don't disappoint, and his nice-guy, fun-loving attitude is highly contagious.
Save a place at the cemetery for this film.
Interesting characters and witty dialogue are overshadowed by predictable gore and an overblown climax.
Add another martial-arts flick to the growing list of Matrix wannabes.
Leaves more loose ends than a family of octopi.
Typical thriller material detracts from a touching father-son bonding story.
Half Past Dead translated from Latin means 'Die Hard in a prison,' or so the filmmakers must have believed.
Parents may find themselves growing tired of the immature undertone, but the charismatic odd couple of O'Connell and Anderson is enough to emphasize the film's light-hearted feel.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
City of Ghosts dons a facade of independent filmmaking, but the core screams Hollywood rehash.
Director Barry Sonnenfeld unites an incredibly unique and charismatic ensemble cast for this witty adaptation of Dave Barry's 1998 novel.
Hope, desperation and the ugliness of ethnic cleansing intersect elegantly in director Elie Chouraqui's intense retelling of the 1991 Croatian-Serbian conflict in Yugoslavia.
Chock full of true-to-life dialogue and inspirational insight, Adaptation is an ode to the frustrated artist in all of us.
Abnormal amounts of blood, bullets and wanton bodily functions could put the ill on some unsuspecting viewers.
Billed as a family film, only very young children will be able to dive into the story without banging their heads.
Wanton gunfire and witless good guys saturate this sadly scripted waste of hard-earned movie money.
Mariah Carey should have taken an acting class from Marky Mark Wahlberg. The first lesson: start small.

Despite the impressive cast and surplus of extraordinary vehicles, the film loses air after the first half, and rookie director Reggie Rock Bythewood can't seem to escape from a music-video mentality.
Call it Armageddon inside out.
Irritating sound effects, cheap scare tactics and a comically bad script all add up to the year's first senseless cinematic attack on the senses.
Clip off a little rehashed material here, trim a few unneeded characters there, and what you have left is sheer entertainment.
Thought-provoking undertones meet Disney sensibilities -- a memorable combination.
Will Ferrell and company balance on the beer-swilling, testosterone tightrope twined by such comedic classics as Animal House and Caddyshack.
Director Steven Beck builds his Ghost Ship with borrowed materials from all across the cinematic sea.
The characters are comical and dynamic -- especially Jimmy, Carl and Sheen -- and the outer space scenes are no less than stellar.
Although the character's methods may not be admirable, Jane's execution is perfect.
This debut feature from Swedish director Jonas Akerlund takes the audience on a wild ride with such squirmy authenticity that it leaves you feeling in need of a long shower.
One clever concept, several witty comedians, and many commonplace scenarios means Serving Sara will be served more at Blockbuster than at the multiplexes.
Best way to ensure a film isn't taken too seriously? Cast Leslie Nielsen of Naked Gun fame as president of the United States. That'll do the trick.
Will Ferrell's uninhibited physical comedy ignites this fish-out-of-water family film.
Much of the movie magic fades during the stilted cartoon-human relations.
Only Hollywood could turn a straightforward children's book into a frantic feature film.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Bad Santa is the best adult comedy since There's Something About Mary.
It may not make the Oscar cut, but nine bucks is a small price to pay for tradition and a charismatic Cruise.
The African-American film community deserves better than a mediocre comedy pulled from the cinematic icebox.
First-time director Casey La Scala may have taken his fledgling film's title too literally, grinding together borrowed ingredients like a mischievous chef.
This latest incarnation of the J. M. Barrie play is an uplifting cinematic fairytale along the lines of Labyrinth and The Neverending Story.
For teenage girls anxious to learn about love through rose-colored glasses, look no further.
Funky good vibes permeate this soulful follow-up to Ice Cube's 2002 surprise success.
The longtime martial-arts enthusiast in me was officially disturbed by Muniz's phony kung-fu and silly stunt kicks.
Dawn rises past 28 Days Later as the new millennium's best flesh-eating flick.
A handful of juvenile jokes and overblown computer effects push Doo 2 into strictly kid-cinema territory.
Put a fork in Disney's 2-D animation empire -- it's officially overcooked.
Writer/director Guillermo del Toro puts too much effort on image and not enough on background.
Wait to rent this mixed-bag family film -- it's much cheaper.
Overall, Underworld is a cinematic treat you can really sink your teeth into.
Faults lie in not fully explaining the creature's origin or true motivations.
The Rock is the action star of the new millennium, and his charismatic presence in The Rundown solidifies that.
In a summer wrought with action adventures and dramatic epics, it's a refreshing change to trust in the teachings and maturity of a 15-year-old.
It's thrilling to see what a talented director can do with the humorous and horrifying imagination of literary legend Stephen King.
The chemistry between Smith and Jones is among the best of cinematic comedy duos, and the aliens are quirky and often hilarious.
Peregrym lands on her feet, even if the movie doesn't.
British actor Jason Statham injects The Transporter with a healthy dose of clout, charisma and kickboxing skill.

Solid direction by F. Gary Gray, a scintillating cast of supporting players and plenty of screen time for everyone's favorite little engine that could -- the MINI Cooper -- all push The Italian Job above and beyond typical remake requirements.
Rugrats Go Wild! is an interesting experiment in character cooperation, but plays out like an extended television episode rather than a well-thought-out feature.
Despite pacing that lulls in a lengthy second half and a visually overwhelming climax, the Hulk is, quite simply, incredible.
The term eye candy has never felt more apropos.
Terminator 3 breaks the third-strike mold thanks to a pair of talented young actors, high-octane action sequences and an aging Austrian who can still hold his own.
Spooky, atmospheric direction and a colorful turn by Depp clash with the dumbed-down storyline and veritable booty of pirate cliches.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It seems as though the effects team was often sleeping on the job.
Bad Boys II struggles with striking a balance between the rib-tickling humor and gut-wrenching gore, the hah and ick mixing like oil and vinegar.
Welcome to the epitome of taking a fresh idea too far.
The so-so summer movie syndrome continues with this poorly written but finely cast action-thriller based on yet another long-buried television series.
The unfortunate feeling of untapped potential is ultimately what lingers.
Amateurish effects, frenetic camerawork and ridiculous villains prevent Chan's Medallion from emanating true cinematic shine.
Slick choreography and a confident performance by Orlando Jones keep this tale from beating to the tune of the same old drum.
The definition of dumb Luck has been captured on celluloid.
Eager dog owners may find themselves hounding for a husky after nibbling on this cinematic treat.
Akin to an unhealthy relationship, this self-described 'anti-romantic comedy' begins hot and heavy before buckling beneath the weight of pointless conflicts and ridiculous game-playing.

Hereafter is deep and deliberate. It requires patience and emotional maturity from its audience. Those willing to give it will be rewarded with a cinematic experience that is complex, heartfelt and spiritually uplifting.
Yates, Radcliffe and the rest of the Potter posse are giving fans exactly what they deserve -- a powerful denouement worthy of a boy wizard who has charmed the world for more than a dozen years.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Ben Affleck has matured as an actor and serves up what is arguably his best performance to date.
Long hair hasn't been this much fun since Woodstock.
Legacy is sort of a one-trick pony. After you get past the neon-glow costumes, whizzing Frisbee weapons and cyberspace backdrop, there really isn't much to get excited about.
A weak script and a fumbled climax seriously deflate what could have been an explosive thriller.
Excellent production values (especially costume design) couple with standout performances from Jeff Bridges and Matt Damon for a terrific cinematic escape.
There's a lot to "Like" about The Social Network.
The Hangover meets Back to the Future in this hilarious and unapologetically adult buddy chuckler.
In Taken viewers are introduced to a new side of Irish actor Liam Neeson, one that is relentless and likes to hit criminals in the throat -- a lot.
Executive producer Elton John's indelible stamp is all over this colorful family film.
Although I Am Number Four boasts some impressive visual effects and plenty of fast-paced action, the silly plot and teen-angst undertones make the film feel like "X-Files" for high-schoolers.
Although the film's crude humor isn't ideal for a school assembly or church social, it is undeniably effective.
The unfortunate combination of a hackneyed script and inexperienced acting makes the film feel like the big-budget version of a bad high-school play.

Paul is aimed primarily at comic-book fans and cosmos-loving adults who aren't easily offended. But the phenomenal cast, funny script and solid pacing help make Paul a stellar cinematic excursion for even the most down-to-earth humans.
The problem with Arthur is far more about concept than execution.
Director Sam Raimi returns to his Evil Dead roots for this tongue-in-cheek gorefest -- one part spooky chiller, one part campy chuckler.
Despite a relatively predictable plot and inconsistent pacing, The Switch scores thanks to a good balance of humor and heart.
Audacious director Edgar Wright (Shaun of the Dead) throws a jolt of energy into the summer movie season with this imaginative and entertaining romp.
The movie is almost hypnotic -- a mind-bending experience laced with palpable tension and fueled with drama. Sweet dreams.
Director McG fuels Terminator Salvation with exceptional visual effects and sharp sound, but more shouting and explosions than a Super Bowl in Beirut.
A thrilling, heartfelt and humorous family film with enough jubilant energy to lift you right off your seat.
Who knew a Hangover could be so much fun?
Although The Proposal isn't a sweep-you-off-your-feet affair, Bullock and Reynolds make it a thoroughly charming engagement.
Although Dickens has been translated time and time again, this animated adventure is no humbug.
An Oscar-caliber cast and dazzling visual effects can't rescue this formulaic disaster flick from a script flooded with generic dialogue and preposterous plot points.
Inspiring messages about equality, forgiveness and understanding resonate thanks to Clint Eastwood's deft hand and standout performances by Morgan Freeman and Matt Damon.
Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's legendary sleuth gets a cinematic adrenaline shot for this wildly entertaining and action-packed mystery.
Edge is a gripping thriller reminiscent of Martin Scorsese's Oscar-winning The Departed, and Mel Gibson serves up a ferocious performance.
With a cast that reads like the Vogue Oscar party guest list, Valentine's Day should have been can't-miss cinema instead of standard Hollywood schmaltz.
The latest R-rated comedy from director Kevin Smith (Clerks) is immature and sloppy. Fortunately, the movie is also pretty darn funny.
This chaotic action flick features a terrific cast but a script so cliched that filmgoers who shell out 10 bucks to see it may feel like the title is directed at them.
Road-tripping romance that features a talented cast and gorgeous locales but an overly sappy plot and nap-inducing pace.
Although the Disney flick suffers from a silly plot and one-dimensional characters, it avoids the cinematic purgatory most video game adaptations tumble into.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Pixar's storytelling masterminds serve up yet another exceptional film packed with humor, imagination, adventure and emotional resonance.
Compelling plot and character development get lost somewhere between explosion No. 1 and explosion No. 78, but the film certainly satisfies the popcorn quotient for summer cinema.
Tom Cruise is not the failsafe, bankable actor he once was. But his performance here reminds us of what made him a star in the first place.

Perhaps the biggest problem with Prom is that there is nothing special about it. Everything feels familiar and rehashed, like eating leftovers that have lingered in the fridge and been picked at for days.
Hugh Jackman and Liev Schreiber are so well-cast and are so sharp in their roles that extraneous missteps almost feel excusable.
Think of it as a cinematic bouquet -- catch it.
Green Lantern is reminiscent of 2008's The Incredible Hulk, another superhero flick that boasted a strong cast but went overboard on visual stimuli.
The strong cast and topical plot help make for a hilarious first hour.
Slogging through the first 75 minutes of Trouble with the Curve is akin to watching a scoreless baseball game that doesn't get exciting until the ninth inning.
Looper is a thoughtful genre-bender that brings science-fiction, action and mystery together in one tight package.

Some films make you weep; others make you squirm. Then there are those that simply make you smile. Pitch Perfect falls into the third category thanks to its strong script, charming cast and catchy soundtrack.
A goofy sci-fi film dubbed Argo never got made in 1980. Fortunately for moviegoers, a brilliant, Oscar-worthy drama/thriller of the same name did get made in 2012.
Fantasy fans hungry for a second breakfast of Tolkien-fueled fare can get their fill with this visually sumptuous feast.
The title itself should deter viewers who favor smart cinema over mindless mayhem.

One of Marvel Comics' popular titles in the 1980s was 'The Spectacular Spider-Man,' and that adjective describes this film. Both familiar and fresh, it's a spectacle with enough thrills and humor to satisfy most fans.
Director Bryan Singer, of The Usual Suspects and X-Men fame, infuses the film with just the right balance of action, romance and goofy fun.
Despite a somewhat slow start and occasional plot missteps, Iron Man 3 ultimately soars thanks to its charismatic leading man and director Shane Black's man-on-wire balancing act of humor and action.
After Earth is the sort of picture the Mystery Science Theater 3000 gang would salivate over.
DC still has much to learn from rival Marvel in the filmmaking realm, but Man of Steel at least offers hope. Hope, and a slight headache
Guillermo del Toro infuses this monstrous undertaking with just what it needs -- a little heart.
This unlikely teaming of Jason Statham and James Franco proves to be a clever blend of action and acting.

Smaug ignites the excitement missing from Jackson's sluggish first Hobbit flick, and the stunning visuals -- cinematography, costuming, set design, effects -- set it apart as one of the most impressive fantasy films ever made.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: While fun in a harmless, artificial sort of way -- like Pop Rocks or costume jewelry -- White House Down is little more than Die Hard at 1600 Pennsylvania Ave.
Wonderstone is an enticing concept but lacks the laughs to back up its potential.
Solid writing and strong performances by leads Chris Pine and Elizabeth Banks propel People Like Us from a maudlin drama to a memorable one.
There is a surprising beauty to Brave that transcends its visual excellence. This one is worth the risk.
Tom Cruise's magnetic performance almost makes the movie worth the price of admission. Almost.
A colorful charmer that proves Disney/Pixar is not the only animation powerhouse.
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2 caps the series with visual panache and emotional punch. It's a fitting finale to an unparalleled cinematic accomplishment.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Daniel Craig and Harrison Ford make a terrific, no-nonsense tandem, but there is a certain absurdity to the whole affair that makes the picture seem a bit small in scope.
Contagion offers a healthy dose of smart filmmaking while most of Hollywood is serving up cinematic placebos.

The unlikely tandem of Brad Pitt and Jonah Hill helps drive what is arguably the most compelling and insightful baseball-themed film since Robert Redford launched a homerun into the stadium lights in The Natural.
Strong production values and another charismatic performance by triple-threat talent Hugh Jackman help keep this heavy-metal offspring of Rocky and Transformers out of the cinematic junk heap.
Watching J. Edgar reminded this critic of sitting in a dimly lit history class after tossing back a tablespoon of NyQuil.
Director Martin Scorsese's well-documented affection for all things cinema has never been more evident than in the enchanting and imaginative Hugo.
Shadows is like the cinematic equivalent to a bowl of Frosted Mini-Wheats -- the adult in me likes the thought-provoking mystery, but the kid in me likes seeing Sherlock kick a thug in the sternum.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Expect War Horse, one of the year's best, to earn some accolades at the Academy Awards in February. Oscar always pays attention when Spielberg is in the saddle.
The movie bombards viewers with a host of scare tactics, from barely startling to borderline terrifying. And therein lies the problem.
If the Adam Sandler/Drew Barrymore chuckler 50 First Dates had been recast as a romantic drama and produced by the Oprah Winfrey Network, The Vow might have been the result.
Fortunately for viewers, the film is directed by Pixar sensation Andrew Stanton (Finding Nemo, WALL-E), and the visual effects are, literally, out of this world.
While Wrath of the Titans may not be escapist fantasy entertainment at its finest, the film's strong cast and striking visuals make for a thrilling theatrical ride.
Adjectives used in some of Marvel Comics' iconic titles from the early 1960s through today -- amazing, fantastic, incredible -- also describe director Joss Whedon's superhero epic The Avengers.
Dark Shadows isn't an abomination, but it falls well short of the high expectations viewers anticipate from two of the industry's top talents.
An eclectic cast and stellar visual effects coalesce to make Men in Black 3 a quintessential kernel of summer popcorn cinema.
Just when you thought a Disney theme-park ride couldn't possibly spawn four feature-length films, here we go again.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This film is for those so buried in gadgets and The Gap that the Earth, at its roots, has become something foreign.
Horrible Bosses follows the precedent set by such earlier crime-gone-awry comedies as Ruthless People (1986), Throw Momma from the Train (1987) and Bottle Rocket (1996) with gut-busting gusto.
Rich with vibrant color, visceral action and dynamic characters, Zack Snyder's ambitious adaptation of the acclaimed graphic novel is a visual and psychological feast.
Denzel Washington infuses this sci-fi thriller with humanity and realism, despite a plot that would befuddle even the creator of Star Trek.
The pacing is so slow and the religious undertones so heavy that only Jesus himself could rise above the draining weight.
Bridget Jones's Diary meets L.A. Story in this feel-good romantic chuckler doused with a healthy layer of seasonal schmaltz.
Despite some juvenile humor and a red-carpet vocal cast, this Web is spun with emotional resonance that sticks.
This fascinating portrait of the future is one of the best-directed films of the year.
Director Tom Tykwer's creative style of storytelling makes Perfume a compelling view, but a depraved protagonist and distasteful plot give the film an overall foul odor.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: When Justin Timberlake is the best thing about a film, you know you're in trouble.
This unflinching expose into the dark underbelly of the All-American burger is a thought-provoking cinematic meal.
Ultimately, even a vivacious Diane Keaton can't make a familiar film feel fresh -- no matter how hard she tries.
Powerhouse performances by Chris Cooper and Laura Linney highlight this taut political thriller.
Like a poorly designed house of cards, 23 tumbles when it becomes apparent that the weak premise sports an even weaker plot. Tack another disaster on to Schumacher's cinematic belt.
Zack Snyder adapts Frank Miller's sparse graphic novel about the Battle of Thermopylae with the same devoted verve that Robert Rodriguez brought to Sin City.
Terrence Howard is a rare and phenomenally gifted actor with the ability to dip into a seemingly endless well of raw emotion.
Although Will Ferrell does supply most of the film's intermittent laughs, the ridiculous concept and poor execution put "Blades" at the bottom of Ferrell's otherwise winning resume.
Fans of the riveting 2003 film Shattered Glass now have a powerful bookend to emphasize the dangers of escalating deception.
Rear Window gets a facelift for the iPod generation.
Eddie Murphy's finest example of multi-role playing is still his first, 1988's Coming to America. Compared to that comedic gem, Norbit is little more than excess weight.
When a deck of cards trumps plot and character development, the film is bound to fold.
One of the most outright enjoyable films of the year -- an imaginative and entertaining ride from the very first flush.
Flags offers an interesting history lesson into the Battle of Iwo Jima and the origin of wartime America's most inspirational photograph, but the massive film lacks emotional resonance.
Make no mistake - Cars is still the best animated film this year. But with Pixar behind the wheel, the film should have cruised to must-see status. Instead, it stalls.

Although the film itself gets trapped in a headlock of steady stupidity (think fart jokes and juvenile slapstick), funnyman Jack Black delivers a riotous performance that helps viewers embrace the silly fun.
Fans of Sandler shouldn't skip past this surprising treat, a soulful and silly comedy with plenty to pause and appreciate.

Although Singer's take on Superman is slightly reminiscent of Peter Jackson's remake of King Kong - epic, breathtaking and a bit over-indulgent - Returns is a welcome addition to the cinematic superhero library.
A Scanner Darkly is well worth viewing solely because films this unusual are rare in our Hollywood-infused world of pirates and popcorn.
The actors each do their part to rev up the silly fun, whether it's Reilly's goofy 'shake and bake' slogan, Cohen's absurd French accent or Ferrell's graceless physicality
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Tucker is strictly for the teen crowd, but the intermittent waves of witty fun are to die for.
This futuristic faux documentary about the assassination of George W. Bush paints the president as a noble hero along the lines of Abraham Lincoln.
Stone paints a grim and claustrophobic picture of the men's nightmarish confines, but beautifully captures their bond and passion to survive.
The Rock no longer exists. Dwayne Johnson has finally shed the identity that turned him into a wrestling legend and earned the right to go by his real name.
Had Top Gun been directed by a curator at the Smithsonian Museum, Flyboys would have been the outcome.
Li fans will appreciate the excellent choreography and Li's calm confidence, but Fearless lacks the imagination necessary for a must-see experience.
movie_title: Jet Li's Fearless (Huo Yuan Jia) (Legend of a Fighter) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It feels like the filmmakers put Old School and Napoleon Dynamite into a cinematic blender and hit frappe in hopes of making a delicious shake. They ended up with a tasteless one.
With the help of slick writing, an A-list cast and plenty of twisted surprises, Scorsese scores again.
Cook serves up some tasty laughs but Employee of the Month feels processed.

Robin Williams and Barry Levinson evoke memories of their 1987 collaboration Good Morning, Vietnam with this insightful political dramedy. But those expecting a light-hearted farce will be sorely disappointed.
The writing is unimaginative -- Tech says 'snap' more often than that elf from the cereal commercials.
Welcome back, Costner. The hit-or-miss actor who earned an Oscar for Dances with Wolves but a Razzie for The Postman shatters expectations with his best performance in more than a decade.
The ornery ogre brought to life by Mike Myers and DreamWorks in 2001 returns to the screen for his third outing, a fast-paced fantasy rife with witty humor and colorful characters.
Rise is exactly what a superhero movie should be: an entertaining, family-friendly popcorn flick with even doses of humor, heroism and heart.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Fans of Keanue Reeves and Forest Whitaker will appreciate Reeves' heavy screen time and Whitaker's performance, but both actors deserve material that doesn't leave the viewer queasy and in need of a long shower.
Seeing Jackie Chan and Jet Li in fist-frenzied combat feels like the kung-fu equivalent of watching Fred Astaire cut the rug with Ginger Rogers.
SNL alumni Tina Fey, Steve Martin, and current mainstay Amy Poehler, all shine in this infectious chuckler.

Doubters with their tales of suspense about whether or not Iron Man will fly as a franchise can finally calm down -- and Batman and Spider-Man fans can start to get edgy about sharing the cinematic spotlight.
The Wachowski Brothers' big-screen, big-budget adaptation of the popular Speed Racer anime series is like the Willy Wonka of racing movies.
Fans furious with Ang Lee's artsy 2003 flick about Marvel's green behemoth can finally breathe a sigh of relief.
Simultaneously groundbreaking and breathtaking, Wanted is more than just one of the best films of 2008 -- it's one of the best action movies ever made.
Plot, dialogue and acting are buried beneath a visual barrage that may stimulate children but dizzy adults.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Revenge of the Nerds gets a feminine twist in this entertaining and uplifting chuckler.
Ghost Town is a fantasy charmer, from its tight cast and excellent soundtrack to its complex characters and soulful climax.

Both complicated and compelling, Body of Lies offers an audacious glimpse at the hypocrisy and religious furor fueling a struggle most Americans recognize only as a political catch phrase -- a 'war on terror.'
Here are six words that would probably get me tarred and feathered at a comic-book convention: I am sick of Star Wars.
I Am Legend is far from a feel-good film; it's a familiar (for fans of Stephen King's The Stand or Heston's Omega Man) post-apocalyptic adventure rife with chills and hopelessness.
Defiance is an extraordinary story and the production is admirable -- if you have the time and patience to trudge through.
Bolt is fast-paced, funny and beautifully animated -- a charming movie that would have Benji and Lassie howling in jealousy.
The tension that builds throughout Valkyrie is palpable and the plot is incredibly compelling.
Confessions is more cautionary tale than comedy.
Hollywood's latest attempt to capitalize on penguin appreciation features a forgettable plot, fountains of toilet humor and enough surfing scenarios to make a viewer seasick.
The screenwriters capably update the 49-year-old critters for socially relevant times, give or take a little suspension of disbelief.
Following three theatrical bombs, British actor Jason Statham hits pay dirt with this compelling picture about the famed 1971 Baker Street bank robbery in London.
Spiderwick is The Neverending Story of the new millennium -- a family-friendly fable that kids will applaud but adults may nap through.
The movie comes across as Sunday school meets Greenpeace meets Ace Ventura -- laughter, religion and environmentalism make strange bedfellows.
Bruce Willis is back in action to remind moviegoers that spandex-clad superheroes and swashbuckling pirates are no more heroic than a hardened cop.
As a fan of the 1980s Saturday morning cartoon and Hasbro toys the film is based on, I was saddened to see characters I grew up with transformed into a corporate ad tool.
Harry's cinematic leap to manhood is not unlike the wizard himself -- spellbinding.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Although 1408 lacks the dramatic power of either Misery or The Shining, John Cusack's riveting performance rivals that of James Caan and Jack Nicholson.

Despite some hearty humor from Adam Sandler, co-star Kevin James and a handful of well-cast character actors, the film's contrived plot and discriminatory jabs ultimately make Chuck and Larry a tactless engagement.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Penelope wiggles its way past a quirky premise with the help of a terrific supporting cast and underlying messages about self-esteem, independence and inner beauty.
The latest cinematic space invaders tale is more of a commentary on modern America than a sci-fi screamer.
Dwayne Johnson shines alongside rising star AnnaSophia Robb, but the film's cookie-cutter plot and adolescent script make Witch Mountain hardly worth racing to.
The term 'suspending disbelief' hasn't been this apropos since Democrats watched President Bush take the oath of office.
Despite a distracting hairdo, Nicolas Cage delivers a solid performance in this fast-paced actioner.
Although Feast is sometimes depressing, a natural side effect when touching on issues such as infidelity and death, it is also uplifting and tender.
Although the edgy humor provides plenty of side-splitting moments, Heartbreak ultimately cracks beneath a lackluster storyline.
Infused with rich writing, strong performances and symbolic undertones, Darjeeling explores how people behave when living in the moment but out of the comfort zone.
An arresting political expose punctuated by stellar acting and resonant messages about leadership, sacrifice and responsibility.
The 3-D film isn't just a movie, it's a movie experience that makes you a part of its noble, frightening and fantasy-infused world.
Ghost gets a romantic-comedy redo with this strained love-triangle tale.
The 11th Hour presents its argument clearly: Disregarding the planetary repercussions of human behavior, or rather misbehavior, holds tragic consequences.
This is the kind of movie runners watch together (multiple times), wish they could make and discuss in vans during long relays, keeping the mythos of Caballo Blanco alive.
movie_title: Run Free: The True Story Of Caballo Blanco (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Controversy aside, you don't get Millar-level recognition without some decent storytelling. Kick-Ass 2 has that, especially in Hit-Girl.
Every moment of Last Night is engrossing and will remain with you long after the final credits roll.
It's nice to know Scorsese's back on the mean streets.
For nearly three overwrought hours, Beloved drags at a draining pace, intermittently introducing unfulfilled story arcs and false climaxes.
A slice of life drama that, like the characters it portrays, plods along at its own pace. All the while engaging the viewer.
It's brilliance is to put you in the moment, some of the greatest moments in modern sports history.
For the most part, The Wolverine succeeds at being an improvement over the last solo outing for the clawed superhero. But it's not much better.

If you are intrigued by the interpersonal relationships and entanglements of a family - maybe a lot like yours and mine - this film is a fascinating exposé that might well prompt some seasonal self-reflection.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Body and Soul is a film not simply with gritty boxing scenes but also a fascinating character analysis indicative of the human condition.
A Hard Day's Night perfectly encapsulates the rash of Beatlemania that was exploding onto the world stage and making its way across the pond to America.
Pickpocket is an intricately staged, truly intimate character study from the imitable Robert Bresson instantly solidifying itself as one of his greatest works.
The Fallen Idol is a fascinating film for how it manages to develop inner turmoil and for its earnest interest in the perspective of a child.
With Limelight, for one last, brief moment, it's like old times even as the new age begins and Chaplin relinquishes his crown to the younger generations.
That Man In Rio has faults but that does not mean for a moment we cannot still get something out of it, even if it's, at the very least, some unadulterated thrills.
If this moralistic apologue appears a tad too simplistic, at least the pictures are pretty.
This is a film of such consistent, determined frivolity that the high spirits soon become wearying.
There are also moments when Coffee Bloom's characters access deep reserves of hurt and despair, which is when the film's bruised, beating heart is laid bare.
It's been a while since Khan did anything that involved the switching on of one personality, let alone two. Fan is a welcome correction.
Independence Day: Resurgence is so contrived and slow-witted a sequel that it's making me reassess my fondness for the 1996 film.
As unpleasant as it is gleefully amoral and perversely enjoyable.

It struck me... that the fireflies of the title could refer to the faint glimmer of hope most of these miners have of making enough money to be able to quit the trade. Yet, for the most part, the film gazes into the abyss.
What drove me to distraction, however, was the constant, aggressive stupidity -- the feeling that no gag was too ridiculous, no double entendre too tawdry, to merit inclusion.
Ultimately, one is left wondering what a genuinely gritty gangster film starring Rajinikanth -- who can still smirk with the best of them -- would have looked like.
It's fascinating to see how the diverse acting styles of the leads meld or clash with each other throughout the film... And there's another performance going on in the background. It's Punjab.
Not since Goodfellas has a Hollywood film had such a high song-per-scene ratio, but at least there was a thematic unity to the tracks in that film. This one just careens all over the place.

Keaton, Tucci and McAdams are all compelling, but I found myself looking forward to the moments when Schreiber would appear on screen. His Marty Baron is careful, undemonstrative, steadfast and vital: the ideal editor.
From an actor who isn't known for putting himself out there emotionally, this is unexpected stuff.
The past few weeks have provided more than a few reasons as to why there's little explicitly political film-making in India. That's good enough reason to catch the ones that break through.
Baahubali 2 is undoubtedly a spectacular action film. It's also a tradition-bound, caste-conscious macho militarist fantasy.
The only lessons worth taking from Padmaavat are sartorial, but this thin epic is likely to be parsed for meaning by millions in the coming weeks.

It's nice to walk into an unheralded film and come out keen to recommend it to everyone. Shefali Bhushan's Jugni isn't always smooth or sensible, but its virtues are the sort that are often missing from films more highly rated.

If the current political climate is to give rise to more films about the Emergency - and we could do with several, just as we could films about other tumultuous periods in our history - one would hope they're better art.

Bhansali might be one of the last exponents of the grand old Bollywood style. Melodrama is the air his characters breathe. His songs don't move the story forward; instead, they are invitations to stop, sit back and gawk.

It's not often that one gets the opportunity to sit back and enjoy a Saurabh Shukla performance...Jolly LLB 2 has a busy plot, but the film's real triumph is the wealth of detail that informs the scenes.

If this review seems to fixate on matters of plot, it's only because there isn't much else to write about. Mohit Suri makes a particular type of film, but from moment to moment, scene to scene, he isn't the most imaginative of directors.

This is exactly the sort of no-hope venture that Randeep Hooda seems to land up in again and again, frustrating those who believe that he ought to be a much bigger star and above dross of this sort by now.
There are stupid films, and there are films that flaunt their stupidity. Rohit Shetty is a frequent purveyor of the latter sort.

Fukrey was rooted in the everyday: the comedy seemed to arise naturally from the slackers' surroundings. The sequel, though, has the desperation and unfocussed energy of a work that's not sure why it exists.
Luckily (and unusually for a Hindi film), Hunterrr finds some footing in the second half.
As far as origin stories go, this one's a blast, in no small measure due to Reynolds, who clearly relishes the part, and director Tim Miller, who keeps you entertained and amused throughout.
Pelé's ambition and struggles seem superficial and the resolutions too simple.
There is plenty of drama and suspense in this true-life story, but the screenplay relies too heavily on formula and is swathed in Hollywood sentimentality.
The 5th Wave, which has echoes of Divergent and The Hunger Games, both of which have strong female protagonists, is too obviously just the introductory chapter.
Ten years later, nothing much has changed -- informers and goons still hang out at the same hovels and bad guys are still caricatures.
When the twist ending comes, it is so shoddily executed and so unoriginal that The Boy degrades into a spoof.
This is a by-the-book disaster-rescue saga with elevated moments of drama. The ocean scenes leave you feeling a little bit seasick, but in awe of the bravery of these men.
Credit must go to Cranston for giving this lean film some heft.
A showcase for the towering talents of Blanchett and Mara, Carol is a sumptuous watch.
At almost two-and-a-half hours, in spite of collapsing cities, new characters and a Wolverine cameo, X-Men: Apocalypse offers so little over such a long running time.
The story is full of holes and the narrative leans too often on ballads and 'sad songs' to establish mood.
Director Jon M Chu tries hard to make the sequel lively and more amusing, but the story is more far-fetched and bloated and too dependent on special effects.
Credit to the director for drawing out convincing performances from two youngsters.

Besides one extended exorcism scene, and the painstaking make-up that shows Veer's gradual degradation by the spirit, this is a drab effort with hardly a shock sandwiched between all the frills, frocks and Rajput finery.
The basic thought is noble, but its execution is old-fashioned and the message delivery preachy.
Finding Dory succeeds in transporting us to a wonderful underwater world while enhancing the franchise's emotional core.
This is the story of Tarzan, but it's not. It's fantastical, but not fantastic.
Subhash Kapoor has become an indie voice to watch out for.
movie_title: Phas Gaye Re Obama (With Love to Obama) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The most frightening thing about Phoonk 2 is the possibility of Phoonk 3.
Teen Patti is a gamble that doesn't pay off.
Sappy and corny, The Choice will either make you bawl your eyes out or dull you into a coma.

[The Nice Guys is] propped up by the performances, humour, action, '70s detailing, a soundtrack with retro tracks (by Kool & The Gang and Earth, Wind & Fire, among others) and a cameo by the dishy Matt Bomer.
The Angry Birds Movie is childish and occasionally cute and capitalises on the game's once addictive popularity.
Chitter-chatter, a chirpy girl, bicker-bicker, weep and hug: Umesh Shukla's All Is Well is littered with talking and histrionics.
Chris Evans, with his pumped-up muscles and thawed-out all-American good looks, adds greatly to making this a satisfying watch.
Kinetic at times, colourful and with scattered humour, The Secret Life Of Pets is a treat for children, but offers no great insights into the secret life of pets.
If you want a laugh, a good time out with friends, and some eye candy, Dostana is for you. If you are looking for a gay movie, this is not the right choice.
Puerile is the first word that comes to mind when describing Golmaal Returns. As a sequel it manages to dive a few notches below the original.
There was surely a good idea in Bangistan at some point but sadly Karan Anshuman's directorial debut takes no risks.
Rogue Nation is a 131-minute roller-coaster ride that slows down long enough for you to catch your breath before jettisoning you into another gasping round of action and adventure.
A heartwarming, fun, smart experience is kneaded into a simple, delightful and insightful story.

This story of a fractured family is high on manipulative cinematic tools but fails to make an emotional connection. What stays with you are the no-holds-barred action sequences and the hummable theme tune.
Nawazuddin Siddiqui takes on the challenging lead role with guns fully loaded.
As fun as it is to watch Streep take on a grungy rocker persona, the novelty wears off pretty quickly. Fortunately, the ensemble cast hits the right notes.
After Body of Lies, Prometheus and Exodus: Gods and Kings, it's good to see Ridley Scott get back some of his lost form in The Martian.
While Olympus Has Fallen was an enjoyable action thriller with Banning single-handedly overpowering the White House infiltrators, London Has Fallen is much harder to swallow.
There's plenty in this family film for children, but it's not wondrous or original enough for any age group.

Crimson Peak is Guillermo del Toro's imagining of the gothic horror movie genre, with unmistakable hat-tips to films such as Alfred Hitchcock's Rebecca resonating in the eerie mansion that serves as the setting for a large chunk of the narrative.
Littered with clichés and rehashed gags, the sequel's strength rests on the impressive art and animation. The simplistic gags might just work with young audiences.

It all comes together nicely as the actors breathe vulnerability, fallibility and personality into their roles, with Daisy Ridley being quite the commanding presence. My favourite, hands down, is the cute and rotund droid BB-8.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Peanuts Movie is charming in parts and high in nostalgia value for generations that virtually befriended characters such as Snoopy, Linus (with his security blanket), Lucy and Pig Pen.
What does stand out is the animation, especially the realistic depiction of flowing rivers, raging storms, placid lagoons, geysers and thermal pools. And the Apatosaurus are cute too.
For the most part, the story sticks to a predictable narrative.
Begins with an interesting premise but does not pack in enough satire into its contrived and predictable screenplay.
Eye in the Sky is a suspenseful and timely, if simplistic, thriller, exploring the new methods of war.

The tension of the competition, usually the staple of sporting films, is sorely missing. You don't get a sense of the rigour of Owens' training and the enormity of his achievement, which is otherwise so well documented.
John Goodman brings his A-game to the part of the tightrope-walking Howard who is at times kind and gentle and at others unhinged and cuckoo. Mary Elizabeth Winstead matches him note for note.
As far as espionage thrillers go, it's a fine watch, elevated greatly by class acts by Hanks and Rylance.
While the animation is topnotch, and there's enough for young audiences, the accompanying adults them might find this course a slog.
Iyer Tiwari creates an authentic world with a universal emotional core.
Bad Moms is a little satirical, a little ironic, a tiny bit feminist and mostly like a high school chick flick set around mothers of two.
Dear Maya is a surprisingly satisfactory watch, mainly for the winsome performances and Bhatnagar's ability to deliver an immersive experience.
Fever will not have you at the edge of the seat but keep you suspended -- in disbelief -- that stories like this get funding and actors agree to work on them.

The casting of an irritating range of characters, and terrible performances by Jackson, Arora and Dheer add to the feeling that you are walking 18 holes in the blazing sun with a heavy golf bag on your shoulder.
Butalia's laborious storytelling punctures the thriller narrative by the mistimed interjection of songs, which are all picturized similarly - a man wandering lost and confused on mountainsides.
Bond is back. Bond is beefy. And the new Bond is blond. Daniel Craig has comfort ably slipped into the tuxedo, size 007, and left audiences shaken and stirred.

I was gasping and willing for the characters to make different choices, to think, to be smarter. But Raman's film is not about the comfortable. It's very much about unearthing and facing the ugly truth, and that's a rather bitter pill.
Although Kumar's film is emotionally wanting, it is technically accomplished and skilfully engaging.
With The Last Jedi, Johnson finds that sweet spot of reverentially seeing out the old to firmly make way for a new, perhaps final, space odyssey.
Half Girlfriend is strictly for fans of the book or the two leads, because at best it's quarter tolerable.

Hindi Medium is obviously playing to the gallery. It makes you laugh, it makes you think, but its one-note characters and black-and-white divisions mean that while it makes the grade, the film is no topper.
There's only so much the actors can do with a script that started off boldly but blinked when it mattered most.
It may be set in the past, but The Post is a timely and urgent tale for the present.

Khan and Kundra put on their most sincere faces and you genuinely believe they want to get out of this situation alive. But it's hard for the audience to keep a straight face as Bhatt's screenplay bumps along from ghostly to ghastly.
There's no point in expecting to find sense in this schmaltzy story.
Oldman has already bagged the Golden Globe for his performance, and it is he who elevates Darkest Hour beyond Wright's stuffy, sluggish and stagy filmmaking into a reflective and passable drama.
There's only so much Fadnavis - who works so hard to deliver a sincere performance - and her two portly leading men, can do to distract us from all the flaws.

Padman is sanitised and sweet, and its message is not just to encourage the use of sanitary pads, but that with the right motivation, imagination and a whole lot of patience you can solve problems with ingenuity.
The blending of innocence and the world of words with modern casualness and the laziness of expression through emojis is what works best for this lighthearted romance.

The special effects, sets, costumes, music and production design are bombastic and overpowering at times. Yet, it's also one of the more well-rounded superhero origin films - with a beginning, middle and open end that efficiently sets itself up.
Del Toro creates a beautifully imagined world, rich in colours and characters, with touches of humour and social commentary.

The message, if there is one, is that sometimes you need a brave man willing to use his fists to fight off bad elements in society. Deepa Bakshi and Dilip Shukla's story provides the basis for the direction and production - musty and hollow.

Pari is technically competent, and Prosit Roy receives production support in plenty. The costumes, hair and make -up, and background music being noteworthy....but themes of good versus evil and love limits this film's appeal to the loyal viewer.
Kaalakaandi is an inconsistent but madcap film, with a couple of terrific performances.
Theoretically, a sequel offers up the opportunity to fix the flaws of part one and strengthen the story. In reality, this is unlikely to happen when your source material was unworthy of a follow up.

Indeed, if there's one remarkable thing about this film, it's that Shivdasani, Deshmukh and Oberoi see merit in reprising their parts as lascivious men driven by under-serviced libidos and invest those roles with such energy and commitment.

As the last scene ends, the following phrase comes up on screen: 'Never take a woman for granted'. A noble sentiment, but in filmmaking one should not take the script, screenplay or craft for granted either.
The result is a fun, feminist reboot that focuses on the actors' strengths and chemistry without ever appearing to provide a forced gender commentary.
Pete's Dragon is perfect family viewing, and it might just want to make you want your own dragon friend.
Inferno is a strained attempt to capitalise on Robert Langdon's popularity and a far cry from the fast-paced and edge-of-the-seat stuff we have come to expect from the Brown-Howard-Hanks combine.
As unimaginative as its title, Office Christmas Party starts strong but declines into nonsense.
When the comedy works, it's because Ranveer Singh knows how to work it. His goofy charm and display or sculpted physique are the two consistent aspects of Bekifre.
The drama builds nicely.
How can a film with a baby in a suit not be cute in parts? But that's all it is -- cute in parts.

While there are tense scenes and earnest storytelling, something seems to have been lost in screenwriter Angela Workman's adaptation of Ackerman's book. The distilled story feels superficial and clichéd.
A film that is large on emotion, drama, and action with a few extravagant battle scenes, some flying ships and SS Rajamouli's flights of fancy.
Gunn's script works overtime to repeat the crazy fun of the first part, but the plot lines in Vol 2 are clumsily manufactured.
The balance between wit, irreverence, philosophy, blockbuster tropes and action is deft, but if only the plot had been more convincing.
You can only surmise that there must have been a fat pay cheque for the Oscar-nominated actor to be a part of something so undercooked and soulless.
Qureshi and Saleem can do little with the limited material and unimaginative direction.
Ideas are too superficially addressed in Jab Harry Met Sejal, a 143-minute tour of Europe, which is 100 minutes too long.
It's ironic that in a film about erectile dysfunction the story should go flaccid in the climax.
Love Games aims to shock, but it's only shockingly bad.
The narrative moves with greater energy and conviction in the post-interval portions. Zubaan is about aspiration, ambition and the dark direction life can take.
Jugni has a lot of sparkle but not enough firepower.
From the get-go, Villeneuve paints Blade Runner 2049 in his unique style. This is a rare, unhurried, futuristic film, much like Villeneuve's Arrival - philosophical and meditative.
More than the story, which leans on several tropes and clichés, it's the graph of the characters and the performances that elevate the emotion.
The House Next Door is very well crafted and a commendable addition to the genre.

Sunny Leone works hard to show she's got acting skills in a film where the only performer who can trump her is Sudha Chandran. The chemistry between Leone and Khan is as palpable as an ice cube on a frozen lake.
While the characters from A Death in the Gunj don't stay with you, the melancholy and mood linger on.
If all you're looking for is some laughs, then the ensemble cast will ensure you get the bang for your buck.
A dated premise, weak plot and abysmal characterisation are only partially made up for by the star power of Akshay Kumar.
The funny thing is, the movie has all the elements of a crowd-pleaser, but they fail to come together.
Overall, this film was a pleasure to watch. It's a complex love story, and one that does not pretend to be anything else.
A highly relatable story featuring likeable characters, teamed with great performances by both the lead and supporting actors, makes for an easy, pleasant viewing experience.
You're left feeling as though you've seen the film before.
Known for her brash outspoken nature in real life, Ranaut imparts some extra oomph to the characters she personifies on screen, and Rangoon's Miss Julia is no different.
Even the actors -- some of the finest in India -- let you down in places.
Your time would be better spent taking a yoga class.
It's a sweet, harmless, meandering tale with an engaging gimmick, but a great love story -- or a great movie -- it's not.
By the time Emma realizes that something might be wrong with her playful, pajama-clad paramour, there are so many red flags she might as well be at a communist rally.
The Mechanic is like a Beretta loaded with blanks -- quick and brutal but ultimately empty.
There is simply not enough material to make a compelling movie, even though Mr. Kapadia appears to have used every last frame of footage from the Formula One archives.
You know there's something wrong with a comedy when you'd rather see the main characters killed off than live happily ever after.
Quote not available.
You're left with the vague recollection of an interesting movie you were watching before you got kidnapped and subjected to over an hour of torture porn starring a fat, sadistic clown.
Our Idiot Brother may not be perfect, but, Crocs and all, Paul Rudd's performance is idiot-proof.
Quote not available.

Ultimately, Source Code makes good on its Hitchcockian opening sequence -- it may pale in comparison to the master, but it's a fun, puzzle-filled ride, with excellent pacing and a mounting uneasiness that recalls the best episodes of The Twilight Zone.
The performances and the music will keep you engrossed in the otherwise predictable story.
It shows, rather convincingly at that, how drama and detailing can keep the audience glued to seats even if none of the actors mouth a single word.
Stylishly dark and visually thrilling with turbo-charged mutant action, X-Men 2 is a spectacle that delivers on every count.
A tense and dramatic psycho-thriller that mostly takes place in a single day, Alexandra's Project is a dense and confronting film that savagely explores the notions of sex within a marriage.
In total bad taste, vulgar, irreverent, politically incorrect and very funny, Fat Pizza is an over-the-top, high-energy rocket ride of insanity.
With much to be enchanted by while you're watching and some worthwhile questions to think about afterwards, Tuck Everlasting is rewarding old-fashioned entertainment.
A fast-paced, big action hip-hop kung fu thriller, Cradle 2 The Grave stretches the boundaries of the genre with an engaging combo of Jet Li magic, a smart, funny script and spectacular stunts.
The film boasts sensational naturalistic performances and a raw edge that is undeniable. I don't think I can tell you that it's entertaining. It draws blood.
A sweet chapter in the life of a young girl battling to identify with her roots and environment, although it never reaches the heights that Bend It Like Beckham achieves.

Paradise is never found here by director Mario Andreacchio, who battles in an uphill struggle with John Goldsmith's script and a structure that totally distances us as it flits from the present to the past and years in between

A handsome production that pays great attention to authentic representation of the era, the legend and the landscape, Ned Kelly excels visually as it recounts a story that many may not fully know, albeit limiting our emotional connection with the man.
It's a whodunit in stilettos, where the stilettos are dangerous, sharp objects handled without care by women on the edge of a murderous breakdown.
This totally original film is a work of daring and brilliance; ignoring the usual parameters and conventions of cinema.
If you're a bit of a romantic with a penchant for playfulness, here is a fresh and funny, entertaining collision of hearts.
movie_title: How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Stephen Daldry has brought together all these strands and complex lives that question the essence of life and death, in a striking and compelling way. This is a story that tries to define happiness. It is about facing the many hours that lie between happi
Moving, insightful and thoroughly entertaining, The Good Girl takes us to the crossroads of the human heart. The question is which way to turn/
A stylishly intelligent thriller with an enthralling performance by John Malkovich.
A gloriously heartfelt story about identity, love and cultural divides.
A superbly made film about the shocking treatment of young girls rejected from their families by the nuns.
Some insanely wild ideas and funny moments, but ends up a pretty mediocre and disappointing affair.
Some of it is clever, but it is never melodic/
Cardoso has clearly connected with Josefina Lopez' work (originally a stage play based on her own experiences) and found something to say without making it either a feminist or a fatty tract.
As funny as a slap in the face with a dead sea urchin.
I'm sorry to say that Kangaroo Jack is top of my 2003 'worst list' so far.
The film's strengths are still Jackie Chan's fascinatingly inventive fight sequences: extensions of the knockabout physical comedy of the great silent era.
It has many strengths, including excellent use of locations and especially the flawless performances from the entire cast.

A strong script, powerful direction and splendid production design allows us to be transported into the life of Wladyslaw Szpilman, who is not only a pianist, but a good human being.

Thelma and Louise meets a tame version of Baise-Moi.
Risky, totally insane, at times brilliant, and absolutely original, Human Nature is a trip. A wonderfully wacky, weird satirical comedy that is hit and miss.
